questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a pelvic mass that was incidentally found on imaging during an evaluation for abdominal discomfort. She is postmenopausal and denies any abnormal bleeding or significant weight loss. A pelvic ultrasound reveals a solid, well-circumscribed ovarian mass. The mass is surgically excised, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans.  C) Brenner tumor

 

  • The histopathological image is characteristic of a Brenner tumor, which is a rare, benign ovarian tumor.
  • Brenner tumors are composed of transitional (urothelial-like) cells arranged in nests within a fibrous stroma.
  •  The cells often have a coffee bean appearance due to longitudinal nuclear grooves.
  •  These tumors are typically solid and well-circumscribed on imaging, and they are usually asymptomatic, often found incidentally during imaging for other reasons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Granulosa cell tumor: This type of ovarian tumor is typically associated with Call-Exner bodies (small, eosinophilic, fluid-filled spaces between granulosa cells) and is often hormonally active, leading to symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding.

 

 

Option B.  Serous cystadenoma: Serous cystadenomas are benign epithelial ovarian tumors that are typically cystic and lined by serous epithelium, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

 

Option D. Endometrioid carcinoma: Endometrioid carcinoma is a type of malignant ovarian tumor that is often associated with endometriosis and presents with complex glandular patterns on histology, unlike the nested pattern seen in Brenner tumors.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brenner tumors are benign ovarian neoplasms characterized by nests of transitional cells within a dense fibrous stroma.
  • These tumors are typically asymptomatic and are often discovered incidentally during imaging or surgery for other conditions.
  • The histological appearance of transitional cells in nests with a coffee bean nuclear appearance is distinctive for Brenner tumors.

 

Summary Table:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic kidney disease undergoes evaluation of his renal function. A study is performed to assess the glomerular filtration barrier's selective permeability. The graph below shows the relative filterability of different substances through the kidney based on their molecular size and charge, with 1 representing complete filtration and 0 representing no filtration. Based on the graph, which of the following correctly identifies substances A, B, and C?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Polycationic, neutral, polyanionic

 

  • The graph shows the relative filterability of substances through the kidney’s glomerular filtration barrier based on molecular size and charge.
  • The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged due to the presence of proteoglycans and other negatively charged molecules.
  • This negative charge repels polyanionic (negatively charged) substances, making them less filterable, especially as their size increases.
    • Substance A (highest filterability): Represents polycationic substances, which are positively charged. Because the filtration barrier is negatively charged, positively charged molecules are more readily filtered.
    • Substance B (intermediate filterability): Represents neutral substances. These are filtered based on size alone without significant influence from charge.
  • Substance C (lowest filterability): Represents polyanionic substances, which are negatively charged. These are repelled by the negative charge of the filtration barrier, making them the least filterable.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Neutral, polycationic, polyanionic: Incorrect because polycationic substances would be filtered more easily than neutral substances due to the charge interaction with the negatively charged filtration barrier.

 

Option B. Polyanionic, polycationic, neutral: Incorrect because polyanionic substances would be the least filterable, not the most.

 

Option D. Polyanionic, neutral, polycationic: Incorrect because polycationic substances would have the highest filterability, not the lowest.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The glomerular filtration barrier is negatively charged, which increases the filterability of polycationic substances and decreases the filterability of polyanionic substances, especially as their size increases.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman has a 9-month history of cough, occurring mainly during the day and especially at night. She frequently clears her throat but has no postnasal drip, acid reflux symptoms, dyspnea, or wheezing. She has never smoked and takes no medications. Physical examination reveals cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx. A chest radiograph is normal. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diphenhydramine and pseudoephedrine

 

  • The patient most likely has upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), which is the most common cause of chronic cough lasting more than 8 weeks.
  • UACS, previously known as postnasal drip syndrome, is associated with excess upper airway secretions, leading to symptoms such as cough, frequent throat clearing, and cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx.
  • The first-line treatment for UACS, particularly when due to nonallergic rhinitis, includes a first-generation antihistamine (like diphenhydramine) combined with a decongestant (like pseudoephedrine).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lansoprazole: Appropriate for treating GERD-related cough, but this patient lacks symptom of GERD.

 

Option C. Spirometry and methacholine challenge: Useful for diagnosing asthma, particularly cough-variant asthma, but should be considered only after empiric treatment for UACS.

 

Option D. Sputum analysis for eosinophils: Considered when other common causes like UACS, asthma, and GERD have been ruled out or empiric treatments have failed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with chronic cough and signs of upper airway involvement, UACS should be the first condition considered and treated with an appropriate antihistamine and decongestant combination.
  • Other causes of chronic cough, such as asthma or GERD, should be explored only if UACS treatment is ineffective.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with progressive bilateral hearing loss and episodes of dizziness over the past year. She reports difficulty maintaining balance, especially when walking in dim light. An MRI of the brain reveals bilateral vestibular schwannomas. Glial hamartia are also detected during the workup. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Neurofibromatosis type 2

 

  • The clinical presentation of bilateral vestibular schwannomas, along with progressive hearing loss and balance difficulties, strongly suggests Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2), a genetic disorder that predisposes individuals to the development of multiple central nervous system tumors, including vestibular schwannomas.
  •  NF2 is also associated with other tumors, such as meningiomas, ependymomas and glial hamartia.
  • The presence of glial hamartia further supports the diagnosis of NF2, as these benign, tumor-like malformations are characteristic of this condition.
  • Glial hamartia refers to a malformation involving glial cells, which are the supportive cells in the nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sturge-Weber syndrome: Sturge-Weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by a facial port-wine stain, leptomeningeal angiomas, and neurological symptoms such as seizures. It is not associated with vestibular schwannomas or glial hamartomas, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Option C. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis is characterized by the presence of benign tumors in various organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys and heart. Although it involves cortical tubers and subependymal nodules, it is not associated with vestibular schwannomas or glial hamartomas.

 

Option D. Cowden syndrome: Cowden syndrome is a genetic disorder associated with multiple hamartomas and an increased risk of several types of cancer, including breast, thyroid and endometrial cancers. It is not typically associated with vestibular schwannomas or glial hamartomas, distinguishing it from NF2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) is characterized by the development of bilateral vestibular schwannomas, progressive hearing loss, and balance issues.
  • The presence of glial hamartomas further supports the diagnosis of NF2, a condition involving multiple types of tumors in the central nervous system.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male with treatment-resistant schizophrenia has been prescribed clozapine. The psychiatrist discusses the necessary monitoring protocol for white blood cells (WBC) and absolute neutrophil count (ANC) to prevent the risk of agranulocytosis. How often should WBC and ANC be monitored after 1.5 years of clozapine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monthly

 

  • After one year of clozapine therapy, WBC and ANC should be monitored monthly due to the continuing risk of agranulocytosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weekly: Monitoring is recommended in the first six months of therapy as the risk of agranulocytosis is higher in the initial period of clozapine therapy.

 

Option B. Bi-weekly: Monitoring is recommended between six months to one year. 

 

Option D. Every three months: It is not an appropriate interval for WBC and ANC monitoring during clozapine treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 67-year-old male with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is scheduled for a total knee replacement. He receives spinal anesthesia with 0.75% bupivacaine at the L3-L4 level. Shortly after the procedure, he begins to experience difficulty breathing, profound hypotension (BP 70/40 mmHg), and bradycardia (HR 45 bpm). He becomes increasingly lethargic, and his oxygen saturation drops to 85%. What is the most likely complication the patient is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) High spinal anesthesia

 

  • High spinal anesthesia occurs when the local anesthetic spreads more cephalad than intended, blocking nerves at higher levels, including those that control the heart and respiratory muscles.
  •  This results in hypotension, bradycardia and respiratory compromise, as seen in this patient.
  • The sensory level reaching the C6 dermatome strongly suggests that the anesthetic has affected the upper thoracic and possibly cervical segments of the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic shock: Although anaphylactic shock can cause hypotension and respiratory distress, it is typically associated with a history of exposure to an allergen and presents with additional symptoms such as urticaria, angioedema and bronchospasm. The rapid onset of symptoms following spinal anesthesia and the sensory level reaching the cervical dermatomes make this less likely.

 

Option B. Myocardial infarction: Myocardial infarction can cause hypotension and bradycardia, but it usually presents with chest pain, shortness of breath and other signs of cardiac ischemia. The lack of chest pain and the presence of a high sensory block point to a different cause.

 

Option D. Pulmonary embolism: Pulmonary embolism can cause sudden onset of hypotension, hypoxia and respiratory distress. However, it is not related to the level of spinal anesthesia and would typically present with chest pain, tachycardia and clear lung fields on auscultation, which is not described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • High spinal anesthesia is a serious complication that occurs when the local anesthetic spreads beyond the intended level, leading to extensive sympathetic blockade, severe hypotension, bradycardia, and respiratory difficulty.
  •  Immediate recognition and intervention, including supportive measures such as fluids, vasopressors, and airway management, are critical in managing this condition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with intermittent numbness and tingling in her right hand, particularly after prolonged periods of writing or overhead activities. On physical examination, there is a decreased radial pulse with arm abduction and external rotation (positive Adson's test). A chest X-ray is performed, as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the radiological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical rib

 

  • The chest X-ray provided shows an additional rib-like bony structure arising from the cervical spine, which is consistent with a cervical rib.
  •  Cervical ribs are extra ribs that arise from the seventh cervical vertebra.
  •  While often asymptomatic, they can compress nearby neurovascular structures, leading to symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome, such as the numbness and tingling described by the patient.
  • The presence of a cervical rib is a classic finding on a radiograph that should prompt further evaluation for neurovascular compression syndromes.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option A. Clavicle fracture: A clavicle fracture would appear as a discontinuity or abnormal angulation of the clavicle on X-ray. This image does not show evidence of a fracture.

 

Option B. Pancoast tumor: This type of tumor, typically at the lung apex, would appear as a soft tissue mass on the X-ray, not as an extra rib.

 

Option D. Scalene muscle hypertrophy: While scalene muscle hypertrophy can contribute to thoracic outlet syndrome, it is not a diagnosis that would be directly visible on a chest X-ray. The radiologic finding here is specifically a cervical rib.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A cervical rib is an extra rib arising from the cervical spine, often detected on chest X-ray. It can cause thoracic outlet syndrome by compressing nearby neurovascular structures.

questions.text: Identify the scenario in which the technique is performed.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Liver resection

 

  • The image shows Pringle manoeuver, used for intra-operative control of liver bleed.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A, B and D: Abdominal aortic bleed, lap cholecystectomy and duodenal anastomosis normally does not involve liver bleeds.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pringle’s technique involves clamping the free edge of the hepatoduodenal ligament to control liver bleed.

questions.text: A judge in an Indian court has the authority to impose a prison sentence of up to 10 years but cannot impose the death penalty. Which type of judge is this?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Assistant Sessions Judge

 

  • The Assistant Sessions Judge has the authority to impose imprisonment for up to 10 years but does not have the jurisdiction to impose the death penalty.
  • This role is typical of mid-level judicial authority within the Indian court system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Additional Sessions Judge: This court can impose the death penalty, but such a sentence must be confirmed by the High Court.

 

Option C. Chief Judicial Magistrate: This court can impose imprisonment for up to 7 years and cannot impose the death penalty.

 

Option D. 1st Class Judicial Magistrate: This court can impose imprisonment for up to 3 years and cannot impose the death penalty.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indian Court System

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents with 90 minutes of crushing anterior chest pain. His blood pressure is 93/65 mm Hg, pulse rate is 112/min, and he is diaphoretic. Pulsus paradoxus is absent, jugular venous distension is present, lungs are clear, and heart sounds are distant without murmur. ECG shows 2-mm ST-segment elevations in leads II, III, and aVF, and 0.5-mm ST-segment elevation in lead V1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right ventricular infarction

 

  • In the context of an inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI), the triad of hypotension, clear lung fields, and jugular venous distention strongly suggests a right ventricular (RV) infarction. RV infarction occurs in about 20% of patients with an inferior wall STEMI. The presence of ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, along with signs of RV dysfunction (elevated jugular venous pressure, hypotension, and clear lungs), supports this diagnosis. Immediate management involves aggressive volume resuscitation to optimize RV filling and, if necessary, intravenous vasopressors, followed by urgent coronary revascularization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardiac tamponade: Characterized by hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and jugular venous distention, often with pulsus paradoxus, which is absent here. ST changes in the inferior leads are not typical of tamponade.

 

Option B. Pulmonary embolism: Can cause right ventricular strain and hypotension, but it is unlikely to cause ST-segment elevations specifically localized to the inferior leads as seen in this case.

 

Option D. Ventricular septal rupture: Typically presents 1 to 3 days after a myocardial infarction with a new harsh murmur and respiratory distress, which is not consistent with the immediate presentation described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with an inferior STEMI, the presence of hypotension, clear lung fields, and jugular venous distention suggests right ventricular infarction, which requires prompt recognition and management to improve outcomes.

questions.text: A 14-year-old adolescent presents to the clinic with a unique set of symptoms. He reports experiencing episodes of sudden and uncontrollable muscle weakness, often triggered by laughter or other strong emotions. During these episodes, he remains conscious but is unable to move, which lasts for a few seconds to a minute. Additionally, he describes vivid and dream-like hallucinations that occur when falling asleep or waking up. He also mentions excessive daytime sleepiness, often struggling to stay awake during lectures. Which of the following conditions best explains this tetrad of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Narcolepsy

 

  • Narcolepsy is a sleep disorder characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: Excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness triggered by strong emotions), hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations (vivid, dream-like hallucinations upon falling asleep or waking up), and sleep paralysis.
  • The patient's symptoms are a classic presentation of narcolepsy, making this the correct diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Generalized Anxiety Disorder: Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) involves excessive, uncontrollable worry about various aspects of daily life. While GAD can cause fatigue and sleep disturbances, it does not typically cause sudden muscle weakness (cataplexy) or hypnagogic hallucinations. Therefore, GAD does not explain the full range of symptoms described in the case.

 

Option B. Multiple Sclerosis: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system. It can cause a variety of neurological symptoms, including fatigue and muscle weakness. However, MS does not typically cause cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations, or excessive daytime sleepiness, making it an unlikely diagnosis for this patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Catatonia: Catatonia is a neuropsychiatric syndrome characterized by motor abnormalities, such as immobility, mutism or repetitive movements. Although catatonia involves altered behavior, it does not include the specific symptoms of cataplexy, hypnagogic hallucinations or excessive daytime sleepiness, so it does not fit the clinical picture described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Narcolepsy is a sleep disorder characterized by a tetrad of symptoms: excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, hypnagogic or hypnopompic hallucinations and sleep paralysis.
  •  Recognizing this cluster of symptoms is essential for diagnosing narcolepsy and differentiating it from other conditions that may present with overlapping features.

choices.text: DNA polymerase I

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial infections and is found to have a genetic disorder affecting DNA replication. Laboratory analysis reveals that his immune cells produce numerous short fragments of DNA with RNA sequences attached to their 5’ ends, indicating a defect in DNA synthesis. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) DNA polymerase I

 

  • DNA polymerase I is responsible for removing RNA primers from the 5' ends of Okazaki fragments and replacing them with DNA nucleotides during DNA replication.
  • A mutation in the gene encoding DNA polymerase I would prevent the removal of RNA primers, leading to the accumulation of short DNA fragments with RNA sequences at their 5' ends, as seen in this patient.
  • This defect in DNA replication would result in a lethal mutation for a bacterium and is similarly deleterious in human cells, contributing to the patient's recurrent infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DNA helicase: This enzyme unwinds the DNA double helix at the replication fork, allowing replication to proceed. A defect in DNA helicase would prevent the unwinding of DNA, but it would not result in the production of short DNA fragments with RNA sequences at their 5' ends.

 

Option B. DNA ligase: DNA ligase is responsible for joining Okazaki fragments by forming phosphodiester bonds between the 3' end of one fragment and the 5' end of another. A defect in this enzyme would result in unconnected DNA fragments, but they would not have RNA sequences at their 5' ends.

 

Option D. DNA gyrase: This enzyme (a type of topoisomerase) relieves supercoiling in front of the replication fork. While crucial for DNA replication, a defect in DNA gyrase would not result in RNA sequences remaining at the 5' ends of DNA fragments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DNA polymerase I is crucial for removing RNA primers during DNA replication.
  • A defect in this enzyme leads to the accumulation of short DNA fragments with RNA sequences at their 5' ends, significantly impairing DNA synthesis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male patient with refractory glaucoma has been recommended for a surgical intervention to manage his intraocular pressure, as medications have not been effective. His ophthalmologist suggests a procedure involving the implantation of a glaucoma valve. Which of the following surgeries typically involves this type of implant?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Setons

 

  • Glaucoma valve implants, often referred to as setons, are used in the surgical management of glaucoma to facilitate aqueous humor outflow from the anterior chamber, thereby reducing intraocular pressure.
  • These devices are a subtype of glaucoma drainage implants and are specifically designed to prevent the closure of the surgically created drainage pathway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trabeculectomy: This involves creating a drainage fistula in the sclera to reduce intraocular pressure but does not typically involve the insertion of a valve.

 

Option B. Sclerotomy: This surgical procedure makes incisions in the sclera for various reasons but is not specifically associated with the implantation of glaucoma valves.

 

Option C. Laser photocoagulation: A non-invasive laser treatment used to treat retinal conditions and glaucoma by targeting the trabecular meshwork to increase outflow of aqueous humor but does not involve implants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glaucoma valve implants (setons) are used in specific surgical settings to manage severe or refractory glaucoma by providing a controlled pathway for fluid drainage, helping to sustain lower intraocular pressure and prevent further optic nerve damage

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is known to be a racemic mixture of two enantiomers with different pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic properties?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Verapamil

 

  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker that exists as a racemic mixture of two enantiomers, R-verapamil and S-verapamil.
  • These enantiomers have different pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles.
  • S-verapamil is more potent as a calcium channel blocker, whereas R-verapamil is metabolized more rapidly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dilantin: Dilantin (phenytoin) is not a racemic mixture; it is a single enantiomer and does not exhibit significant enantiomer-specific differences in its pharmacokinetic or pharmacodynamic properties.

 

Option B. Digoxin: Digoxin is not a racemic mixture; it is a single compound with no enantiomeric forms.

 

Option D. Octreotide: Octreotide is a synthetic octapeptide that mimics natural somatostatin, and it does not exist as a racemic mixture with enantiomers having different properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Verapamil is a racemic mixture of R- and S-enantiomers, with S-verapamil being the more potent calcium channel blocker.
  • The enantiomers have different pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic profiles, influencing their overall clinical effects.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the emergency department following a stab injury to the chest. He is hemodynamically stable but complains of severe chest pain and shortness of breath. A chest X-ray is performed, revealing the imaging findings shown in the image. Based on the radiographic findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemothorax

 

  • In this scenario, the patient has sustained a stab injury to the chest, and an X-ray has been provided as part of the diagnostic process.
  • The X-ray described in the explanation reveals a white area on the affected side of the lung field.
  • Hemothorax: A hemothorax occurs when blood accumulates in the pleural cavity.
  • On a chest X-ray, this condition presents as a white-out or opaque area on the affected side due to the fluid (blood) collecting in the pleural space.
  • The clinical findings, such as hypotension (which can result from blood loss), further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax: In contrast, a pneumothorax, which is the presence of air in the pleural space, would show up on a chest X-ray as a black area (radiolucency) without lung markings, indicating air in the pleural space. This would not match the white-out appearance seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option C. Diaphragmatic Rupture: This condition would typically present with air-fluid levels within the chest cavity if abdominal organs have herniated into the thoracic cavity. However, this is not indicated by the described X-ray findings.

 

Option D. Lung Contusion: A lung contusion would appear as a focal area of consolidation (white patch) due to localized bleeding or bruising of the lung tissue, but it would not cause a widespread white-out of the lung field.Thus, the presence of a white-out on the X-ray, along with clinical signs such as hypotension, suggests the correct diagnosis is hemothorax.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A white-out on the chest X-ray after a chest injury, especially with accompanying hypotension, is indicative of a hemothorax, which is the accumulation of blood in the pleural space.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a burning sensation in the soles, a condition often referred to as "Burning Sole Syndrome." This symptom is most commonly associated with a deficiency in which of the following vitamins?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pantothenic acid

 

  • "Burning Sole Syndrome" is classically associated with a deficiency of pantothenic acid, also known as vitamin B5.
  • Pantothenic acid is crucial for the synthesis of coenzyme A and is involved in fatty acid metabolism.
  • Deficiency, though rare, can lead to symptoms like burning feet, fatigue, and irritability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Riboflavin: Deficiency can lead to symptoms such as angular stomatitis, cheilosis, and glossitis, but it is not typically associated with Burning Sole Syndrome.

 

Option B. Pyridoxine: Deficiency of pyridoxine (vitamin B6) can cause peripheral neuropathy and anemia but is not specifically linked to Burning Sole Syndrome.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neurological symptoms, including peripheral neuropathy, but it is not directly linked to Burning Sole Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • "Burning Sole Syndrome" is typically associated with a deficiency of pantothenic acid (vitamin B5), highlighting the importance of this vitamin in nerve function and overall metabolic processes.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with sickle cell disease is scheduled for a minor surgical procedure. Which anesthetic modality should be avoided to prevent complications related to her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intravenous Regional Anaesthesia

 

  • Intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier block) is contraindicated in sickle cell disease due to the use of a tourniquet, which can lead to ischemia and trigger sickling of red blood cells in the affected limb.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. General Anaesthesia: Generally safe when carefully monitored to avoid hypoxia and acidosis.

 

Option B. Brachial Plexus Block: Typically, safe and does not involve the use of a tourniquet, reducing the risk of ischemia.

 

Option D. Spinal Anaesthesia: Safe with appropriate precautions to avoid triggers like hypoxia, hypovolemia, and acidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Intravenous regional anesthesia (Bier block) should be avoided in patients with sickle cell disease due to the risk of ischemia and subsequent sickling crisis caused by tourniquet use.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 41 weeks gestation is in active labor with cervical dilation at 6 cm. The cardiotocography (CTG) trace shown below is reviewed. Based on the pattern seen, what does this CTG trace most likely indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fetal hypoxia

 

  • The CTG trace shows late decelerations, which are characterized by a gradual decrease and return to baseline of the fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of the contraction and ends after the contraction has finished.
  • Late decelerations are a sign of uteroplacental insufficiency and are associated with fetal hypoxia.
  • This pattern is concerning and indicates that the fetus may not be receiving adequate oxygen, necessitating prompt evaluation and possible intervention to prevent further compromise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cord prolapse: Cord prolapse typically presents with sudden, severe variable decelerations or a prolonged deceleration, not with the pattern of late decelerations seen in this trace.

 

Option B. Head compression: Head compression is associated with early decelerations, where the deceleration mirrors the contraction in both timing and shape. This is a benign finding, unlike the late decelerations associated with fetal hypoxia.

 

Option D. Cord compression: Cord compression is usually associated with variable decelerations, which are abrupt decreases in fetal heart rate with varying onset and duration, unlike the gradual late decelerations seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Late decelerations on a CTG trace are indicative of uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia, requiring immediate attention to prevent fetal distress.

questions.text: Based on the CT image given, identify the correct diagnosis among the given options:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fungal ball (Mycetoma)

 

  • The CT image provided corresponds to Fungal ball (Mycetoma), specifically identified in the first image.
  • The first image shows a classic appearance of a fungal ball (mycetoma) within the sinus, typically presenting as a hyperdense lesion in the sinus cavity without bone destruction.
  • This is commonly found in the maxillary sinus and can be seen as a high-attenuation mass on CT imaging.
  • It is a non-invasive form of fungal infection, typically seen in immunocompetent patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis: Allergic fungal rhinosinusitis is characterized by the presence of allergic mucin, usually with scattered hyperdense areas due to the presence of fungal elements. There is often expansion of the involved sinus with thinning of the bony walls, but without bone destruction, which is typical in chronic allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

 

Option C. Invasive Mucormycosis: Invasive mucormycosis, which is a severe, often life-threatening fungal infection, invades the sinuses and adjacent structures, including bone and soft tissue. On CT, it may show bony erosion, orbital involvement, and infiltration into the surrounding tissues, indicating its aggressive nature. This condition is often seen in immunocompromised patients.

 

 

Option D. Ethmoidal Polyposis: The fourth image depicts ethmoidal polyposis, which shows multiple soft tissue masses within the ethmoid sinuses, often causing sinus opacification. These are benign growths of the mucosa and do not show the hyperdense characteristics of a fungal ball or the aggressive features of mucormycosis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fungal ball (mycetoma) typically presents as a hyperdense mass within the sinus on CT, often in the maxillary sinus, without bone destruction, and is non-invasive, usually affecting immunocompetent individuals.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with developmental delay, hypotonia and hyperphagia leading to obesity. On examination, you notice small hands and feet, almond-shaped eyes and a narrow bifrontal diameter. Which genetic mechanism is most commonly responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13

 

  • Prader-Willi syndrome is most commonly caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13 region, which accounts for about 70% of cases.
  • This syndrome is characterized by the features described in the question, including developmental delay, hypotonia, hyperphagia leading to obesity, and distinctive facial features such as small hands and feet, almond-shaped eyes, and a narrow bifrontal diameter.
  •  The deletion of this specific region on the paternal chromosome leads to the absence of paternal gene expression in this region, resulting in Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uniparental disomy of chromosome 15: Uniparental disomy refers to the inheritance of both copies of a chromosome from one parent. In the context of Prader-Willi syndrome, uniparental disomy of chromosome 15 (where both copies are inherited from the mother) accounts for about 25% of cases. While it is a known cause, it is less common than the paternal deletion.

 

Option C. Maternal deletion of chromosome 15q11-q13: A deletion on the maternal chromosome 15q11-q13 region leads to Angelman syndrome, not Prader-Willi syndrome. Angelman syndrome is characterized by severe developmental delay, speech impairment, ataxia and a happy demeanor, which is very different from the clinical presentation of Prader-Willi syndrome.

 

Option D. Trinucleotide repeat expansion: Trinucleotide repeat expansions are responsible for disorders like Fragile X syndrome and Huntington's disease. This genetic mechanism does not cause Prader-Willi syndrome and is unrelated to the clinical features described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prader-Willi syndrome is most commonly caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15q11-q13.
  • This syndrome is characterized by developmental delay, hypotonia, hyperphagia leading to obesity, and distinctive facial features such as small hands and feet, almond-shaped eyes and a narrow bifrontal diameter.
  • Recognizing these features and understanding the genetic basis of Prader-Willi syndrome are crucial for early diagnosis and management of the condition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is started on an intravenous infusion of procainamide at 9:00 AM to manage his ventricular arrhythmia. The half-life of procainamide is 2 hours. At 1:00 PM on the same day, the blood concentration of procainamide is measured at 3 mg/L. Assuming that the infusion rate remains constant, what is the expected steady-state concentration of procainamide after 2 days of continuous infusion?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 mg/L

 

  • The steady-state concentration of a drug during continuous IV infusion is reached when the rate of drug administration equals the rate of drug elimination.
  • For a drug with first-order kinetics, the plasma concentration reaches approximately 50% of the steady-state level after one half-life, 75% after two half-lives, and over 90% after four half-lives.
  • In this case, the drug's half-life is 2 hours. By 1:00 PM, 4 hours have passed since the infusion started, meaning the plasma concentration has reached 75% of the steady-state level.

 

Given:

 

  • 75% of steady-state concentration = 3 mg/L
  • Therefore, steady-state concentration = 3 /0.75 = 4 mg/L

 

After 2 days (which is significantly more than 4 half-lives), the steady-state concentration would be 4 mg/L.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For drugs given by constant IV infusion, the plasma concentration reaches 50% of the steady-state after one half-life, 75% after two half-lives, and 87.5% after three half-lives.
  • The steady-state concentration is typically reached after 4-5 half-lives.

questions.text: Identify the incision shown below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Midfacial degloving

 

  • The image shown is indicative of the midfacial degloving procedure.
  • Midfacial degloving is a surgical approach used to access the midfacial skeleton without visible scars.
  • The incision involves elevating the soft tissues of the midface off the facial skeleton, usually through a combination of intraoral and nasal incisions.
  • It is particularly used in procedures for removing tumors or for extensive reconstructive surgery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caldwell-Luc: The Caldwell-Luc procedure is an approach used for accessing the maxillary sinus, typically through an incision made in the gingivobuccal sulcus above the upper canine and premolars. This procedure is often performed to address chronic maxillary sinusitis, remove tumors, or obtain biopsy samples.

 

 

Option C. Open Rhinoplasty: Open rhinoplasty involves an incision across the columella to lift the nasal skin and expose the underlying cartilage and bone. This approach provides better visualization and access to the nasal structure for reshaping during rhinoplasty.

 

 

Option D. Lateral Rhinotomy: Lateral rhinotomy is a surgical procedure where an incision is made along the side of the nose to gain access to the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses, often for the removal of tumors.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The midfacial degloving incision provides access to the midface and nasal structures without external scarring, often used in surgeries involving the nasal cavity and sinuses.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will most effectively distinguish Vibrio cholerae from E. coli?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Oxidase test

 

  • Vibrio cholerae is oxidase positive, meaning it produces the enzyme oxidase, which is used to identify bacteria that produce cytochrome c oxidase.
  • This characteristic distinguishes it from E. coli, which is oxidase negative.
  • The oxidase test is crucial for differentiating Vibrio spp. from other Gram-negative enteric bacteria.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Catalase test: Both Vibrio cholerae and E. coli are catalase positive, so this test does not distinguish between the two.

 

Option C. Optochin sensitive: This test is primarily used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae (which is optochin sensitive) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci and is not relevant to either Vibrio cholerae or E. coli.

 

Option D. Lactose fermenter: E. coli ferments lactose, whereas Vibrio cholerae does not typically ferment lactose. While this could also serve as a distinguishing test, the oxidase test is a more direct and commonly used biochemical test for initial differentiation in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The oxidase test is a quick and effective method to differentiate Vibrio cholerae from E. coli, as Vibrio is oxidase positive, contrasting with the oxidase negative status of E. coli.
  • This distinction helps guide appropriate clinical and public health responses, particularly in cases of suspected cholera outbreaks.

questions.text:
In a study evaluating the relationship between hypertension (HTN) and dietary sodium intake, the following data were collected:

 

 

Based on this data, what is the estimated odds ratio (OR) for developing hypertension when on a high-sodium diet compared to a low-sodium diet?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2.67

 

  • The odds ratio (OR) is calculated as follows:

 

 

 

  • This value indicates that individuals with a high-sodium diet are approximately 2.67 times more likely to have hypertension compared to those with a low-sodium diet.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The odds ratio is a measure used to determine the strength of association between an exposure (e.g., high-sodium diet) and an outcome (e.g., hypertension).
  • An OR greater than 1 suggests a positive association between the exposure and the outcome.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with a painless mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen, as shown in the image. The mass is firm, mobile and non-tender. She also reports increased urinary frequency and intermittent constipation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Wilm's tumor

 

  • Wilm's tumor, also known as nephroblastoma, is the most common renal malignancy in children.
  • It typically presents as a painless, firm, mobile abdominal mass in children aged 3-10 years.
  • The mass may cause secondary symptoms such as increased urinary frequency or intermittent constipation due to its compression on nearby structures.
  • The absence of pain or tenderness, along with the characteristics of the mass, makes Wilm's tumor the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Appendiceal abscess: An appendiceal abscess usually presents with symptoms of acute appendicitis, including abdominal pain, fever, and signs of localized peritonitis, such as rebound tenderness and guarding. The lack of pain and the presence of a firm, mobile mass make an appendiceal abscess unlikely in this case.

 

Option B. Ovarian cyst: Ovarian cysts can present as abdominal masses, but they are often associated with abdominal pain, particularly if the cyst undergoes torsion, rupture or hemorrhage. A painless, firm, mobile mass in a young girl is less typical for an ovarian cyst, especially without other gynecological symptoms.

 

Option D. Mesenteric lymphadenitis: Mesenteric lymphadenitis typically presents with abdominal pain rather than a palpable mass. It is often associated with a recent viral illness and can mimic appendicitis, presenting with fever and right lower quadrant pain. The clinical presentation in this case, including the presence of a firm, mobile mass, does not fit with mesenteric lymphadenitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wilm's tumor is the most common renal tumor in children and typically presents as a painless, firm and mobile abdominal mass.
  • It is essential to recognize the typical presentation of Wilm's tumor, including secondary symptoms such as urinary frequency or constipation due to compression of surrounding organs, to ensure prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman in labor is being monitored in the labor room. The image below shows a procedure being performed. Identify the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cardiotocography

 

  • The image depicts cardiotocography (CTG), a common procedure performed in the labor room to monitor the fetal heart rate and uterine contractions simultaneously.
  •  This method helps assess fetal well-being and detect any signs of fetal distress during labor.
  • The device shown in the image is connected to external sensors placed on the mother's abdomen: one to monitor uterine contractions and the other to detect the fetal heart rate.
  •  The readings from these sensors are displayed on a monitor and can be printed out for further analysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid index determination: This procedure involves an ultrasound assessment to measure the amount of amniotic fluid around the fetus. It does not involve the use of external monitors or straps as seen in the image.

 

Option B. Amniocentesis: Amniocentesis is an invasive procedure in which a needle is inserted into the amniotic sac to obtain a sample of amniotic fluid for diagnostic testing. It is typically performed under ultrasound guidance and does not resemble the monitoring setup shown in the image.

 

Option D. MCA Doppler: MCA Doppler refers to Doppler ultrasonography of the middle cerebral artery, used to assess fetal anemia or other conditions by measuring blood flow velocities. This is done via ultrasound and does not involve the equipment seen in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiotocography (CTG) is a vital monitoring technique used during labor to assess fetal heart rate patterns and uterine contractions, helping to identify fetal distress and guide obstetric management.

choices.text: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign
Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD with complaints of mild lower abdominal pain and light vaginal spotting. Her menstrual period is delayed by about 7 days, and she reports a faintly positive result on a home urine pregnancy test (UPT). An ultrasound with color doppler is performed, and the image shown below is observed. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the sonographic sign depicted?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

 

  • The image provided in the scenario is characteristic of the "Ring of fire" sign on Doppler ultrasound, which is often associated with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • The "Ring of fire" sign is a term used to describe the hypervascular appearance surrounding an ectopic pregnancy on color Doppler ultrasound, indicating significant blood flow around the abnormal implantation site, typically in the fallopian tube.
  • This vascular pattern is a critical finding in diagnosing an ectopic pregnancy, especially when an intrauterine pregnancy is not visualized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign: The "Circle of fire" is not a term commonly used in medical literature, and while a corpus luteal cyst can show increased vascularity, the specific "Ring of fire" sign is more classically associated with an ectopic pregnancy.

 

Option B. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign: The term "Circle of fire" is less accurate in this context. The correct term used to describe the vascularity around an ectopic pregnancy is "Ring of fire."

 

Option C. Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign: Although a corpus luteal cyst can show increased vascularity on Doppler ultrasound, the "Ring of fire" sign is more specifically associated with an ectopic pregnancy rather than a corpus luteal cyst. The key to distinguishing these conditions lies in the clinical context and other ultrasound findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "Ring of fire" sign on Doppler ultrasound is a hallmark of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy, indicating the hypervascularity surrounding the abnormal implantation site.
  • Recognizing this sign is crucial for timely diagnosis and management of an ectopic pregnancy, a potentially life-threatening condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with left flank pain and mild hematuria. Urine analysis shows dumbbell shaped crystals. What is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Plain CT KUB

 

  • Plain CT KUB (Kidneys, Ureters, and Bladder) is the investigation of choice for diagnosing urolithiasis, especially when crystals are detected in the urine.
  • The presence of dumbbell-shaped crystals suggests calcium oxalate stones, which are radio-opaque and can be easily identified on a non-contrast CT scan.
  • Plain CT KUB is highly sensitive and specific for detecting renal and ureteric stones, allowing for accurate diagnosis and management planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  X-ray KUB: While X-ray KUB can detect some types of renal stones, it is not as sensitive as CT, particularly for smaller stones or stones that are radiolucent. X-ray KUB may miss smaller stones or those located in areas obscured by overlying structures.

 

Option C. CECT KUB: Contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is not typically required for the initial evaluation of suspected urolithiasis. The use of contrast can obscure stones or lead to unnecessary complications, especially in patients with renal impairment.

 

Option D. USG KUB: Ultrasound is a non-invasive option for evaluating suspected renal stones, particularly in pregnant women or those with contraindications to radiation. However, it is less sensitive than CT for detecting small stones or stones located in the ureters, making it a secondary option when CT is not available or advisable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plain CT KUB is the investigation of choice for diagnosing urolithiasis due to its high sensitivity and specificity in detecting renal and ureteric stones, including calcium oxalate stones suggested by dumbbell-shaped crystals on urinalysis.

questions.text: A public health team conducted a survey in 40 towns with a total population of 80,000 to assess the prevalence of dengue. Out of 15,000 blood samples were examined, 300 were positive for dengue. What is the annual incidence rate of dengue per 1,000 population?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3.75

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The annual incidence rate per 1,000 population is a useful measure in public health to determine the frequency of new cases of a disease in a population.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and osteomyelitis of the right calcaneal bone is evaluated for anemia. Her current medications include intravenous antibiotics, metformin, and liraglutide. Laboratory studies reveal hemoglobin 9.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume 80 fL, reticulocyte count 0.5%, elevated ferritin, low iron, low total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and transferrin saturation >20%. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient's anemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue current management

 

  • This patient has anemia of inflammation, often seen in chronic infections like osteomyelitis.
  • This type of anemia typically presents with a hemoglobin level of 8 to 10 g/dL, low reticulocyte count, elevated ferritin, low serum iron, and reduced TIBC.
  • The appropriate management is to address the underlying inflammatory condition, as the anemia does not usually require specific treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Darbepoetin alfa: While it may improve anemia of inflammation, it is not routinely recommended due to potential risks, including thrombosis. It is usually reserved for patients with additional indications, such as anemia of chronic kidney disease.

 

Option B. Intravenous iron: This is indicated in cases of iron deficiency or in conditions where oral iron is inadequate. This patient does not exhibit signs of iron deficiency.

 

Option C. Oral iron supplementation: Not appropriate because the patient is not iron deficient, as indicated by the elevated ferritin and transferrin saturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with anemia of inflammation, treatment is generally focused on the underlying condition rather than the anemia itself, as specific anemia treatments like iron supplementation or erythropoiesis-stimulating agents are not typically required unless there is an additional indication.

choices.text: Drug A may be oxybutynin and is used for the treatment of overactive bladder.
Drug B may be mirabegron and is used for the treatment of atonic bladder.
Drug C may be tamsulosin and is used to relieve urinary symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).
Drug B is relatively safer in patients of Alzheimer disease compared to drug A.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with symptoms of urinary urgency, frequency, and occasional incontinence. The physician considers starting him on one of three medications, each with different mechanisms of action, as illustrated in the figure provided. The figure shows the actions of Drug A, Drug B, and Drug C on different receptors in the bladder and urethra. Which of the following statements regarding these drugs is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drug B may be mirabegron and is used for the treatment of atonic bladder.

 

  • Drug A: Oxybutynin is a muscarinic receptor antagonist (particularly M3 receptor), which reduces bladder contractions and is used to treat overactive bladder. This statement is correct.
  • Drug B: Mirabegron is a 3-adrenergic agonist, which relaxes the detrusor muscle of the bladder and is used to treat overactive bladder, not atonic bladder. The statement that it is used for atonic bladder is incorrect.
  • Drug C: Tamsulosin is an 1-adrenergic receptor antagonist, which relaxes the smooth muscle in the bladder neck and prostate, improving urinary flow in patients with BPH. This statement is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Drug A may be oxybutynin and is used for the treatment of overactive bladder: This statement is true, as oxybutynin is a commonly used antimuscarinic agent for overactive bladder.

 

Option C. Drug C may be tamsulosin and is used to relieve urinary symptoms of BPH: This is also correct, as tamsulosin is an 1 blocker used to relieve urinary symptoms associated with BPH.

 

Option D. Drug B is relatively safer in patients of Alzheimer disease compared to drug A: Drug of choice of overactive bladder in Alzheimer disease is mirabegron.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxybutynin (Drug A) is a muscarinic antagonist used to treat overactive bladder.
  • Mirabegron (Drug B) is a 3-adrenergic agonist used to treat overactive bladder, not atonic bladder.
  • Tamsulosin (Drug C) is an 1-adrenergic antagonist used to treat urinary symptoms in BPH.

questions.text:
An ophthalmologist is categorizing patient data based on the National Programme for Control of Blindness (NPCB) standards. Match the visual impairment categories (Column A) to the correct classifications (Column B):

 

Column A

 

A: < 6/18 to 6/60

B: < 6/60 to 3/60

C: < 3/60 to 1/60

D: < 1/60 to perception of light

 

Column B:

 

I: Economic Blindness

II: Manifest Blindness

III: Social Blindness

IV: Low Vision
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-IV, B-I, C-III, D-II

 

  • A: < 6/18 to 6/60 corresponds to IV - Low Vision.
  • B: < 6/60 to 3/60 corresponds to I - Economic Blindness.
  • C: < 3/60 to 1/60 corresponds to III - Social Blindness.
  • D: < 1/60 to perception of light corresponds to II - Manifest Blindness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO and NPCB Definitions of Blindness

choices.text: Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis
Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch
Simple primary repair
Purse string suture

questions.text: A patient with history of NSAID use, was brought to the emergency with diffuse abdominal pain and abdominal wall rigidity. Exploratory laparotomy was done and following was found. What would you do in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and apply the Omental patch

 

  • Cleaning the edges of the ulcer and applying an Omental patch (Graham patch) is the most appropriate management for a perforated duodenal ulcer, as depicted in the image.
  •  This technique involves debriding the edges of the ulcer to remove necrotic tissue, followed by patching the perforation with a piece of the omentum, which is sutured in place.
  •  The omental patch helps seal the perforation and promotes healing, reducing the risk of further leakage of gastric contents into the abdominal cavity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Resection of the diseased segment and end-to-end anastomosis: This approach is generally used for malignant or severely diseased segments of the gastrointestinal tract, such as in cases of cancer or significant bowel ischemia. It is not typically necessary for managing a simple perforated duodenal ulcer, especially when the perforation can be adequately treated with an omental patch.

 

Option C. Simple primary repair: While simple primary repair involves suturing the perforation closed, this technique alone may not be sufficient for a perforated duodenal ulcer. Without the addition of an omental patch, there is a higher risk of leakage and recurrence, which is why the omental patch is favored in this situation.

 

Option D. Purse string suture: Purse string sutures are used to close small circular defects, such as in certain hernia repairs or the closure of a trocar site in laparoscopic surgery. It is not the preferred technique for repairing a perforated duodenal ulcer, where an omental patch provides more secure closure and better healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The management of a perforated duodenal ulcer typically involves debriding the ulcer edges and applying an omental patch to promote healing and reduce the risk of recurrence.

questions.text: During a discussion on viral hemorrhagic fevers at a medical conference, a speaker mentions a type of Ebola virus that is non-fatal in human beings. Which strain of the Ebola virus is known to be non-fatal to humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reston

 

  • The Reston ebolavirus, discovered in Reston, Virginia, among primates imported from the Philippines, is known to be non-fatal in humans.
  • While it can cause disease in non-human primates and pigs, there have been no reported cases of this strain causing illness or death in humans.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Zaire: The most deadly strain of Ebola, responsible for the largest outbreaks and highest mortality rates.

 

Option C. Côte d’Ivoire:  Also known as Tai ebolavirus, has caused disease in humans but is less virulent compared to the Zaire strain.

 

Option D. Bundibugyo:  Another virulent strain that has caused outbreaks with significant fatalities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Reston strain of Ebola virus is unique among Ebola viruses as it does not cause disease in humans, highlighting the importance of strain-specific characteristics in the epidemiology and management of Ebola outbreaks.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with complaints of altered taste sensation and discomfort on the sides of her tongue. She has a history of frequent acid reflux, which she believes might be contributing to her symptoms. A biopsy is taken from the affected area, and the histological section is shown below. Based on the image, which type of papilla is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fungiform

 

  • The histological section shows a papilla with a rounded, mushroom-like shape, which is characteristic of fungiform papillae.
  • Fungiform papillae are distributed mainly on the tip and sides of the tongue and contain taste buds, making them involved in taste sensation.
  • They are typically smaller than circumvallate papillae and do not have the trench-like structure seen with circumvallate papillae.
  • The patient's symptoms of altered taste sensation are consistent with issues involving these taste bud-containing papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foliate: Foliate papillae are found on the lateral aspects of the posterior tongue and have multiple vertical folds, which are not present in the image.

 

Option B. Filiform: Filiform papillae are slender, thread-like, and do not contain taste buds. They are more involved in the mechanical aspect of food manipulation and do not match the structure seen in the image.

 

Option C. Circumvallate: Circumvallate papillae are large, dome-shaped structures found at the back of the tongue in a V-shaped row. They are surrounded by a trench, which is not observed in the image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fungiform papillae are mushroom-shaped papillae found primarily on the tip and sides of the tongue.
  • They contain taste buds and are involved in the sensation of taste, particularly sweet and salty flavors.
  • The histological appearance of these papillae, with their rounded shape, distinguishes them from other types of papillae.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with difficulty when reading or descending stairs due to double vision. On examination, it is noted that his symptoms worsen when attempting to look downward and inward. Imaging reveals a problem with one of the extraocular muscles responsible for these movements. Based on the image provided, where is the nucleus of the nerve that innervates this muscle (green marked) located?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inferior colliculus of midbrain

 

  • The superior oblique muscle, which is marked green in the image, is innervated by the trochlear nerve (cranial nerve IV).
  • The nucleus of the trochlear nerve is located at the level of the inferior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • This is the only cranial nerve that emerges dorsally from the brainstem and decussates before innervating the contralateral superior oblique muscle.
  • Damage to this nerve or its nucleus can lead to difficulty in downward gaze and result in diplopia, especially when reading or descending stairs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior colliculus of midbrain: This is associated with the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III), which innervates most of the other extraocular muscles but not the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option B. Facial colliculus of pons: This structure is associated with the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) and the abducens nerve (cranial nerve VI), neither of which innervate the superior oblique muscle.

 

Option D. Inferior olivary nucleus of medulla: This is involved in the coordination of motor activities and does not relate to the innervation of the extraocular muscles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trochlear nerve, which innervates the superior oblique muscle, has its nucleus at the level of the inferior colliculus of the midbrain.
  • Damage to this nerve can impair the ability to move the eye downward and inward, leading to diplopia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with hirsutism, acne, and irregular menstrual cycles. Laboratory testing reveals elevated levels of androgens. The endocrinologist is trying to determine the source of excess androgen production. Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by the adrenal glands and not by the ovaries?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DHEA-S

 

  • Dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEA-S) is a hormone that is exclusively produced by the adrenal glands.
  • It is a sulfated form of DHEA, which increases its solubility and half-life in the circulation.
  • DHEA-S is often used as a marker of adrenal androgen production in conditions like adrenal hyperplasia or adrenal tumors, where androgen excess is suspected.
  • Unlike DHEA, which is produced by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries, DHEA-S is specific to the adrenal cortex and is not produced by the ovaries.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: Progesterone is produced by both the ovaries and the adrenal glands. It plays a significant role in the menstrual cycle and pregnancy, and thus cannot be used to distinguish adrenal from ovarian hormone production.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Estrogen is primarily produced by the ovaries, but small amounts can also be synthesized by the adrenal glands, especially through the aromatization of adrenal androgens. Therefore, estrogen is not exclusively adrenal in origin.

 

Option D. DHEA: Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) is produced by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries. It is a precursor to androgens and estrogens, making it non-specific for adrenal production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DHEA-S is a hormone exclusively secreted by the adrenal glands and not by the ovaries, making it a specific marker for evaluating adrenal androgen production.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, pallor, and glossitis. His laboratory findings reveal a macrocytic anemia. A FIGLU (formiminoglutamate) excretion test is performed, and it is positive. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B9 deficiency

 

  • The patient’s symptoms and macrocytic anemia point to a deficiency affecting DNA synthesis.
  • A positive FIGLU (formiminoglutamate) excretion test specifically points to a deficiency in folic acid (Vitamin B9).
  • FIGLU is an intermediate in the catabolism of histidine, and its conversion to glutamate requires the enzyme formiminotransferase, which uses tetrahydrofolate (a derivative of folic acid) as a cofactor.
  • When folic acid is deficient, FIGLU cannot be efficiently converted to glutamate, leading to its accumulation and subsequent excretion in the urine.
  • Thus, a positive FIGLU test is a direct indicator of Vitamin B9 deficiency, making this the most likely cause of the patient's macrocytic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Also causes macrocytic anemia but does not lead to a positive FIGLU test. It’s more associated with neurological symptoms.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Causes microcytic, not macrocytic anemia, and is unrelated to FIGLU metabolism.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6 deficiency: Involves amino acid metabolism, not FIGLU conversion, and does not cause macrocytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive FIGLU excretion test specifically indicates folic acid (Vitamin B9) deficiency.

questions.text: A patient on tricyclic antidepressants presents with blurred vision and dry mouth. These side effects are most likely due to the blockade of which receptors?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) M3 muscarinic receptors

 

  • Tricyclic antidepressants can cause anticholinergic side effects, such as blurred vision and dry mouth, by blocking M3 muscarinic receptors, which are responsible for parasympathetic functions like salivation and accommodation in the eyes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. GABA-A receptors: These are involved in inhibitory neurotransmission, not in the anticholinergic effects seen with tricyclic antidepressants.

 

Option C. H1 histamine receptors: Blockade of H1 receptors can cause sedation and weight gain, but not the anticholinergic effects like dry mouth and blurred vision.

 

Option D. 5HT2 receptors: These receptors are involved in various neurotransmitter pathways, but their blockade does not cause anticholinergic effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anticholinergic side effects of tricyclic antidepressants, such as dry mouth and blurred vision, result from the blockade of M3 muscarinic receptors.

questions.text: Which of the following parasites is commonly known as the rat lungworm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Angiostrongylus cantonensis

 

  • Angiostrongylus cantonensis, also known as rat lungworm.
  •  This parasite is known for its role in causing eosinophilic meningitis, particularly in Southeast Asia and the Pacific Basin.
  • The infection is typically acquired through ingestion of raw or undercooked snails, slugs or produce contaminated with the larvae.

 

 

Other Options:


Option B. Ascaris suum: While also a nematode, Ascaris suum generally causes pulmonary and gastrointestinal symptoms due to its life cycle in the human host, affecting the lungs and intestines.

 

Option C. Ancylostoma Caninum: This hookworm species is primarily a parasite of dogs and causes cutaneous larva migrans in humans when the larvae penetrate the skin. It is not associated with eosinophilic meningitis or the neurological symptoms typically seen with Angiostrongylus cantonensis.

 

Option D. Toxocara Canis: This is another roundworm from dogs, causing toxocariasis which can lead to visceral larva migrans, primarily affecting the liver, lungs and eyes, but not typically the CNS as seen with rat lungworm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Angiostrongylus cantonensis is known as rat lung worm, rarely infects man; causes eosinophilic meningitis.

choices.text: Ventral divisions of upper, middle, and lower trunks
Dorsal divisions of upper, middle, and lower trunks
Ventral division of upper trunk
Dorsal division of upper trunk

questions.text: A 34-year-old construction worker presents with difficulty extending his wrist and fingers after sustaining an injury to his right shoulder in a fall. Physical examination reveals wrist drop and weakened triceps reflex. The neurologist suspects a brachial plexus injury affecting the posterior cord. Which of the following describes the formation of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dorsal divisions of upper, middle, and lower trunks

 

  • The posterior cord of the brachial plexus is formed by the dorsal (or posterior) divisions of the upper, middle, and lower trunks.
  • This cord gives rise to several important nerves, including the axillary nerve and the radial nerve, which are responsible for innervating the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm.
  • Injury to the posterior cord can result in symptoms such as wrist drop, as seen in this patient, due to impaired function of the radial nerve.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventral divisions of upper, middle, and lower trunks: The ventral divisions of these trunks contribute to the formation of the medial and lateral cords, not the posterior cord.

 

Option C. Ventral division of upper trunk: This forms part of the lateral cord, not the posterior cord.

 

Option D. Dorsal division of upper trunk: This alone would not form the posterior cord; the posterior cord is formed by the dorsal divisions of all three trunks (upper, middle, and lower).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The posterior cord of the brachial plexus is formed by the dorsal divisions of the upper, middle, and lower trunks and is responsible for giving rise to nerves that control the extensor muscles of the arm and forearm.
  • Injury to this cord can result in significant motor deficits, such as wrist drop.

questions.text: A researcher studying fatty acid metabolism investigates the role of delta-9 desaturase in modifying saturated fatty acids. The enzyme acts on stearic acid by introducing a double bond at the 9th carbon. Which of the following fatty acids is the direct product of this enzymatic reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oleic acid

 

  • Delta-9 desaturase is an enzyme responsible for introducing a double bond at the 9th carbon position of saturated fatty acids, specifically converting stearic acid, a saturated fatty acid with 18 carbon atoms and no double bonds, into oleic acid.
  • Oleic acid is a monounsaturated fatty acid, meaning it has a single double bond, specifically at the 9th carbon position.
  • This conversion is crucial in the regulation of membrane fluidity and the production of signaling molecules.
  • The role of delta-9 desaturase is vital in lipid metabolism because it transforms saturated fatty acids, which are more rigid and contribute to less fluid cell membranes, into monounsaturated fatty acids like oleic acid, which enhance membrane fluidity and function.
  • This process also plays a role in energy storage and metabolic regulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmitic acid: Palmitic acid is a saturated fatty acid with 16 carbons and no double bonds. It is not a product of delta-9 desaturase activity.

 

Option B. Linoleic acid: Linoleic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid with 18 carbons and two double bonds at the 9th and 12th positions. It is not produced by delta-9 desaturase.

 

Option D. Arachidonic acid: Arachidonic acid is a polyunsaturated fatty acid with 20 carbons and four double bonds. It is not a direct product of delta-9 desaturase acting on stearic acid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Delta-9 desaturase converts stearic acid into oleic acid by introducing a double bond at the 9th carbon, producing a monounsaturated fatty acid.

questions.text: At what age after birth will child with bilious vomiting with double bubble on x-ray present?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Few days after birth

 

  • Few days after birth is the correct timeframe for the presentation of a neonate with bilious vomiting and a "double bubble" sign on x-ray.
  • This radiographic finding is highly suggestive of duodenal atresia, a congenital condition where the duodenum is blocked or absent, preventing the passage of stomach contents into the small intestine.
  • Duodenal atresia is usually diagnosed shortly after birth when the newborn begins feeding and symptoms such as bilious vomiting become apparent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Few weeks after birth: Although gastrointestinal conditions may present weeks after birth, duodenal atresia typically manifests within the first few days of life as the neonate begins to feed. Delayed presentation beyond a few days is uncommon for this condition.

 

Option C. Weaning period: The weaning period, typically occurring around 6 months to 1 year of age, is when a child transitions from breast milk or formula to solid foods. Gastrointestinal conditions associated with this period include food intolerances or gastrointestinal infections, not congenital conditions like duodenal atresia.

 

Option D. 1-2 years: By 1-2 years of age, children typically present with gastrointestinal issues related to diet or infection rather than congenital abnormalities such as duodenal atresia, which would have been diagnosed and treated shortly after birth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "double bubble" sign on x-ray in a neonate with bilious vomiting typically indicates duodenal atresia, which usually presents within the first few days after birth.

choices.text: Mallory Weiss tear

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, following binge drinking and heavy meals, was brought to the emergency with sudden onset of severe left sided chest pain radiating to the left shoulder and subcutaneous emphysema. Pneumomediastinum was present. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Esophageal perforation

 

  • Esophageal perforation is the most likely diagnosis in this case. The combination of severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema (air under the skin), and the presence of pneumomediastinum (air in the mediastinum) strongly suggests esophageal perforation.
  •  This condition often occurs after episodes of severe vomiting or retching, which can cause a tear or rupture in the esophagus. The esophagus's location and the nature of its contents make perforation a medical emergency requiring prompt diagnosis and treatment.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Mallory-Weiss tear: Mallory-Weiss tears are mucosal lacerations at the gastroesophageal junction, typically caused by severe vomiting or retching. However, they generally present with hematemesis (vomiting blood) rather than the severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum seen in this patient. Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum are not associated with a Mallory-Weiss tear.

 

Option C. Hollow viscus perforation: Hollow viscus perforation, such as a perforated peptic ulcer, typically presents with acute abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. While this is a surgical emergency, it would not usually cause subcutaneous emphysema or pneumomediastinum unless there was extension of the perforation into the thoracic cavity, which is less common.

 

Option D. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis is associated with epigastric pain radiating to the back and elevated pancreatic enzymes. While it can cause severe abdominal pain and systemic symptoms, it does not typically cause subcutaneous emphysema or pneumomediastinum. Therefore, it is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Esophageal perforation should be suspected in patients with severe chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum following episodes of vomiting or heavy meals.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of painful, progressively enlarging breasts. He has no history of medications or illicit drug use, and puberty was normal. Physical examination reveals symmetric tender gynecomastia with no other signs of feminization, and normal testicular volume. His serum β-human chorionic gonadotropin level is normal, luteinizing hormone level is normal, and total morning testosterone level is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Estradiol level measurement

 

  • In the evaluation of gynecomastia, particularly when the cause is not clear from the history and physical examination, measuring the estradiol level is essential.
  • Gynecomastia results from an imbalance in the testosterone-to-estrogen ratio, which can occur due to elevated estradiol levels or low testosterone levels.
  • Given this patient's normal testosterone levels, the next step is to check for an elevated estradiol level, which could suggest conditions such as testicular or adrenal tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adrenal CT: This is not indicated unless an elevated estradiol level suggests the presence of an adrenal tumor.

 

Option C. Mammography: Typically used for unilateral, nontender, or fixed breast masses suspicious for breast cancer, but not indicated in this case of bilateral gynecomastia.

 

Option D. Tamoxifen: This is a treatment option for gynecomastia but is not appropriate until the underlying cause is fully evaluated, particularly when an elevated estradiol level may indicate a neoplasm.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The evaluation of gynecomastia should include measurement of estradiol, total testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and β-human chorionic gonadotropin levels to determine the underlying cause, especially when the initial workup does not reveal a clear etiology.

questions.text: A microbiologist is setting up a culture to isolate Campylobacter jejuni from a stool sample of a patient with symptoms of gastroenteritis. Which of the following conditions is true regarding the optimal growth environment for Campylobacter jejuni?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 42°C microaerophilic

 

  • Campylobacter jejuni optimally grows at 42°C under microaerophilic conditions, which involve low oxygen and high carbon dioxide levels, but not as high as 10%.
  •  This temperature, slightly higher than human body temperature, is advantageous for isolating Campylobacter from samples contaminated with other gut flora.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Campylobacter jejuni is microaerophilic, grows best at 42°C
