questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents with primary amenorrhea. On examination, her breasts are poorly developed, and a vagina is present. Ultrasound reveals a normal uterus, but gonads are not detected. Further evaluation shows a 46XY karyotype. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Swyer syndrome

 

  • The most likely diagnosis for a patient presenting with primary amenorrhea, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics (such as breast development), a normal uterus, and a 46XY karyotype is Swyer syndrome.
  •  Swyer syndrome, also known as 46XY gonadal dysgenesis, is a condition where individuals have a typical female phenotype but possess a 46XY karyotype.
  • These individuals are genetically male but have nonfunctional streak gonads, which leads to a lack of sex hormone production, resulting in the absence of secondary sexual development and primary amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Turner syndrome: Turner syndrome is typically associated with a 45X karyotype and presents with primary amenorrhea, short stature, and underdeveloped sexual characteristics. The presence of a 46XY karyotype excludes Turner syndrome.

 

Option B. True hermaphrodite: True hermaphroditism, or ovotesticular disorder, is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue. It is associated with ambiguous genitalia or atypical development of the reproductive organs, which does not fit the description of a normal uterus and vagina with a 46XY karyotype.

 

Option D. Androgen insensitivity syndrome: Androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) also involves a 46XY karyotype but is typically characterized by a female external phenotype with a blind-ending vagina, absent uterus, and testes located in the abdomen or inguinal canal. The presence of a normal uterus and the absence of detectable gonads on ultrasound make AIS less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Swyer syndrome (46XY gonadal dysgenesis) is characterized by a 46XY karyotype, primary amenorrhea, poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, and the presence of a normal uterus with undetectable gonads.
  •  This condition results from nonfunctional streak gonads that fail to produce sex hormones, leading to the observed clinical features.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling. She has a history of two second-trimester abortions. What is the most appropriate next investigation to perform?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hysterosalpingography

  

  • In a patient with a history of recurrent second-trimester abortions, the most likely underlying cause could be structural abnormalities of the uterus, such as uterine septum, bicornuate uterus, or cervical incompetence.
  • Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is the appropriate next step in the investigation, as it allows for detailed visualization of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.
  • HSG can help identify any structural abnormalities that could be contributing to the recurrent pregnancy losses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endometrial Biopsy: An endometrial biopsy is typically used to evaluate the endometrial lining for abnormalities, such as chronic endometritis, but it is not the first-line investigation for recurrent second-trimester abortions.

 

Option B. TORCH screen: The TORCH screen tests for infections that can lead to congenital anomalies or miscarriages, such as toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex virus, and others. However, these infections are more commonly associated with first-trimester losses or congenital abnormalities, not recurrent second-trimester losses.

 

Option C. Karyotyping of the parents: Karyotyping of the parents is used to detect genetic abnormalities that could lead to recurrent miscarriages, but it is more relevant in cases of recurrent first-trimester losses rather than second-trimester losses. Structural uterine abnormalities are a more likely cause of second-trimester losses, making HSG the more appropriate next step.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a woman with a history of recurrent second-trimester abortions, hysterosalpingography (HSG) is the investigation of choice to evaluate for possible structural uterine abnormalities that could be contributing to pregnancy loss.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man has a 9-month history of nausea, vomiting, early satiety, and postprandial bloating. His only other medical problem is chronic shoulder pain, for which he takes daily ibuprofen. Vital signs are normal. The abdomen is distended, with epigastric tenderness without guarding or rigidity. A succussion splash is heard. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Upper endoscopy

 

  • The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of delayed gastric emptying, such as nausea, vomiting, early satiety, and postprandial bloating.
  • The succussion splash indicates retained gastric contents.
  • The most appropriate initial management is an upper endoscopy to exclude gastric outlet obstruction, especially considering his chronic use of ibuprofen, which could have led to peptic ulceration and obstruction.
  • Only after ruling out mechanical obstruction should further testing for gastroparesis, such as gastric scintigraphy, be considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gastric scintigraphy: Appropriate only after ruling out mechanical obstruction with an upper endoscopy.

 

Option B. Lansoprazole: May be used if a pyloric ulcer is diagnosed but is premature without a confirmed diagnosis.

 

Option C. Metoclopramide: A prokinetic agent used to treat gastroparesis but should not be administered until mechanical obstruction is excluded.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with symptoms suggestive of delayed gastric emptying, the initial diagnostic test should be upper endoscopy to exclude gastric outlet obstruction before considering other diagnostic tests or treatments.

questions.text: A forensic expert receives a conceptus material brought in by the police for examination. The conceptus measures 4 cm in length and weighs 10 grams. The expert is tasked with estimating its gestational age. Based on the given measurements, what is the most probable age of the conceptus?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 8 weeks

 

  • A conceptus measuring 4 cm in length and weighing 10 grams is most likely around 6 weeks of gestation.
  • At this stage, the embryo has undergone significant development, including the formation of basic structures and organ systems.
  • End of second month: Length four cm; weight ten gm. The hands and feet are webbed. The placenta begins to form. The anus is seen as a dark spot. First ossification centre in a foetus appears in clavicle (4 to 5 weeks), followed by maxilla (6 weeks). Ossification centres are present in the upper segments of sacrum and mandible.

 

Note:

 

Rule of Hasse-

 

It is a rough method of calculating the age of fetus.

 

  • The length of fetus is measured from crown to heel in centimetres.
  • During first 5 months of pregnancy—square root of length gives approximate age of fetus in months.
  • During the last 5 months—length in centimetres divided by 5 gives age in months.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: External fixation followed by ORIF with soft tissue management
Immediate ORIF with supplemental external fixation
Conservative management with a cast and elevation
Arthroscopic debridement and delayed fixation

questions.text: Image showing a Schatzker Type VI tibial plateau fracture with extensive soft tissue swelling and joint depression. What is the optimal management approach?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) External fixation followed by ORIF with soft tissue management

 

  • Schatzker Type VI Tibial Plateau Fracture: This type of fracture is severe, involving significant comminution of the tibial plateau and associated with substantial soft tissue injury. The fracture often shows joint depression and disruption of the articular surface.
  • External Fixation: This is a temporary measure to stabilize the fracture and control swelling. It involves applying an external frame to stabilize the limb and provide temporary fixation. It is particularly useful in managing fractures with extensive soft tissue damage, as it avoids further compromising the soft tissue by avoiding extensive surgical dissection.
  • ORIF (Open Reduction and Internal Fixation): After initial stabilization with external fixation, ORIF is performed to definitively fix the fracture. This involves open surgery to realign and stabilize the fracture using internal hardware such as plates and screws.
  • Soft Tissue Management: Proper management of the soft tissue is crucial to prevent complications such as infection and ensure good healing. This involves careful handling of the soft tissues during surgery and may include wound care and monitoring for signs of infection or compartment syndrome.
  • Advantages: This approach allows for initial stabilization of the fracture and management of the soft tissue injury before undertaking definitive surgical fixation. It reduces the risk of further compromising soft tissue, improves fracture alignment, and enhances overall outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immediate ORIF with Supplemental External Fixation:

 

  • Immediate ORIF: Performing ORIF right away involves directly addressing the fracture by realigning and stabilizing it using internal hardware. However, in the context of severe soft tissue injury and swelling, immediate ORIF can lead to complications such as wound healing problems or exacerbation of soft tissue injury.
  • Supplemental External Fixation: Using an external fixator in conjunction with ORIF can help stabilize the fracture and manage soft tissue swelling. However, this approach might not be optimal as the immediate ORIF can increase the risk of complications in the setting of extensive soft tissue damage.
  • Consideration: While combining external fixation with ORIF is sometimes used, in cases with severe soft tissue damage like a Schatzker Type VI fracture, external fixation is typically employed first to manage the swelling and soft tissue before proceeding with definitive fixation.

 

Option C. Conservative Management with a Cast and Elevation:

 

  • Conservative Management: This approach involves using a cast to immobilize the fracture and elevation to reduce swelling. This is generally reserved for less severe fractures where the fracture is stable and there is minimal soft tissue damage.
  • Limitations: Schatzker Type VI fractures are complex with extensive joint and soft tissue involvement. Conservative management is insufficient for such severe fractures as it does not address the need for accurate realignment of the articular surface or adequate fixation of the comminuted fracture.
  • Consideration: Given the complexity of Schatzker Type VI fractures, conservative management with a cast and elevation alone is not appropriate. Definitive surgical intervention is required for optimal outcomes.

 

Option D. Arthroscopic Debridement and Delayed Fixation:

 

  • Arthroscopic Debridement: This involves using an arthroscope to clean out the joint and remove debris or damaged tissue. While useful for joint cleaning, it does not address the underlying fracture.
  • Delayed Fixation: This refers to postponing definitive fracture fixation until after the initial inflammation and swelling have subsided. While this might be done in some cases, it is typically not the best approach for severe fractures requiring immediate stabilization.
  • Consideration: In cases of Schatzker Type VI fractures, immediate and appropriate fixation is crucial to prevent joint instability and long-term complications. Delayed fixation with only arthroscopic debridement does not address the need for proper fracture alignment and stabilization.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • External Fixation Followed by ORIF with Soft Tissue Management is the optimal approach for managing a Schatzker Type VI tibial plateau fracture.
  • This strategy addresses the severe nature of the fracture and extensive soft tissue damage by initially stabilizing the limb with an external fixator to manage swelling and soft tissue injury.

choices.text: Tibio Talar part of Deltoid Ligament

questions.text: A 19-year-old male basketball player presents to the emergency department after landing awkwardly on an opponent's foot during a game. He reports that his right ankle "rolled" inward, followed by immediate severe pain and swelling. He is unable to bear weight on the injured foot. X-rays show no fractures. This is his first ankle injury. Based on the mechanism of injury and clinical presentation, which of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior Talo-Fibular Ligament

 

  • The most common type of ankle sprain occurs when the ankle is forcefully inverted, as described in this patient.
  • The anterior talo-fibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured ligament in such cases, as it is the weakest of the lateral ankle ligaments and is most vulnerable during an inversion injury.
  • The mechanism described, where the ankle "rolled" outward (inversion), strongly suggests injury to the ATFL, particularly given the rapid onset of pain and swelling without evidence of fracture on X-ray.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibio-Calcaneal part of Deltoid Ligament: The deltoid ligament is a strong medial ligament, and injuries to this structure are less common in inversion sprains. It is more likely to be injured in eversion injuries, where the ankle rolls inward.

 

Option B. Capsular Ligament: The capsular ligament is part of the joint capsule, and while it can be involved in ankle injuries, it is not the primary structure injured in typical inversion sprains.

 

Option C. Tibio Talar part of Deltoid Ligament: This is another component of the deltoid ligament complex on the medial side of the ankle and is not typically injured in inversion sprains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anterior talo-fibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured ligament in inversion ankle sprains, particularly in athletes.
  • This ligament is located on the lateral side of the ankle and is the first to be stressed during inversion injuries.

choices.text: Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and glucocorticoids
Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine
Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and medical marijuana

questions.text: A 28-year-old man is evaluated for a testicular mass recently discovered by his wife. He also notes the recent onset of cough and lumbar back pain. An inguinal orchidectomy reveals a testicular seminoma, and staging reveals distant metastases. He will be treated with highly-emetogenic cisplatin-based combination chemotherapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate measure to prevent this patient's nausea and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine

 

  • For patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy, such as cisplatin-based regimens, the combination of a serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine is recommended to prevent both acute and delayed nausea and vomiting.
  • This combination has been shown to significantly decrease breakthrough symptoms and is supported by guidelines from the American Society of Clinical Oncology (ASCO).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alprazolam and olanzapine: Alprazolam is primarily used for managing anxiety and anticipatory nausea, not for preventing acute or delayed chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting.

 

Option B. Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and glucocorticoids: This combination is effective but may be insufficient for highly emetogenic chemotherapy, especially for preventing delayed nausea and vomiting.

 

Option D. Serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, and medical marijuana: The evidence for using medical marijuana as an antiemetic in chemotherapy is insufficient, and it is not recommended over the tested and approved medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To prevent nausea and vomiting in patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy, a combination of a serotonin antagonist, neurokinin-1 receptor antagonists, glucocorticoids, and olanzapine is recommended.
  • This regimen addresses both acute and delayed symptoms, significantly reducing the risk of breakthrough nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman delivers a healthy baby, and the placenta is expelled intact. However, 30 minutes later, she begins to experience significant vaginal bleeding. On examination, she is hypotensive, and a boggy mass is palpated in the lower abdomen. An ultrasound reveals retained placental tissue. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Placenta succenturiata

  

  • Placenta succenturiata refers to a condition where there is an accessory lobe of placental tissue separate from the main body of the placenta.
  • During delivery, the main placenta may be expelled intact, but the accessory lobe might be retained in the uterus, leading to postpartum hemorrhage.
  • The retained tissue can be detected by ultrasound, as described in the scenario, and requires prompt management to prevent severe bleeding and complications.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Circummarginate placenta: This condition involves a placental margin that is more flattened than normal, but it is not typically associated with retained placental tissue or significant postpartum hemorrhage.

 

 

Option C. Placenta membranacea: Placenta membranacea is a rare condition where the placenta develops as a thin membrane covering the entire or a large part of the uterine surface. This condition does not typically cause retention of placental tissue post-delivery as described in this case.

 

 

Option D. Circumvallate placenta: Circumvallate placenta is characterized by a thickened, raised ring of membranes on the fetal side of the placenta. It can be associated with various complications during pregnancy, but it does not typically cause postpartum hemorrhage due to retained placental tissue.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta succenturiata, characterized by an accessory lobe of placental tissue, can result in retained placental tissue after delivery, leading to postpartum hemorrhage.
  • This condition should be suspected when there is postpartum bleeding despite the expulsion of an intact placenta.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic with abnormal eye movements, as depicted in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internuclear ophthalmoplegia

 

  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) is characterized by a deficit in the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF), which inhibits the adduction of the ipsilateral eye during horizontal gaze, while the contralateral eye abducts and often exhibits nystagmus.
  • The diagram illustrates nystagmus, which is a common finding in INO, especially observed in the abducting eye during lateral gaze.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horizontal gaze palsy: This involves a total inability to move the eyes horizontally and would not typically present solely with nystagmus.

 

Option C. Internal ophthalmoplegia: Affects the pupillary reflexes and accommodation, not horizontal eye movement or nystagmus.

 

Option D. Duane's retraction syndrome: Characterized by retraction of the eyeball into the orbit during attempted adduction, limited abduction, or adduction, and not primarily by nystagmus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Internuclear ophthalmoplegia should be considered in patients presenting with dissociated horizontal eye movements, where nystagmus in the abducting eye is accompanied by impaired adduction of the ipsilateral eye.
  • This condition is often seen in young adults with multiple sclerosis or older adults with stroke.

questions.text: A longitudinal study observes that individuals who significantly reduce their consumption of processed meats have a lower incidence of colorectal cancer compared to those who maintain a high consumption level. This finding supports which of the following criteria of causality in linking dietary habits to disease outcomes?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reversibility or reversible association

 

  • The observation that reducing processed meat consumption leads to a lower incidence of colorectal cancer suggests that the risk can be reduced by changing the exposure.
  • This illustrates the concept of reversibility, where modifying or removing the exposure decreases the risk of the disease, supporting the causal relationship.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temporal relationship: Refers to the cause preceding the effect, important for causality but not the focus here.

 

Option B. Consistency: Refers to the observation of the association across various studies, but not the main point in this scenario.

 

Option C. Strength of association: Refers to the magnitude of the relationship between processed meat consumption and cancer, but the key point here is the reversibility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reversibility is a critical criterion in establishing causality, demonstrated when reducing or eliminating an exposure (like processed meat consumption) leads to a decrease in the associated risk of a disease (such as colorectal cancer).

questions.text: During a family therapy session, a psychologist observes a family where all members, regardless of age or role, actively participate in discussions about family affairs and decision-making. The psychologist is evaluating the family structure to optimize therapeutic approaches. This type of family interaction, characterized by collective participation in decision-making, is best described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Communal family

 

  • A communal family is characterized by collective participation in decision-making and management of family affairs by all its members. This structure emphasizes shared responsibilities and cooperative living.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elementary family: Refers to a basic family unit, typically consisting of parents and their children, without the extended involvement of other family members.

 

Option B. New family: Generally, refers to modern or non-traditional family structures, such as single-parent families or families with non-binary roles, but does not specifically imply shared management.

 

Option C. 3-Generation family: A family that includes three generations living together (e.g., grandparents, parents, and children), but the term does not necessarily imply collective management by all members.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A communal family is one where all members actively participate in the management and decision-making processes, reflecting a collective approach to family responsibilities.
  • This structure differs from more traditional or hierarchical family models.

choices.text: Parathyroid multiglandular hyperplasia
Pancreatic endocrine tumour

questions.text: Which of the following manifestations is not typically associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

 

MEN 1 syndrome:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pheochromocytoma is usually associated with MEN 2 syndrome.

choices.text: Sensitivity is less than specificity
Sensitivity is the same as specificity
Positive predictive value (PPV) is more than negative predictive value (NPV)
Positive predictive value (PPV) is the same as negative predictive value (NPV)

questions.text: A recent study evaluating a new blood test for diagnosing chronic kidney disease (CKD) yielded the following results in a 2x2 table. Based on these results, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive predictive value (PPV) is the same as negative predictive value (NPV)

 

  1. Sensitivity = True Positives / (True Positives + False Negatives)
    = 200 / (200 + 30) ≈ 0.87 (or 87%)
  2. Specificity = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Positives)
    = 120 / (120 + 50) ≈ 0.71 (or 71%)
  3. Positive Predictive Value (PPV) = True Positives / (True Positives + False Positives)
    = 200 / (200 + 50) = 200 / 250 = 0.80 (or 80%)
  4. Negative Predictive Value (NPV) = True Negatives / (True Negatives + False Negatives)
    = 120 / (120 + 30) = 120 / 150 = 0.80 (or 80%)

 

(d) Positive predictive value (PPV) is the same as negative predictive value (NPV): Both PPV and NPV are 80% in this scenario, making this the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensitivity is less than specificity: Incorrect. Sensitivity (87%) is higher than specificity (71%).

 

Option B. Sensitivity is the same as specificity: Incorrect. Sensitivity and specificity are not equal.

 

Option C. Positive predictive value (PPV) is more than negative predictive value (NPV): Incorrect. PPV and NPV are the same in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In this scenario,

 

  • Sensitivity > PPV OR NPV > Specificity
  • PPV = NPV

questions.text: Identify the instrument given in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bonney’s myomectomy clamp

 

  • The instrument shown in the image is a Bonney’s myomectomy clamp.
  • This specialized clamp is commonly used in myomectomy procedures to grasp and secure the uterine tissue while fibroids are being excised.
  • The design of the clamp, with its robust and slightly curved jaw, allows it to firmly hold the tissue, minimizing bleeding and providing the surgeon with better control during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine manipulator: A uterine manipulator is used during gynecological surgeries to move and position the uterus. It has a different structure and is not designed to clamp tissue.

 

Option B. Green Armitage: The Green Armitage forceps are used for holding and clamping blood vessels or tissues, but they have a different design compared to Bonney’s myomectomy clamp. They are typically straight with long, flat jaws.

 

Option C. Shirodkar’s clamp: Shirodkar’s clamp is used in the Shirodkar procedure for cervical cerclage, where it helps in placing the stitch around the cervix. Its structure is different, and it is not used for myomectomy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bonney’s myomectomy clamp is a surgical instrument specifically designed for securing uterine tissue during the excision of fibroids in a myomectomy. Its robust design helps minimize bleeding and provides better control during the procedure.

questions.text: A clinician evaluates a patient with painful vesicular lesions on the lips. To aid in diagnosis, a Tzanck smear was made from the scrapping of the lesion. Identify the pathogen:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herpes simplex

 

  • Herpes simplex virus is typically identified by the presence of multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear, indicative of active viral replication.
  • This finding is characteristic of herpes simplex infections, which often present as painful vesicular lesions on the lips, commonly referred to as cold sores or fever blisters.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Varicella zoster: While it can produce similar cytopathic effects, it more commonly presents as either chickenpox or shingles, not typically isolated to lip ulcers.

 

Option C. Parvovirus: Known for causing erythema infectiosum in children, it does not cause vesicular lesions on the lips.

 

Option D. HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Leads to warts, not vesicular lesions, and does not show multinucleated giant cells on Tzanck smears.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognizing the clinical presentation of herpes simplex and its cytopathic effect on Tzanck smears can facilitate prompt and accurate diagnosis, allowing for effective management of the infection.

choices.text: Annual new case detection rate per 100,000 population
Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability

questions.text: A regional health authority is conducting a comprehensive review of current leprosy control program. The review aims to optimize resource allocation by evaluating the effectiveness of different performance indicators. Which of the following performance indicators is LEAST useful for determining whether the health system is effectively prioritizing the identification of leprosy within the community?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Treatment initiation rate

 

  • The treatment initiation rate reflects how quickly patients begin treatment after being diagnosed, but it does not directly assess the health system's emphasis on identifying new cases of leprosy.
  • The focus of identifying new cases is more directly measured by other indicators, such as the annual new case detection rate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment completion rate: This is an important indicator of how well the health system is managing and curing leprosy, but it also indirectly reflects the system's effectiveness in controlling the disease, which includes identification and treatment.

 

Option B. Annual new case detection rate per 100,000 population: This directly measures the effectiveness of the health system in identifying new cases of leprosy in the community.

 

Option D. Proportion of newly diagnosed patients with grade-2 disability: This indicates how effectively the health system is identifying leprosy cases early enough to prevent severe disability, reflecting the emphasis on early case detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Main/Core Indicators for NLEP: Monitor functioning of control activities:

 

  • No. of new cases detected per 1 Lac population per year
  • New cases with Grade-2 disability 1 Lac population per year
  • Treatment completion/cure rate
  • Prevalence rate

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of headache and dizziness. His blood pressure is measured at 190/100 mm Hg, and his pulse pressure is noted to be 90 mm Hg. Considering the elevated pulse pressure, which of the following physiological changes is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Arterial wall compliance

 

  • Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic blood pressure.
  • It is primarily influenced by the stroke volume and arterial compliance. In older adults, one of the most common reasons for an increased pulse pressure is decreased arterial wall compliance, commonly seen as a result of arterial stiffness.
  • Arterial stiffness reduces the ability of the arteries to expand during systole, leading to higher systolic pressure, while diastolic pressure may not rise as significantly, thereby increasing the pulse pressure.
  • This scenario is commonly observed in elderly patients with conditions such as hypertension or atherosclerosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myocardial contractility: While myocardial contractility affects stroke volume and cardiac output, it does not directly cause the increase in pulse pressure associated with decreased arterial compliance.

 

Option B. Stroke volume: Increased stroke volume can elevate systolic blood pressure, but in this case, the pulse pressure increase is more likely due to decreased arterial compliance rather than an isolated change in stroke volume.

 

Option C. Cardiac output: Cardiac output, which is the product of heart rate and stroke volume, influences overall blood pressure but is not directly responsible for changes in pulse pressure independent of other factors such as arterial compliance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Increased pulse pressure, especially in older adults with hypertension, is most commonly due to decreased arterial wall compliance, leading to greater systolic pressure relative to diastolic pressure.

questions.text: A 28-year-old nurse is assigned to care for a patient diagnosed with a highly infectious bloodborne virus. Which piece of PPE is most effective at protecting her from infected body fluids?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gloves

 

  • Gloves are the most effective method of protecting healthcare workers from infected body fluids.
  • They prevent direct contact with blood, bodily fluids, secretions and excretions, thereby reducing the risk of acquiring infections that can be transmitted in this manner.
  •  Gloves are especially crucial when handling materials or touching surfaces contaminated with infectious agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gown: Gowns protect the skin and clothing from contamination. They are important but do not provide as direct a barrier against infected fluids as gloves, which are in constant contact with infectious materials.
 

Option B. Goggles: Goggles protect the eyes from splashes of infectious fluids. While important for overall protection, they are not used as frequently as gloves in standard patient interactions.
 

Option D. Mask: Masks protect the respiratory tract from airborne infectious agents rather than from contact with body fluids. They are essential in the prevention of inhalation of infectious agents but are not the primary protection against contact transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hand hygiene is the most important as hands will be in contact first.
  • So gloves will be the most effective method among the options given here.

choices.text: Preparing cell lines for viral culture

questions.text: The technique depicted in the image is most commonly used for which of the following purposes?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Synthesis of monoclonal antibodies

 

  • The image depicts the hybridoma technique, where spleen cells from a mouse are fused with myeloma cells to produce hybridoma cells.
  • These hybridoma cells can then be cultured to produce monoclonal antibodies, which are identical and target a specific antigen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preparing cell lines for viral culture: While cell lines can be used for viral cultures, the technique shown is specifically for monoclonal antibody production.

 

Option C. Synthesis of vaccine: Vaccines can involve various processes, but the image represents the production of monoclonal antibodies, not vaccines.

 

Option D. Process of genetic engineering: Genetic engineering involves altering the genetic material of organisms, which is different from the antibody production process shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hybridoma technique is a key method in biotechnology for producing monoclonal antibodies, which are used for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
  • This process involves fusing antibody-producing spleen cells with myeloma cells to create hybridoma cells that can produce large quantities of specific antibodies.

choices.text: Candida albicans
All Candida species

questions.text: A microbiologist is performing a germ tube test to aid in the identification of a yeast isolated from a patient's blood culture. Which of the following fungi is known to produce a positive germ tube test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Candida albicans

 

  • Candida albicans is known for giving a positive germ tube test, which involves the yeast forming filamentous outgrowths called germ tubes when incubated in serum.
  • This test is specific to C. albicans among the Candida species, helping distinguish it from other yeasts which do not form germ tubes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptococcus: This genus, including Cryptococcus neoformans, does not produce germ tubes. It is instead identified by other methods such as India ink staining, which reveals its characteristic capsule.

 

Option B. Aspergillus: Aspergillus species are molds, not yeasts, and do not produce germ tubes. They are identified by their filamentous structure and conidial heads under the microscope.

 

Option D. All Candida species: Not all Candida species give a positive germ tube test. This test is specific to Candida albicans, distinguishing it from non-albicans Candida species like C. glabrata and C. krusei, which are germ tube negative.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The germ tube test is a rapid, specific method for identifying Candida albicans, useful in clinical microbiology to differentiate it from other yeast species that do not produce germ tubes.

choices.text: Inhibition of PD1 receptor on T-cells
Upregulation of expression of PDL1

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with a history of non-small cell lung cancer is undergoing immunotherapy. His oncologist is monitoring for potential immune evasion mechanisms by the tumor cells. Which of the following mechanisms is not involved in immune evasion by tumor cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inhibition of PD1 receptor on T-cells

 

  • Inhibition of the PD1 receptor on T-cells is not a mechanism used by tumor cells to evade the immune system.
  • In fact, this inhibition is a therapeutic strategy used in immunotherapy, specifically with PD1 inhibitors like pembrolizumab or nivolumab, to enhance the immune system's ability to recognize and destroy tumor cells.
  • By blocking the PD1 receptor, these drugs prevent the interaction between PD1 on T-cells and PDL1 on tumor cells, thereby promoting an anti-tumor immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Induction of regulatory T-cells: Tumor cells can evade immune detection by inducing the proliferation of regulatory T-cells (Tregs). These cells suppress the immune response against the tumor, helping it to grow and spread.

 

Option C. Induction of galectin: Galectins are proteins that can be secreted by tumor cells to induce apoptosis in activated T-cells and inhibit their function, thereby aiding in immune evasion.

 

Option D. Upregulation of expression of PDL1: Tumor cells often upregulate the expression of PDL1, a ligand that binds to the PD1 receptor on T-cells, leading to the suppression of T-cell activity and enabling the tumor to evade the immune system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Inhibition of the PD1 receptor on T-cells is a therapeutic strategy used to boost the immune system's response against tumors, not a mechanism of immune evasion by the tumor cells.
  •  Tumors evade the immune system through mechanisms such as the induction of regulatory T-cells, upregulation of PDL1 expression, and induction of galectin.

choices.text: Immediate fasciotomy to relieve compartment syndrome
Start high-dose IV antibiotics and observe
Apply a compression bandage and elevate the limb
Administer systemic anticoagulants to prevent thromboembolism

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient involved in a severe accident presents with increasing leg pain, swelling and sensory deficits. Compartment pressure measurements are elevated. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Immediate fasciotomy to relieve compartment syndrome

 

  • Compartment Syndrome: This condition arises when there is increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment that compromises blood flow and tissue perfusion, leading to muscle and nerve damage if not promptly addressed. The common causes include trauma, fractures  or prolonged pressure on the limb.
  • Indications for Fasciotomy: Elevated compartment pressures (usually above 30 mmHg) combined with clinical signs such as severe pain, swelling, and sensory deficits indicate compartment syndrome. Immediate fasciotomy is required to relieve the pressure, restore normal blood flow, and prevent irreversible muscle and nerve damage.
  • Procedure: A fasciotomy involves making an incision through the skin and fascia to release the pressure within the affected compartment. This surgical intervention is typically urgent and must be performed as soon as possible to avoid complications such as muscle necrosis or permanent functional impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Start High-Dose IV Antibiotics and Observe: Antibiotic Use: High-dose intravenous antibiotics are appropriate for treating infections but are not effective in managing compartment syndrome. While antibiotics might be necessary if there is an infection or suspected infection (e.g. in the case of an open fracture with infection risk), they do not address the root cause of compartment syndrome.

 

Observation: Simply observing the patient without addressing the underlying elevated compartment pressures would lead to worsening muscle and nerve damage. Immediate intervention is required to manage the elevated pressure and prevent serious complications.

 

Option C. Apply a Compression Bandage and Elevate the Limb: Compression Bandage: Applying a compression bandage is contraindicated in compartment syndrome because it can exacerbate the problem by increasing the pressure within the compartment. This can lead to further impairment of blood flow and worsen the condition.

 

Elevation: Elevating the limb can be helpful in reducing swelling but does not address the underlying elevated compartment pressure. It is not sufficient alone for managing compartment syndrome, where surgical intervention is critical.

 

Option D. Administer Systemic Anticoagulants to Prevent Thromboembolism: Anticoagulants: Systemic anticoagulants are used to prevent blood clots (thromboembolic events) but are not relevant in the management of compartment syndrome. Administering anticoagulants in the presence of compartment syndrome can be dangerous as it does not alleviate the pressure in the compartment and might increase bleeding risk if a fasciotomy is performed.

 

Compartment Syndrome Management: The primary goal is to relieve the pressure within the compartment, and anticoagulants do not address this need.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient with compartment syndrome, the immediate and essential treatment is fasciotomy.
  •  This surgical procedure is necessary to relieve the elevated pressures within the muscle compartment, restore normal blood flow and prevent permanent damage.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with metastatic cancer is found to have a serum calcium level of 14.8 mg/dL. He is symptomatic with confusion and dehydration. What is the immediate treatment for hypercalcemia of malignancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV fluids

 

  • The immediate treatment for hypercalcemia of malignancy is aggressive hydration with intravenous fluids to restore intravascular volume and promote renal excretion of calcium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bisphosphonates: Used for long-term management but not immediate treatment.

 

Option C. Calcitonin: Can be used for rapid but temporary reduction in calcium levels.

 

Option D. Glucocorticoids: Useful in certain types of hypercalcemia, such as those due to granulomatous disease or certain cancers, but not the first-line immediate treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The immediate treatment for hypercalcemia of malignancy is IV fluids to enhance renal calcium excretion and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: A full-term female infant presents with failure to gain weight and metabolic acidosis during the neonatal period. By 6 months, physical examination reveals failure to thrive, hypotonia, small muscle mass, severe head lag, and persistent acidosis with a blood pH between 7.0 and 7.2. Blood tests show greatly elevated levels of lactate, pyruvate, and alanine. Treatment with thiamine has not alleviated the lactic acidosis. Which enzyme is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

 

  • The clinical scenario described is suggestive of a pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) deficiency.
  • PDH deficiency is a rare metabolic disorder that results in the inability to convert pyruvate into Acetyl-CoA, leading to the accumulation of pyruvate, which is then shunted to lactate and alanine, causing lactic acidosis.
  • The elevated levels of blood lactate, pyruvate, and alanine, along with the lack of response to thiamine treatment, strongly indicate a PDH deficiency.
  • The persistent metabolic acidosis despite thiamine supplementation, which is a cofactor for PDH, further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase: This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, converting oxaloacetate to phosphoenolpyruvate. A deficiency would lead to hypoglycemia and other metabolic disturbances, but it is less directly related to lactic acidosis as seen in this case.

 

Option C. Alanine aminotransferase: This enzyme catalyzes the reversible transfer of an amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate. A deficiency in this enzyme would not lead to the clinical presentation described, particularly the elevated lactate and persistent acidosis.

 

Option D. Pyruvate carboxylase: This enzyme is involved in gluconeogenesis, converting pyruvate to oxaloacetate. A deficiency could lead to lactic acidosis, but the clinical presentation would likely include hypoglycemia and failure to thrive. The presence of elevated alanine and pyruvate levels makes PDH deficiency more likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency is characterized by severe lactic acidosis, elevated levels of pyruvate and alanine, and lack of response to thiamine supplementation.
  • It results from the inability to convert pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, causing an accumulation of pyruvate that is shunted to lactate.

choices.text: Presence of atypical pseudocholinesterase in this patient

questions.text: A 53-year-old male with multiple fractures and internal injuries is undergoing emergency surgery. Anesthesia is induced with thiopentone, and succinylcholine is used for intubation, followed by vecuronium. During surgery, the patient develops the arrhythmias shown in the ECG. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Succinylcholine-induced hyperkalemia

 

  • Succinylcholine is known to cause hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with conditions such as crush injuries, burns, or severe trauma.
  • The rapid release of potassium from cells can lead to dangerous arrhythmias, as suggested by the ECG findings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of atypical pseudocholinesterase in this patient: This would result in prolonged muscle paralysis due to slower metabolism of succinylcholine, but is less likely to directly cause arrhythmias.

 

Option C. Vecuronium overdose: This would typically cause prolonged muscle relaxation and paralysis, not hyperkalemia-induced arrhythmias.

 

Option D. Accidental intra-arterial injection of thiopentone: This might cause vascular complications but is unlikely to cause the arrhythmias seen on the ECG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Succinylcholine can cause significant hyperkalemia, especially in patients with trauma, which can lead to life-threatening arrhythmias.
  • It is crucial to monitor potassium levels in such high-risk patients during anesthesia.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with a history of recurrent episodes of joint pain, swelling and rash. The rash appears as erythematous, scaly plaques over the cheeks and buttocks. The child's parents mention that these symptoms seem to flare up periodically and are associated with fever. Physical examination reveals synovitis in multiple joints and eye examination shows uveitis. Genetic testing is performed, revealing a mutation in the NOD2 gene. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Blau Syndrome

 

  • Blau syndrome is a rare autoinflammatory disorder that presents with a classic triad of arthritis, dermatitis (skin rash) and uveitis.
  • The syndrome is characterized by granulomatous inflammation, which affects the joints, skin and eyes.
  • The presence of a mutation in the NOD2 gene, as noted in the patient's genetic testing, is strongly associated with Blau syndrome.
  • This genetic mutation supports the diagnosis in this case, explaining the recurrent symptoms of joint pain, skin rash and eye inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA): Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis is a common cause of arthritis in children and can present with joint pain and swelling. However, JIA typically does not present with granulomatous inflammation, skin rashes that flare periodically, or uveitis as described in this case. Moreover, JIA is not associated with NOD2 gene mutations.

 

Option B. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE): Systemic Lupus Erythematosus can present with a variety of symptoms, including joint pain, rash and systemic involvement. However, SLE is more commonly associated with malar rash (butterfly-shaped rash across the cheeks and nose) and is not specifically associated with NOD2 gene mutations. The presence of granulomatous inflammation and the specific triad of symptoms described are more consistent with Blau syndrome.

 

Option D. Kawasaki Disease: Kawasaki Disease is an acute vasculitis that typically affects young children. It presents with prolonged fever, rash, conjunctivitis, changes in the extremities and lymphadenopathy. It does not typically present with the recurrent joint pain, granulomatous inflammation or NOD2 gene mutations seen in Blau syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blau syndrome is a rare autoinflammatory disorder characterized by the triad of granulomatous arthritis, skin rash and uveitis.
  •  It is associated with mutations in the NOD2 gene.
  • Recognizing this constellation of symptoms and the genetic association is crucial for diagnosing Blau syndrome and differentiating it from other pediatric conditions with overlapping features.

choices.text: More risk of perianal fistulae

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with a history of inflammatory bowel disease presents with worsening diarrhoea and abdominal pain. She reports experiencing episodes of blood in her stool and has also noticed perianal discomfort. Physical examination reveals perianal skin tags and tenderness near the anus. Based on these findings, which of the following is more characteristic of Crohn’s disease compared to ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) More risk of perianal fistulae

 

  • Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis are both types of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), but they have distinct characteristics and should not be considered the same.
  • Crohn's disease can affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract, from the mouth to the anus, and is known for causing "skip lesions," meaning areas of diseased tissue interspersed with healthy tissue.
  • Perianal fistulae: Crohn’s disease is more associated with perianal complications, including fistulae, abscesses and fissures, due to the deeper transmural inflammation that characterizes the disease.
  • This is in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which primarily involves the mucosa and submucosa and starts from the rectum, rarely involving perianal areas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lesions are continuous: This statement is incorrect for Crohn’s disease. Continuous lesions are characteristic of ulcerative colitis. In Crohn’s disease, the inflammation is patchy, with skip lesions being typical.

 

Option C. Malignancy is more common: Malignancy is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis, particularly colorectal cancer, due to the long-standing inflammation typically confined to the colon. Crohn’s disease has a lower risk of malignancy.

 

Option D. Often presents with hematochezia: Hematochezia, or the passage of fresh blood in the stool, is more commonly associated with ulcerative colitis. Crohn’s disease typically presents with non-bloody diarrhoea, although some cases might involve blood, it is not as frequent as in ulcerative colitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crohn’s disease is characterized by a higher risk of perianal fistulae and skip lesions, in contrast to ulcerative colitis, which presents with continuous lesions and a higher risk of colorectal malignancy.

choices.text: Brain MRI and carotid ultrasonography

questions.text: A 39-year-old man faints while waiting to buy concert tickets. He felt warm and diaphoretic just before fainting and recovered completely within 1 to 2 minutes. His pulse rate is 50/min, and the ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 52/min. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No further testing

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with neurally mediated syncope (also known as vasovagal syncope), which is the most common type of syncope. Suggestive features include the “3 P's”: posture (occurrence during prolonged standing or aborted by lying down), provoking factors (e.g., heat, stress), and prodromal symptoms (diaphoresis, warmth, and pallor). Given the classic presentation and normal examination findings, no further testing is required. The patient should be advised on maintaining adequate hydration and using counterpressure maneuvers if symptoms recur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Brain MRI and carotid ultrasonography: Not recommended in the absence of neurologic findings.

 

Option B. Echocardiography: Indicated only if structural heart disease is suspected, which is not the case here.

 

Option C. Prolonged electrocardiographic monitoring: Used for suspected arrhythmic causes of syncope, but this patient's presentation suggests a benign vasovagal cause.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of uncomplicated vasovagal syncope, no further testing beyond a clinical evaluation and ECG is required. Patients should be counseled on preventive strategies, including hydration and counterpressure maneuvers.

choices.text: The syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
The condition is associated with increased risk of lymphoma and leukemia.
The syndrome is characterized by progressive peripheral neuropathy with onset in late adolescence.
Elevated serum lactate is a hallmark of this condition.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with a history of progressive ataxia, oculomotor apraxia and choreoathetosis. She also has recurrent infections and elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the ATM gene. Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The condition is associated with increased risk of lymphoma and leukemia.

 

  • Ataxia-Telangiectasia is associated with a significantly increased risk of developing malignancies, particularly lymphoma and leukemia, due to defects in DNA repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The syndrome is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern: The condition described is Ataxia-Telangiectasia (A-T), which is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern, not dominant.

 

Option C. The syndrome is characterized by progressive peripheral neuropathy with onset in late adolescence: Progressive peripheral neuropathy is not a primary feature of A-T. The neurological symptoms in A-T typically include cerebellar ataxia and movement disorders that begin in early childhood.

 

Option D. Elevated serum lactate is a hallmark of this condition: Elevated serum lactate is not associated with Ataxia-Telangiectasia; it is more commonly associated with mitochondrial disorders

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  Ataxia-Telangiectasia is associated with a significantly increased risk of developing malignancies, particularly lymphoma and leukemia, due to defects in DNA repair.

questions.text: Below diagram shows auditory brainstem implant. Identify the structure marked:
questions.solution: Ans. A) Grounding electrode

questions.text: A patient on anticoagulation therapy is being monitored to ensure safety and efficacy. For which of the following medications is drug monitoring required?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that requires monitoring of the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) to ensure therapeutic levels are achieved and to avoid the risk of bleeding or thrombosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fondaparinux: Fondaparinux is a synthetic pentasaccharide that inhibits factor Xa. Routine monitoring is generally not required because it has a predictable pharmacokinetic profile.

 

Option B. Enoxaparin: Enoxaparin, a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), does not typically require monitoring in most patients due to its predictable dose-response relationship, though anti-Xa levels may be checked in special populations (e.g., renal impairment, obesity).

 

Option D. Dabigatran: Dabigatran, a direct oral anticoagulant (DOAC), does not require routine monitoring due to its predictable pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepirudin requires monitoring of aPTT to ensure therapeutic efficacy and safety, unlike Fondaparinux, Enoxaparin, and Dabigatran, which generally do not require routine drug monitoring.

choices.text: Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)
Yellow fever

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, headache, and confusion after a hiking trip in southern India. He has been diagnosed with a condition similar to Russian spring-summer encephalitis. Given his diagnosis, which of the following flaviviruses is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD)

 

  • The virus causing Kyasanur Forest Disease is a tick-borne flavivirus closely related to the virus that causes Russian spring-summer encephalitis.
  • Both are members of the tick-borne encephalitis (TBE) complex within the Flavivirus genus, sharing similarities in their transmission and clinical presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dengue: Although Dengue is a flavivirus, it is transmitted by mosquitoes and is not closely related to the Russian spring-summer encephalitis virus.

 

Option B. Chikungunya: Chikungunya is an alphavirus, not a flavivirus, and is transmitted by mosquitoes.

 

Option D. Yellow fever: Yellow fever virus is a flavivirus, but it is mosquito-borne and not part of the tick-borne encephalitis complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) virus is a tick-borne flavivirus closely related to the Russian spring-summer encephalitis virus, both part of the tick-borne encephalitis complex.
  • Understanding the relationships between viruses within the Flavivirus genus is important for diagnosis and epidemiological tracking.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is scheduled for a tonsillectomy under general anesthesia. The anesthesiologist uses a specialized endotracheal tube to ensure unobstructed access to the surgical field while maintaining airway security. The image below shows the endotracheal tube in place during the procedure. Which type of endotracheal tube is being used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) South Pole endotracheal tube

 

The South Pole tube is specially designed for surgeries like tonsillectomies. Its downward curve allows the tube to be positioned out of the surgical field, providing the surgeon with better access to the tonsils while maintaining a secure airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Standard endotracheal tube: A standard endotracheal tube is commonly used in general anesthesia but does not have the specialized curvature required for certain surgeries like tonsillectomy, where the tube might obstruct the surgeon's view or access to the surgical field.

 

 

Option B. North Pole endotracheal tube: The North Pole tube is a curved tube, but it is designed to curve in the opposite direction of the South Pole tube, making it less suitable for procedures like tonsillectomy where downward curvature is needed to keep the tube out of the surgical field.

 

 

Option C. Flexometallic endotracheal tube: This type of tube has a flexible, reinforced structure that prevents kinking, making it useful in head and neck surgeries. However, it does not have the specific directional curve characteristic of the South Pole tube used in tonsillectomies.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The South Pole endotracheal tube is specifically designed for use in tonsillectomy and similar surgeries, where its unique downward curve allows for unobstructed surgical access while maintaining airway management.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with a 9-month history of cramping pain in the buttocks radiating to both legs, more on the right. The pain worsens with standing and walking up stairs but is relieved by sitting or leaning forward. She has a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination reveals normal lower extremity strength, sensation, reflexes, and intact peripheral pulses. No spinal tenderness is noted. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Spinal stenosis

 

  • The patient's symptoms are most consistent with spinal stenosis, which is caused by narrowing of the spinal canal, often due to degenerative changes.
  • The hallmark of spinal stenosis is pain that worsens with standing and walking (spinal extension) and improves with sitting or leaning forward (spinal flexion).
  • This positional relief is characteristic of spinal stenosis and differentiates it from other causes of leg pain, such as peripheral artery disease, which does not typically improve with changes in posture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy: This condition typically presents with progressive, symmetric weakness and sensory loss with diffuse areflexia, none of which are seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Diabetic amyotrophy: Presents with acute, asymmetric pain followed by weakness and atrophy, usually involving the proximal leg, and often associated with weight loss and autonomic failure, which are not present in this case.

 

Option C. Peripheral artery disease: Causes claudication that worsens with exertion but does not improve with postural changes like sitting or leaning forward, and is typically associated with diminished peripheral pulses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Spinal stenosis should be considered in patients with back or leg pain that worsens with standing and walking and improves with sitting or leaning forward.
  • It is differentiated from vascular causes by the positional nature of symptom relief and the presence of normal peripheral pulses.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the dermatology clinic with multiple painful blisters on her skin. The blisters are filled with clear fluid, and a Tzanck smear is performed on one of the lesions. The smear shows specific cytological findings that help in diagnosing her condition. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on a Tzanck smear of her lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acantholysis

 

  • A Tzanck smear is a diagnostic test used to examine cells from blistering skin conditions.
  • In the context of bullous lesions, acantholysis refers to the loss of cohesion between keratinocytes, leading to the formation of blistering lesions.
  • This finding is characteristic of conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris, where the Tzanck smear would reveal acantholytic cells.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Langerhans cells: Langerhans cells are dendritic cells involved in the immune response and are not typically identified in a Tzanck smear. They are more relevant in the context of immune surveillance and skin immunity.

 

Option C. Leukocytosis: Leucocytosis refers to an increased number of white blood cells in the blood, not a specific finding on a Tzanck smear. A Tzanck smear examines cells from the blister fluid, not blood cells.

 

Option D. Absence of melanin pigment: The absence of melanin pigment is not a finding associated with a Tzanck smear. The smear focuses on cellular changes, such as the presence of multinucleated giant cells or acantholytic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acantholysis is a characteristic finding on a Tzanck smear from a bullous lesion, indicative of conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male undergoes dental surgery under local anesthesia with a reported history of a previous dental procedure where he received an anesthetic agent. Shortly after the procedure, he begins to experience shortness of breath, cyanosis and lightheadedness. His oxygen saturation drops to 85% despite being on 100% oxygen. Blood drawn for analysis appears chocolate-brown in color, and a co-oximetry test confirms the presence of methemoglobinemia. Which of the following local anesthetic agents is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prilocaine

 

  • Prilocaine is known to be associated with the development of methemoglobinemia, particularly at higher doses.
  •  Methemoglobinemia occurs when hemoglobin is oxidized to methemoglobin, which cannot effectively bind and release oxygen, leading to symptoms such as cyanosis and hypoxia.
  • Prilocaine is metabolized to o-toluidine, a compound that promotes the formation of methemoglobin, making it the most likely cause of the patient's symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mepivacaine: Mepivacaine is a local anesthetic that is not commonly associated with methemoglobinemia. While it is effective for local anesthesia, it does not have the same propensity to cause methemoglobin formation as prilocaine does.

 

Option C. Lignocaine: Lignocaine (also known as lidocaine) is a widely used local anesthetic and, although it has a low risk of causing methemoglobinemia, it is significantly less likely to cause this condition compared to prilocaine.

 

Option D. Bupivacaine: Bupivacaine is a potent local anesthetic used in various surgical procedures, particularly for long-duration blocks. However, it is not typically associated with methemoglobinemia, making it an unlikely cause in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Prilocaine is the local anesthetic most commonly associated with methemoglobinemia due to its metabolism into o-toluidine, which increases the level of methemoglobin in the blood.
  • Recognizing this potential side effect is important when selecting an anesthetic agent, especially in patients with a history of methemoglobinemia or when using high doses.

choices.text: Hepatitis A
Hepatitis B
Hepatitis C
Hepatitis D

questions.text: A researcher is investigating the genetic factors that influence the immune response to viral Hepatitis infections. In her study, she notes that certain HLA types are associated with either susceptibility to or clearance of specific Hepatitis viruses. Which Hepatitis virus is HLA DR 5 most associated with the clearance of?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hepatitis C

 

  • HLA DR 5 has been particularly associated with the clearance of Hepatitis C virus (HCV).
  • Individuals possessing this allele are more likely to spontaneously clear HCV, which is an important consideration in understanding immune responses and potentially guiding personalized treatment strategies.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Hepatitis A: While immune responses are crucial for recovery, specific HLA associations with Hepatitis A clearance are not as prominently recognized as with HCV.

 

Option B. Hepatitis B: Certain other HLA types have been associated with the control and clearance of HBV, but not specifically HLA DR 5.

 

Option D. Hepatitis D:  Hepatitis D virus infection depends on the presence of Hepatitis B virus, and no significant association with HLA DR 5 has been reported for HDV clearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genetic factors such as HLA DR 5 play a significant role in the immune response to viral infections, including a favorable outcome in HCV infections. This information can be vital for developing targeted therapies and understanding individual variations in disease progression and resolution.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with alcohol use disorder is referred for evaluation. She has no history of encephalopathy, gastrointestinal bleeding, or ascites, but has splenomegaly and a platelet count of 85,000/µL. Her only medication is naltrexone. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Upper endoscopy

 

  • The patient has signs suggestive of portal hypertension, likely due to cirrhosis, given her splenomegaly and thrombocytopenia.
  • The most appropriate next step is an upper endoscopy to assess for esophageal varices, which are a common complication of portal hypertension.
  • Early detection is crucial to prevent variceal bleeding.
  • If varices are found, treatment options such as nonselective β-blockers or endoscopic variceal ligation can be considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Platelet transfusion: Not indicated in asymptomatic thrombocytopenia unless there is active bleeding or an upcoming high-risk procedure.

 

Option B. Propranolol: Used to prevent bleeding in patients with known varices but should not be initiated without confirming the presence of varices.

 

Option C. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS): Indicated for refractory variceal bleeding or ascites, not for initial evaluation or prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with cirrhosis and suspected portal hypertension, upper endoscopy is essential to evaluate for esophageal varices.
  • Early identification and management of varices can prevent life-threatening complications like variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) undergoes a pulmonary function test (PFT) as part of his routine evaluation. The results indicate that at a specific lung volume, the pressure measured at the upper airway is zero, which corresponds to no net airflow in or out of the lungs. At which of the following lung volumes or capacities does this phenomenon occur?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Functional residual capacity

 

  • Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the lung volume at the end of a normal exhalation when the elastic recoil forces of the lungs are balanced by the outward pull of the chest wall.
  • At FRC, the pressure in the airways equals atmospheric pressure (zero), meaning there is no driving force for air to move in or out of the lungs, and the airflow is at equilibrium.
  • This is the point where the lungs are at rest between breaths, and the pressure in the upper airways is zero.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total lung capacity: Total lung capacity (TLC) is the maximum volume of air that the lungs can hold after a maximal inhalation. At this point, the intrapleural pressure is very negative, and the airway pressure is not zero.

 

Option B. Inspiratory capacity: Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the volume of air that can be inhaled after a normal exhalation, but it does not represent the equilibrium point where airway pressure is zero.

 

Option C. Residual volume: Residual volume (RV) is the amount of air remaining in the lungs after a maximal exhalation, and at this volume, the airway pressure is not zero.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Functional residual capacity (FRC) is the lung volume at which airway pressure reaches zero, meaning there is no net movement of air in or out of the lungs, reflecting the equilibrium between lung and chest wall forces.

questions.text: A young man complaints of pain in lower back. His X-rays are shown below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

  • Anatomy and Pathology: Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that predominantly affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. It often begins in young adults and is characterized by chronic inflammation leading to the gradual fusion of the spine. This fusion creates a rigid, immobile spine that can be visualized on X-rays as a "bamboo spine."
  • X-ray Findings: The "bamboo spine" appearance results from the formation of syndesmophytes (bone growths from the spinal ligaments) and the eventual fusion of the vertebrae. This results in a radiographic appearance where the vertebrae have a characteristic appearance resembling bamboo stalks, with alternating areas of radiolucency (dark areas) and radiopacity (bright areas) due to the calcification of the anterior longitudinal ligament and the formation of bridges between vertebrae.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients often present with chronic lower back pain and stiffness, which typically worsens with inactivity and improves with movement. Other symptoms can include morning stiffness, reduced spinal mobility, and sometimes peripheral arthritis or enthesitis (inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments attach to bone). HLA-B27 antigen positivity is commonly associated with this condition.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves clinical evaluation, radiographic findings, and laboratory tests. MRI can also reveal early inflammatory changes before significant radiographic changes occur.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spondylolisthesis:

 

  • Anatomy and Pathology: Spondylolisthesis involves the forward displacement of one vertebra over the one below it, often due to a defect in the pars interarticularis (a part of the vertebra) or other structural abnormalities. This condition can be caused by congenital defects, trauma, or degenerative changes.
  • X-ray Findings: On X-rays, spondylolisthesis is characterized by the slippage of a vertebra, which can be graded based on the degree of displacement. There is typically no "bamboo spine" appearance; instead, the focus is on the alignment and displacement of vertebrae.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms include lower back pain, potentially radiating pain into the legs, and in severe cases, neurological symptoms such as weakness or numbness. It often results from stress fractures or other structural issues in the lumbar region.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is confirmed by X-ray or CT scans showing vertebral slippage. MRI may be used to assess the degree of nerve root involvement or other complications.

 

Option C. Paget’s Disease:

 

  • Anatomy and Pathology: Paget’s disease is a chronic bone disorder characterized by abnormal and excessive bone remodeling. It results in enlarged and weakened bones, affecting areas such as the pelvis, skull, spine and long bones.
  • X-ray Findings: X-rays in Paget’s disease reveal abnormalities such as enlarged, thickened and deformed bones. The spine can show enlarged vertebrae and areas of bone sclerosis (increased bone density), but it does not typically present with a "bamboo spine" appearance.
  • Clinical Presentation: Symptoms may include bone pain, deformities, and in some cases, neurological symptoms due to spinal involvement. It more commonly affects older adults rather than young individuals.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves X-rays showing characteristic bone changes, bone scans, and laboratory tests to measure markers of bone metabolism.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis:

 

  • Anatomy and Pathology: Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by reduced bone density and increased risk of fractures. It weakens bones, making them more susceptible to fractures, particularly in the spine, hips and wrists.
  • X-ray Findings: X-rays may show vertebral compression fractures, decreased bone density, and sometimes a "wedged" appearance of vertebrae due to fractures. There is no "bamboo spine" appearance in osteoporosis.
  • Clinical Presentation: Common symptoms include back pain, especially following minor trauma, and a higher risk of fractures. It typically affects older individuals, though secondary forms can affect younger people due to certain risk factors.
  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is usually made through bone density testing (DEXA scans) and X-rays showing vertebral compression fractures. Osteoporosis is not characterized by the "bamboo spine" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The bamboo spine appearance is a hallmark of AS, resulting from the progressive fusion of the vertebrae and calcification of spinal ligaments.

 

This condition aligns with the chronic inflammatory nature of AS and its typical onset in young adults.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents with persistent wheezing, episodes of hemoptysis, and a dry cough. A CT scan of the chest reveals a mass occluding the left bronchus. A biopsy of the mass shows polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for CD56, synaptophysin and chromogranin. What is the cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kulchitsky cell

 

  • The patient presents with symptoms and imaging findings suggestive of a pulmonary neoplasm.
  • The biopsy findings, including the presence of polygonal cells with fine stippled chromatin and eosinophilic cytoplasm arranged in nests, along with positive immunohistochemical staining for CD56, synaptophysin and chromogranin, are characteristic of a neuroendocrine tumor, specifically small cell lung carcinoma (SCLC).
  • Kulchitsky cells, also known as neuroendocrine cells, are the cells of origin for small cell lung carcinoma.
  • These cells are part of the diffuse neuroendocrine system and are found in the respiratory epithelium.
  • Their neuroendocrine nature is confirmed by the presence of markers such as CD56, synaptophysin, and chromogranin, which are critical for the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Goblet cell: Goblet cells are mucus-secreting cells found in the epithelial lining of the respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts. While they are important for secreting mucus to protect the respiratory epithelium, they do not give rise to neuroendocrine tumors and are not associated with small cell lung carcinoma.

 

Option C. Basal cell: Basal cells are progenitor cells found in the basal layer of the epithelium, which have the ability to differentiate into various cell types in the respiratory tract. However, they are not involved in the pathogenesis of neuroendocrine tumors like small cell lung carcinoma.

 

Option D. Type 2 pneumocyte: Type 2 pneumocytes are alveolar cells responsible for the production of surfactant and the regeneration of the alveolar epithelium. While they are important in lung physiology, they do not give rise to neuroendocrine tumors like small cell lung carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Small cell lung carcinoma originates from Kulchitsky cells (neuroendocrine cells) in the respiratory epithelium, which are characterized by their neuroendocrine markers, including CD56, synaptophysin and chromogranin.

choices.text: Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient with a history of myelodysplastic syndrome is scheduled to undergo an allogeneic stem cell transplant. To prepare for the transplant, the patient requires multiple transfusions of red blood cells (RBCs). The medical team decides to transfuse irradiated red blood cells. What condition is primarily being prevented by transfusing irradiated RBCs?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Graft versus host disease

 

  • Transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) is primarily done to prevent graft versus host disease (GVHD).
  • GVHD is a severe and potentially fatal condition that can occur when transfused donor lymphocytes attack the recipient's tissues.
