  • This is particularly concerning in immunocompromised patients, such as those undergoing stem cell transplants, as their immune systems are unable to mount an effective defense against these donor cells.
  • Irradiation of RBCs effectively inactivates these lymphocytes, thereby preventing GVHD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI): TRALI is a serious complication of blood transfusion characterized by acute lung injury. It is typically associated with antibodies in the donor plasma that react with the recipient’s white blood cells, leading to lung damage. Irradiation of RBCs does not prevent TRALI, as it is not related to the presence of active lymphocytes.

 

Option B. HLA Alloimmunization: HLA alloimmunization occurs when the recipient develops antibodies against human leukocyte antigens (HLA) present on transfused cells. This condition is more relevant in platelet transfusions rather than RBC transfusions. Irradiation of RBCs does not prevent HLA alloimmunization, which is more related to the presence of antigens rather than viable lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Immunomodulation: Immunomodulation refers to the alteration of the immune response due to transfusion. It is generally associated with the transfusion of non-irradiated blood products, which might lead to a down-regulation of the recipient's immune system. However, the primary purpose of irradiating RBCs is to prevent GVHD, not to modulate the immune system in general.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary purpose of transfusing irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) is to prevent graft versus host disease (GVHD) in immunocompromised patients.
  •  This is accomplished by inactivating any donor lymphocytes that might otherwise initiate an immune attack on the recipient's tissues.

choices.text: Squamous cell carcinoma
Basal cell carcinoma

questions.text: An elderly male presents with papular lesions on his face. The papules are with pearly telangiectatic border on sun-damaged skin. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Basal cell carcinoma

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is the most common type of skin cancer, particularly in elderly individuals with a history of chronic sun exposure.
  • It often presents as pearly or translucent papules with telangiectasia (visible blood vessels) on sun-exposed areas such as the face.

 

 

  • These lesions can also develop a rolled border and central ulceration, commonly described as "rodent ulcer."
  • BCC grows slowly and rarely metastasizes but can cause significant local tissue destruction if not treated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous cell carcinoma: Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) also occurs on sun-exposed skin but typically presents as a rough, scaly, and sometimes ulcerated nodule or plaque. It may also have a more aggressive clinical course compared to BCC.

 

Option B. Melanoma: Melanoma arises from melanocytes and usually presents as an asymmetric pigmented lesion with irregular borders and color variation.

 

 

 

It is more dangerous than BCC and SCC due to its higher potential for metastasis.

 

Option D. Actinic keratosis: Actinic keratosis is a precancerous lesion that appears as rough, scaly patches on sun-damaged skin.

 

 

It can progress to SCC if left untreated but does not have the characteristic pearly appearance and telangiectatic border seen in BCC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Basal cell carcinoma typically presents as pearly papules with telangiectatic borders on sun-damaged skin, especially in elderly individuals with chronic sun exposure.
  • It is the most common type of skin cancer and has a low risk of metastasis but can cause significant local damage.

questions.text: A woman presents with a breast tumor of size 6 x 3cm, with adherence to the pectoralis major muscle. Only the dermis of the overlying skin is found to be puckered. As her surgeon, what will you designate her T staging as?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) T3

 

  • P Major involvement does not affect T stage. Hence T4a is not the answer.
  • Puckering is not skin involvement. Hence T4b is not her stage
  • T4d implies inflammatory breast cancer.
  • Thus T stage will be based on size alone: 6 cm = T3

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Size of breast tumor of 6 cm implies stage T3.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is diagnosed with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML). The disease is driven by the BCR-ABL fusion gene, which activates a tyrosine kinase. Which of the following drugs is specifically designed to inhibit this tyrosine kinase?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Ponatinib: Ponatinib is a potent inhibitor of BCR-ABL and is effective against various mutations of the kinase, including those resistant to other treatments.

 

Option B. Bosutinib: Bosutinib is another BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of CML.

 

Option C. Imatinib: Imatinib was the first BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor developed and is widely used as a frontline treatment for CML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase, central to the pathogenesis of CML, can be effectively inhibited by drugs such as Bosutinib, Imatinib, Nilotinib, Dasatinib, and Ponatinib, which are specifically designed to target this abnormal kinase activity.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman from the Caribbean presents to the neurology clinic with progressive weakness and spasticity of her lower limbs. After a detailed history and neurological examination, the clinician suspects tropical spastic paraparesis. Which virus is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus (HTLV)

 

  • Tropical spastic paraparesis, also known as HTLV-1 associated myelopathy, is most commonly caused by the Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus type 1 (HTLV-1). This retrovirus infects CD4+ T cells and can lead to neurological impairments, including progressive weakness and spasticity in the legs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epstein Barr Virus: Known primarily for causing infectious mononucleosis, not typically associated with chronic neurological conditions like tropical spastic paraparesis.

 

Option C. Human Immunodeficiency Virus: While HIV can cause a variety of neurological complications, it is not the primary cause of tropical spastic paraparesis.

 

Option D. Hepatitis B virus: Primarily affects the liver and does not cause neurological conditions such as tropical spastic paraparesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HTLV-1 is a key viral etiology in tropical spastic paraparesis, emphasizing the need for awareness and testing for HTLV-1 in patients presenting with unexplained neurological symptoms, particularly in endemic areas.
  • Early diagnosis can help in managing symptoms and preventing further progression of the disease.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents to the clinic with complaints of postmenopausal bleeding. What is the most appropriate next step to evaluate the cause of her bleeding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Endometrial sampling

  

  • In a postmenopausal woman, especially with risk factors such as diabetes and hypertension, postmenopausal bleeding is a red flag that necessitates prompt investigation for endometrial cancer.
  • Endometrial sampling is the most appropriate and definitive diagnostic tool to evaluate the endometrial lining, checking for hyperplasia, atrophy, or malignancy.
  • It directly assesses the tissue that is the most likely source of the abnormal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colposcopy: Colposcopy is typically used for further evaluation of abnormal cervical findings and is not the first-line investigation for postmenopausal bleeding, which is more likely to be related to endometrial issues.

 

Option B. Pap smear: While important for cervical cancer screening, a Pap smear does not evaluate the endometrium and is not the first step in assessing postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Option D. Visual inspection with iodine: This method is used primarily in cervical cancer screening in resource-limited settings and is not applicable to the assessment of postmenopausal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometrial sampling is the most appropriate initial step in evaluating postmenopausal bleeding, especially in women with risk factors like diabetes and hypertension, to rule out endometrial cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with early satiety, abdominal discomfort, and unintentional weight loss over several months. Imaging reveals a mass in the stomach. A biopsy of the mass is performed, and the pathology report is suggestive of a gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Which of the following immunohistochemical markers is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) DOG-1

 

  • Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) are the most common mesenchymal tumors of the gastrointestinal tract, arising from the interstitial cells of Cajal.
  • DOG-1 (Discovered on GIST-1) is a highly specific and sensitive marker for GISTs. Unlike CD117, which may occasionally be negative in GISTs, DOG-1 is consistently expressed even in CD117-negative tumors.
  • Therefore, DOG-1 is increasingly used as an important diagnostic marker, particularly in cases where CD117 is negative or equivocal.
  • In this clinical scenario, where a patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a gastric mass and biopsy results indicate a GIST, the use of DOG-1 as a diagnostic marker would confirm the diagnosis with high specificity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CD30: CD30 is a marker associated with certain types of lymphomas, such as Hodgkin lymphoma and anaplastic large cell lymphoma. It is not relevant to gastrointestinal stromal tumors and would not be useful in confirming a diagnosis of GIST.

 

Option C. CD34: CD34 is a marker that is often expressed in GISTs; however, it is not as specific as DOG-1. While it may be positive in GISTs, CD34 alone is insufficient for a definitive diagnosis, particularly when CD117 or DOG-1 could provide more specificity.

 

Option D. CD117: CD117 (c-Kit) is a common marker for GISTs and is positive in a large majority of cases. However, it can occasionally be negative in some GISTs, where DOG-1 might still be positive, making DOG-1 a more reliable marker in certain situations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DOG-1 is a highly specific and sensitive immunohistochemical marker used to diagnose gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs), particularly in cases where CD117 may be negative or equivocal.

choices.text: Opinions and conventional wisdom of experts

questions.text: A physician is updating her practice guidelines and wants to ensure they align with the highest standards of Evidence-Based Medicine (EBM). She seeks the most reliable source of evidence for informing clinical decision-making. Which of the following is considered the most important source of evidence in EBM to guide clinical practice?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blinded trials

 

  • In Evidence-Based Medicine, the highest importance is given to strong epidemiological studies, with blinded trials being among the most critical sources of evidence.
  • These trials are valued for their ability to minimize bias and provide reliable data for clinical decision-making.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Opinions and conventional wisdom of experts: These are given the least importance in EBM, as they are more subjective and less scientifically rigorous.

 

Option C. Observational studies: While valuable, observational studies rank lower in the hierarchy of evidence compared to blinded trials.

 

Option D. Case reports: These are among the least important forms of evidence in EBM due to their anecdotal nature and lack of generalizability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Evidence-Based Medicine, the most reliable evidence comes from strong epidemiological studies like meta-analyses, systematic reviews, and blinded trials, whereas opinions and anecdotal evidence are considered the least reliable.

questions.text: A junior resident is tasked with designing a study on the long-term effects of a dietary supplement. The resident is particularly concerned about avoiding the types of bias typically encountered in retrospective studies. Which type of bias, commonly affecting retrospective data, can be effectively minimized by utilizing a prospective study design?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Recall bias

 

  • Recall bias occurs when participants in a retrospective study inaccurately remember past events or exposures, leading to distorted data.
  • This type of bias is minimized in prospective studies because data is collected in real-time, reducing the reliance on memory.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confounding: Confounding can be controlled in both retrospective and prospective studies through careful design and statistical adjustments.

 

Option B. Effect modification: Effect modification is not a bias but rather a real difference in the effect of an exposure on an outcome depending on the presence of a third factor.

 

Option D. Measurement bias: Measurement bias can occur in any study design if there are errors in how data is collected, but it is not specifically eliminated by a prospective design.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recall bias is a significant concern in retrospective studies and can be minimized by using a prospective design, where data is collected as events occur, reducing reliance on participants' memories.

choices.text: Superior layer of coronary ligament
Hepatoduodenal portion of the lesser omentum

questions.text: During an abdominal surgery, the surgeon needs to access the omental bursa to address a posterior gastric ulcer. To avoid damaging the structures entering the porta hepatis and the blood vessels supplying the stomach, which of the following structures should be incised?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transverse mesocolon

 

  • The omental bursa, also known as the lesser sac, is a potential space in the abdominal cavity behind the stomach.
  • Accessing this space is necessary in some surgical procedures, such as addressing posterior gastric ulcers or in pancreatic surgery.
  • The transverse mesocolon is the structure that attaches the transverse colon to the posterior abdominal wall.
  • By incising the transverse mesocolon, the surgeon can safely enter the omental bursa without risking injury to the structures in the porta hepatis or the blood vessels that supply the stomach.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior layer of coronary ligament: This ligament is involved in the attachment of the liver to the diaphragm and does not provide direct access to the omental bursa.

 

Option B. Falciform ligament: This ligament connects the anterior part of the liver to the anterior abdominal wall and diaphragm. Incising this structure would not provide access to the omental bursa and would risk damaging the liver.

 

Option D. Hepatoduodenal portion of the lesser omentum: This structure contains important vessels like the portal vein, hepatic artery, and bile duct. Incising here could risk significant vascular injury and would not be the preferred approach to accessing the omental bursa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To access the omental bursa during surgery while avoiding damage to vital structures, the transverse mesocolon is the safest structure to incise.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with complaints of fatigue, joint pain and darkening of his skin that has persisted despite avoiding sun exposure. On physical examination, he is noted to have hepatomegaly and hyperpigmented skin. Laboratory tests reveal elevated serum ferritin and transferrin saturation. A liver biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Which type of cardiomyopathy is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dilated cardiomyopathy

 

  • The patients presentation of hepatomegaly, skin hyperpigmentation, and elevated iron levels is consistent with hereditary hemochromatosis, a condition characterized by excessive iron accumulation in various organs, including the liver, heart and pancreas.
  • The histopathological image of the liver shows iron deposition, stained with perls Prussian blue which is indicative of this condition.
  • In hereditary hemochromatosis, iron overload can lead to dilated cardiomyopathy, the most common form of cardiomyopathy associated with this disease.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy results from iron deposition in the myocardium, leading to impaired contractility and heart failure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Restrictive cardiomyopathy: Although restrictive cardiomyopathy can be seen in conditions with infiltrative processes, it is has lower prevalence in comparison to dilated cardiomyopathy.

 

Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: This is most commonly due to genetic mutations affecting sarcomeric proteins and is characterized by asymmetric septal hypertrophy, not typically seen in hemochromatosis.

 

Option D. Arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy: This type of cardiomyopathy is characterized by fibrofatty replacement of the right ventricular myocardium, leading to arrhythmias. It is unrelated to iron overload conditions like hemochromatosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In hereditary hemochromatosis, excessive iron deposition in the heart often leads to dilated cardiomyopathy, characterized by an enlarged and weakened heart muscle.
  • This is the most common type of cardiomyopathy associated with iron overload disorders.

 

This is classic for Hereditary Hemochromatosis an iron overload disorder, usually due to HFE gene mutations.

 

Common features:

 

  • "Bronze diabetes" diabetes + skin hyperpigmentation
  • Hepatomegaly / cirrhosis
  • Arthropathy
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Associated Cardiomyopathy:
  • In hemochromatosis, iron deposits in the myocardium can lead to:
  • Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM)
  • The most common cardiac manifestation.
  • Iron overload myocyte injury impaired contractility ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the neurology clinic with complaints of difficulty in performing tasks that require coordination between her vision and hand movements, such as reaching for objects and writing. She also reports that she frequently misjudges the position of objects in space. A neurological examination suggests a lesion in her brain. Which of the following lobes is most likely affected, leading to her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parietal lobe

 

  • The parietal lobe is primarily responsible for integrating sensory information from different modalities, particularly spatial sense and navigation.
  • It plays a crucial role in coordinating visual information with motor actions, which is essential for hand-eye coordination.
  • A lesion in the parietal lobe can impair the brain's ability to process spatial relationships and coordinate hand movements with visual input, leading to difficulty with tasks that require precise hand-eye coordination, such as reaching for or accurately positioning objects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Frontal lobe: The frontal lobe is involved in decision-making, problem-solving, and motor function but is not specifically responsible for integrating visual and motor information for hand-eye coordination.

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: The occipital lobe is the primary visual processing center of the brain. While it is crucial for visual perception, it does not integrate this information with motor functions necessary for hand-eye coordination.

 

Option C. Temporal lobe: The temporal lobe is involved in auditory processing, memory, and language comprehension. It does not play a significant role in hand-eye coordination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The parietal lobe is essential for integrating sensory input with motor functions, particularly for tasks requiring hand-eye coordination.
  • A lesion in this lobe can result in significant difficulties with spatial awareness and coordinated movements.Top of Form

questions.text: A public health official is tasked with designing a system to most accurately measure the true morbidity of a chronic disease within a specific urban population. Considering the need for high accuracy in data collection and reporting, which of the following surveillance methods would provide the most reliable information?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sentinel surveillance

 

  • Sentinel surveillance involves selected healthcare providers or institutions reporting specific health conditions.
  • This method is designed to provide detailed and accurate data on morbidity trends within a population, particularly for diseases that are difficult to track comprehensively.
  • It is useful for understanding the true morbidity in a monitored population or for specific diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Active surveillance: While active surveillance is proactive and comprehensive, it is more resource-intensive and may not be as targeted as sentinel surveillance.

 

Option B. Passive surveillance: Relies on voluntary reporting, which can lead to underreporting and less accurate morbidity data.

 

Option D. Continuous surveillance: This term broadly refers to ongoing monitoring but does not inherently ensure accuracy in measuring true morbidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sentinel surveillance is an effective method for measuring true morbidity, providing detailed data from selected sites or groups, which can give an accurate picture of disease trends in a population.

choices.text: Vaginal examination for cervical dilatation

questions.text: A 21-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman with a history of a previous preterm delivery presents at 32 weeks of gestation with complaints of abdominal pain. Which of the following is the most definitive method to confirm that she is in preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vaginal examination for cervical dilatation

  

  • The most definitive way to confirm preterm labor is by performing a vaginal examination to assess cervical dilatation.
  • Preterm labor is diagnosed when there are regular uterine contractions accompanied by cervical changes, specifically cervical dilatation of 3 cm or more, or significant effacement before 37 weeks of gestation.
  • This method directly evaluates the physical changes in the cervix, which is the primary determinant of labor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fetal fibronectin: While the presence of fetal fibronectin in cervico-vaginal secretions can indicate an increased risk of preterm delivery, it is not definitive for diagnosing active preterm labor. It is more of a predictive test rather than a diagnostic one.

 

Option B. Tocography: Tocography measures uterine contractions but does not provide information about cervical changes. Contractions alone are not sufficient to confirm preterm labor unless they are associated with cervical dilatation.

 

Option D. Cervical length on ultrasound: Measuring cervical length via ultrasound can help assess the risk of preterm labor, particularly if the cervix is shortened. However, it does not confirm that labor is occurring at the moment; it is more predictive than diagnostic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most definitive method to confirm preterm labor is by assessing cervical changes through a vaginal examination, specifically looking for cervical dilatation or effacement in the presence of regular uterine contractions.

choices.text: The sample should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius
The sample should be incubated at 37 degrees Celsius
The sample should be kept in the deep freezer
The sample should be refrigerated for the initial 3 hours and then incubated

questions.text: After collecting a vitreous sample from a patient during the evening, you need to instruct the lab staff on the best way to store the sample overnight before analysis. Which of the following is the most appropriate storage method?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The sample should be stored at 4 degrees Celsius

 

  • Refrigerating the vitreous sample at 4 degrees Celsius is crucial for slowing down bacterial growth and enzymatic processes that could degrade the sample.
  • This method ensures that the chemical and cellular components of the vitreous are preserved, maintaining its integrity for accurate diagnostic results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The sample should be incubated at 37 degrees Celsius: This is inappropriate as it could encourage bacterial growth and potentially alter the sample's properties.

 

Option C. The sample should be kept in the deep freezer: Freezing can damage some cellular components, making it less suitable for immediate testing needs unless specific long-term preservation is required.

 

Option D. The sample should be refrigerated for the initial 3 hours and then incubated: This inconsistent approach could lead to unpredictable changes in the sample, compromising the diagnostic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Correct storage conditions are essential for the preservation of biological samples.
  • For vitreous samples intended for short-term analysis, maintaining a consistent refrigeration temperature of 4 degrees Celsius is generally the best practice to ensure sample integrity and reliability of subsequent laboratory tests.

choices.text: Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding, and prevent infection

questions.text: Which of the following are components of Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC)?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

 

  • These are the key components of Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).
  • KMC involves holding the baby in skin-to-skin contact, usually on the mother's chest, which helps regulate the baby's body temperature and breathing.
  •  Exclusive breastfeeding is encouraged to provide the baby with essential nutrients and antibodies.
  • Early discharge and ambulatory care support the continuation of KMC outside the hospital environment, allowing the mother to care for her baby at home while still receiving necessary medical follow-up.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, prevent infection: While skin-to-skin contact and early discharge are essential parts of KMC, preventing infection is not listed as one of the core components of KMC. Instead, infection prevention is a broader aspect of neonatal care, especially in low birthweight or preterm infants.

 

Option C. Skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection: Skin-to-skin contact and exclusive breastfeeding are indeed components of KMC. However, preventing infection, although crucial in neonatal care, is not considered a primary component of KMC. KMC focuses more on the skin-to-skin method, feeding and early discharge rather than infection prevention.

 

Option D. Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding, and prevent infection: This option includes early discharge and exclusive breastfeeding, which are components of KMC, but it incorrectly lists infection prevention instead of skin-to-skin contact. The correct components focus on the physical contact between mother and baby, which is central to the practice of KMC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) involves early discharge, skin-to-skin contact between the mother and baby, and exclusive breastfeeding.
  • These practices are essential for the care and development of low birthweight and preterm infants.
  •  KMC not only helps stabilize the infant's physiological parameters but also strengthens the mother-baby bond and supports breastfeeding.
  • Understanding these components is vital for optimizing neonatal care and promoting early discharge with ongoing support.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency with flame burns. On clinical evaluation there were deep burns involving the left upper limb, the right upper limb and the anterior aspect of chest and abdomen. How much percentage of burns would it be classified as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36%

 

  • 36% is the correct classification of the burn percentage in this patient based on the Rule of Nines, which is a method used to estimate the total body surface area (TBSA) affected by burns. According to the Rule of Nines:
  • Each upper limb (left and right) accounts for 9% of the TBSA.
  • The anterior aspect of the chest and abdomen together account for 18% of the TBSA.

 

Therefore, the total percentage of burns in this patient is calculated as:

 

  • 9% (left upper limb) + 9% (right upper limb) + 18% (anterior chest and abdomen) = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rule of Nines is used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns. In this case, burns involving both upper limbs and the anterior chest and abdomen account for 36% of the total body surface area.

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler every day to check for reversion

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents at 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation with concerns about her pregnancy. An ultrasound reveals an amniotic fluid index (AFI) of 5 and absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler assessment. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Immediate termination

  

  • Absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery on Doppler ultrasound is a significant finding that indicates compromised placental function and poor fetal blood flow, which can lead to fetal hypoxia and acidosis.
  • When this finding is associated with an AFI of 5 (indicating oligohydramnios), it suggests that the fetus is at significant risk.
  • Immediate delivery is recommended to prevent fetal demise or other severe complications, particularly when the pregnancy is beyond 34 weeks, where fetal lung maturity is likely adequate for survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks: While surfactant may be beneficial in promoting lung maturity in preterm infants, waiting in this scenario with absent end-diastolic flow poses a high risk of fetal compromise or death. Immediate action is necessary.

 

Option B. Terminate after 37 weeks: Delaying termination until after 37 weeks is not appropriate given the significant risk to the fetus from absent end-diastolic flow. Waiting could lead to stillbirth or other severe complications.

 

Option C. Do Doppler every day to check for reversion: Daily Doppler assessments may be useful in certain high-risk pregnancies, but in the presence of absent end-diastolic flow and oligohydramnios, the immediate concern is fetal well-being, and the priority should be delivery rather than waiting for potential reversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absent end-diastolic flow in the umbilical artery with oligohydramnios in a pregnancy beyond 34 weeks is a critical finding that typically necessitates immediate delivery to prevent serious fetal complications or death.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure is admitted to the hospital for worsening dyspnea and lower extremity edema. The physician suspects significant fluid retention and orders a test involving the administration of I-125 labelled albumin to measure his body fluid compartments accurately. Which of the following body fluid compartments is being measured with this technique?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plasma volume

 

  • Iodine-125 (I-125) labeled albumin is specifically used to measure plasma volume.
  • Albumin, being a large protein, is confined to the intravascular space and does not cross into the interstitial or intracellular compartments.
  • When tagged with the radioactive isotope I-125, albumin allows for precise measurement of plasma volume by detecting the distribution of the isotope within the blood.
  • This measurement is particularly useful in clinical scenarios like congestive heart failure, where fluid status needs careful assessment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interstitial fluid volume: This refers to the fluid between cells within the extracellular space, which is not measured by I-125 labeled albumin since albumin remains in the plasma.

 

Option B. Intracellular fluid (ICF): The intracellular fluid is inside cells, and albumin cannot penetrate cell membranes to enter this compartment, so I-125 labeled albumin does not measure ICF.

 

Option C. Extracellular fluid (ECF): The ECF includes both plasma and interstitial fluid. However, I-125 labeled albumin is specifically used to measure the plasma portion, not the entire ECF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • I-125 labeled albumin is used to measure plasma volume accurately because albumin stays within the intravascular compartment, making it ideal for assessing the plasma component of the extracellular fluid.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man with a 5-year history of ulcerative colitis is hospitalized due to a 1-week history of fever, tenesmus, diffuse abdominal pain, and 12 daily episodes of bloody diarrhea despite oral glucocorticoid treatment. Stool cultures and Clostridioides difficile assays are negative. He does not improve with intravenous glucocorticoid therapy. What is the most appropriate treatment to induce and maintain remission?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infliximab

 

  • This patient is experiencing a severe flare of ulcerative colitis unresponsive to glucocorticoid therapy.
  • The tumor necrosis factor (TNF) inhibitor infliximab is appropriate to induce and maintain remission in this situation.
  • TNF inhibitors are effective in treating severe ulcerative colitis, especially when glucocorticoids fail. Infliximab can rapidly reduce symptoms and is suitable for both induction and maintenance therapy in severe cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Azathioprine: Effective for maintenance therapy but not for inducing remission in severe ulcerative colitis.

 

Option C. Tofacitinib: A Janus kinase inhibitor used for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, often after anti-TNF agents like infliximab have failed.

 

Option D. Vedolizumab: Another agent used for inducing and maintaining remission, particularly after failure of TNF inhibitors, but infliximab is typically used first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with severe ulcerative colitis who do not respond to glucocorticoids, TNF inhibitors like infliximab are recommended to induce and maintain remission.
  • Azathioprine is not effective for induction and is reserved for maintenance therapy, while tofacitinib and vedolizumab are generally used after TNF inhibitors if further treatment is needed.

choices.text: 12-14 years
13-15 years
17-18 years
> 19 years

questions.text: During the investigation of a homicide case, a forensic expert analyzes an X-ray of the pelvis from the deceased to help establish the victim's age at the time of death. The X-ray image is shown below. what is the most likely age range of the deceased?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 17-18 years

 

  • Head, greater trochanter, and lesser trochanter are all fused with the shaft of femur (so age > 17 years)
  • Iliac crest is not yet fused (so age < 18 years)
  • Hence, age is 17-18 years.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with a history of renal impairment is being treated for a severe bacterial infection with a carbapenem antibiotic. Which of the following carbapenems is associated with the highest risk of inducing seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Imipenem

 

  • Imipenem is known to carry the highest risk of inducing seizures, particularly in patients with renal impairment or pre-existing neurological conditions.
  • This is due to its ability to lower the seizure threshold, especially when dosages are not adjusted for renal function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meropenem: Meropenem has a lower risk of seizures compared to imipenem, making it a safer alternative in patients at risk of seizures.

 

Option C. Ertapenem: Ertapenem is associated with a lower incidence of seizures and is not typically implicated in increasing seizure risk.

 

Option D. Doripenem: Doripenem also has a lower seizure risk compared to imipenem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Imipenem is the carbapenem with the highest risk of inducing seizures, particularly in patients with renal impairment or neurological conditions, and requires careful dosing adjustments.

choices.text: Due to toxin secretion by streptococci

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of fever, joint pain, and a new heart murmur. He recently recovered from a sore throat caused by a group A streptococcal infection. Based on his clinical presentation, acute rheumatic fever is suspected. The pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever involves which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cross-reactivity with antigen

 

  • Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) is an autoimmune inflammatory disease that occurs after an infection with group A Streptococcus (GAS).
  • The pathogenesis involves molecular mimicry, where the body's immune response to streptococcal M proteins cross-reacts with human tissues, particularly the heart, joints, skin and central nervous system.
  • This cross-reactivity leads to the development of carditis, arthritis and other manifestations of ARF.
  • The immune system mistakenly attacks host tissues, thinking they are the foreign antigen, which leads to the clinical features of the disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Innocent bystander effect: This refers to tissue damage caused by immune cells targeting a pathogen, leading to collateral damage to surrounding tissues. It is not the primary mechanism in the development of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option C. Release of pyrogenic cytokines: While cytokines play a role in the inflammatory response, the specific mechanism of ARF is not primarily driven by cytokine release but by molecular mimicry and cross-reactivity.

 

Option D. Due to toxin secretion by streptococci: Toxins produced by streptococci, such as streptolysins and exotoxins, can cause direct tissue damage, but they are not responsible for the autoimmune process seen in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A Group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection (especially pharyngitis) triggers the immune response.
  • The immune system generates antibodies against streptococcal M protein.
  • These antibodies cross-react with host antigens, particularly:
  • Myocardial tissue (causing carditis)
  • Joint tissue (causing migratory arthritis)
  • Basal ganglia (Sydenham chorea)
  • The pathogenesis of acute rheumatic fever involves molecular mimicry, where the immune response to streptococcal M protein cross-reacts with host tissues, leading to an autoimmune response.
  • This cross-reactivity is the key mechanism that causes the inflammatory symptoms of ARF, including carditis, arthritis and other systemic manifestations.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman undergoes an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy for symptomatic cholelithiasis. Which of the following wound classes best describes this surgical procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Class II, Clean/contaminated

 

  • Clean/contaminated wounds involve surgeries where the respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions and without unusual contamination.
  • An elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy involves entry into the gastrointestinal tract (the gallbladder), but there is no active infection or significant spillage of contents, classifying it as a clean/contaminated wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I, Clean: Clean wounds are those in which no part of the respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary tracts is entered, and there is no break in sterile technique. Examples include procedures like hernia repair and breast surgery. This classification does not apply to a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, as the gastrointestinal tract is entered.

 

Option C. Class III, contaminated: Contaminated wounds involve gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract, fresh open accidental wounds, or operations with major breaks in sterile technique. This would be applicable in cases such as penetrating abdominal trauma or enterotomy during bowel obstruction, which do not apply to this elective, controlled procedure.

 

Option D.  Class IV, Dirty: Dirty wounds include those with existing clinical infection, necrotic tissue, or those created in the presence of purulent material. Examples include wounds with perforated diverticulitis or necrotizing soft tissue infections. This category is not relevant to an elective cholecystectomy without signs of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Class II, Clean/contaminated wounds involve surgical procedures where the respiratory, gastrointestinal, or genitourinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions without unusual contamination.
  • Recognizing the classification of surgical wounds is important for predicting the risk of postoperative infection and for guiding prophylactic antibiotic use and wound management strategies.

questions.text: A block medical officer is tasked with deciding whether to implement a mass azithromycin treatment program in his rural area showing signs of trachoma transmission. According to international health guidelines, mass treatment with azithromycin is recommended in a community when the prevalence of trachoma among children aged 1-9 years exceeds what percentage?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 10%

 

  • According to WHO guidelines, mass treatment with Azithromycin is recommended when the prevalence of trachoma in children aged 1-9 years is greater than 10%.
  • This threshold is used to help control the spread of trachoma in endemic areas as part of the SAFE strategy.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Current WHO recommendations for antibiotic treatment of trachoma:
    • District level prevalence is > 10% in 1-9 years old children: Mass treatment with Azithromycin
    • District level prevalence is 5-10% in 1-9 years old children: Targeted treatment with Azithromycin (the identification and treatment of all members of any family in whom one or more members have follicular trachoma)
    • District level prevalence is < 5% in 1-9 years old children: Azithromycin distribution may not be necessary

questions.text: Laxative abuse is commonly associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

  • Laxative abuse leads to excessive loss of water and electrolytes, particularly potassium, through the gastrointestinal tract.
  • This can result in hypokalemia, which is one of the most common complications associated with chronic laxative abuse.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomagnesemia: While electrolyte imbalances are common in laxative abuse, hypokalemia is more typical than hypomagnesemia.

 

Option C. Hypoglycemia: Hypoglycemia is not associated with laxative abuse. Laxative abuse primarily affects electrolyte balance rather than blood glucose levels.

 

Option D. Colonic spasticity: Chronic laxative abuse can lead to colonic inertia rather than spasticity, where the colon becomes less responsive to natural stimuli for defecation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Laxative abuse is primarily associated with hypokalemia due to the excessive loss of potassium through the gastrointestinal tract, leading to significant electrolyte imbalances.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman, who has remarried after the death of her first husband, presents to the gynecology OPD with a complaint of inability to conceive after trying for one year. She has a history of a dilation and curettage (D&C) procedure for a missed abortion with her first husband. Her menstrual cycles are regular, and a pelvic ultrasound is normal. Her husband's semen analysis is also normal. What is the next best step in the management of her infertility?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Laparoscopy with chromopertubation

  

  • Given the patient’s history of a dilation and curettage (D&C) for a missed abortion, there is a possibility of intrauterine adhesions (Asherman’s syndrome) or tubal factor infertility.
  • Laparoscopy with chromopertubation is the most appropriate next step as it allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs, assessment of tubal patency, and identification of any pelvic pathology that might be causing infertility, such as adhesions or endometriosis.
  • Chromopertubation involves the injection of dye through the cervix to check if the fallopian tubes are open.
  • This procedure is critical in cases where other evaluations, such as ultrasound and semen analysis, are normal but infertility persists.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IVF: In vitro fertilization (IVF) is a more advanced treatment option that is typically considered after less invasive options have been explored or if there is a specific indication for it. IVF would not be the first-line management in this scenario without further diagnostic evaluation.

 

Option B. Ovulation Induction: Ovulation induction is used in women with ovulatory disorders. However, this patient has regular periods, which suggests she is ovulating normally. Therefore, ovulation induction is not indicated at this point.

 

Option C. Endometrial biopsy: An endometrial biopsy can be used to evaluate the endometrium, typically for suspected chronic endometritis or endometrial pathology. However, it is not the first step in the evaluation of infertility, especially when the history suggests a possible tubal or uterine factor that could be assessed with laparoscopy and chromopertubation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a patient with a history of D&C and unexplained infertility, laparoscopy with chromopertubation is the next best step to evaluate for possible intrauterine adhesions, tubal factor infertility, or other pelvic pathology that could be contributing to her difficulty conceiving.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with peripheral artery disease (PAD) experiences left calf pain that limits walking. She recently completed an exercise rehabilitation program with minimal improvement. She also has hyperlipidemia and is currently taking aspirin and atorvastatin. Her left femoral, popliteal, ankle, and pedal pulses are diminished. Transthoracic echocardiography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55%. What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cilostazol

 

  • Cilostazol is the most appropriate additional treatment for this patient with peripheral artery disease and lifestyle-limiting claudication, particularly when exercise therapy alone has not sufficiently improved symptoms.
  • Cilostazol, a phosphodiesterase inhibitor with antiplatelet and vasodilatory effects, has been shown to improve walking distance and reduce claudication symptoms.
  • It is contraindicated in patients with heart failure, but given this patient's preserved ejection fraction, cilostazol is safe and recommended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pentoxifylline: This medication has not been shown to be beneficial in treating PAD and is not recommended.

 

Option C. Ticagrelor: While effective in acute coronary syndrome, it has no added benefit in PAD when combined with aspirin.

 

Option D. Warfarin or rivaroxaban: Anticoagulation therapy is not recommended in PAD without other specific indications, as it does not provide added benefit and increases bleeding risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with PAD and lifestyle-limiting claudication, cilostazol is recommended to improve walking distance and reduce symptoms, provided there is no heart failure.
  • Other medications like pentoxifylline and anticoagulants are not beneficial in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is characterized by time-dependent killing and a prolonged post-antibiotic effect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Beta-lactams

 

  • Beta-lactams, such as penicillins and cephalosporins, exhibit time-dependent killing.
  • Their effectiveness depends on maintaining drug levels above the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) for a prolonged period.
  • Some beta-lactams also demonstrate a prolonged post-antibiotic effect, particularly against Gram-positive bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolones exhibit concentration-dependent killing rather than time-dependent killing. They also have a prolonged post-antibiotic effect but are not primarily classified under time-dependent antibiotics.

 

Option C. Clindamycin: Clindamycin also relies on time-dependent killing, but it is less associated with a prolonged post-antibiotic effect compared to beta-lactams.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: Erythromycin, a macrolide, exhibits time-dependent killing but does not typically have a significant post-antibiotic effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beta-lactams are time-dependent antibiotics that require prolonged exposure above the MIC for optimal effectiveness and can exhibit a prolonged post-antibiotic effect, particularly against Gram-positive organisms.

choices.text: Cessation of calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum
Dissociation of ADP and Pi from the myosin head
Attachment of ATP to the myosin head

questions.text: Which of the following events in the muscle contraction process is primarily responsible for the detachment of myosin from actin filaments, allowing the muscle to relax?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Attachment of ATP to the myosin head

 

  • During muscle contraction, the attachment and detachment of myosin to and from actin are crucial for the sliding filament mechanism.
  • After the power stroke, where myosin pulls actin, the myosin head remains attached to the actin filament until a new ATP molecule binds to the myosin head.
  • The binding of ATP causes a conformational change in the myosin head, leading to the detachment of myosin from actin.
  • This is essential for the continuation of the contraction cycle, allowing the myosin to reset and attach to a new site on the actin filament for the next contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conformational change in Troponin T: This occurs in response to calcium binding to troponin C, which then moves tropomyosin away from the actin binding sites, allowing myosin to attach to actin, but it does not cause the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Option B. Cessation of calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum: The cessation of calcium release leads to muscle relaxation by allowing calcium to be re-sequestered in the sarcoplasmic reticulum, which prevents further actin-myosin interaction, but this process does not directly cause myosin detachment from actin.

 

Option C. Dissociation of ADP and Pi from the myosin head: This event occurs during the power stroke, leading to the movement of the actin filament but does not cause the detachment of myosin from actin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The attachment of ATP to the myosin head is critical for the detachment of myosin from actin during the muscle contraction cycle, enabling the muscle to relax and prepare for the next contraction.

choices.text: Double the current dose of antiepileptic drugs
Switch to a different class of antiepileptic drugs
Monitor serum levels of antiepileptic drugs and adjust dosage accordingly

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman with a history of epilepsy presents to the clinic reporting an increase in the frequency of her seizures. She is concerned about the potential effects on her pregnancy. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Monitor serum levels of antiepileptic drugs and adjust dosage accordingly

  

  • In pregnant women with epilepsy, it is crucial to maintain seizure control while minimizing risks to both the mother and the fetus.
  •  Pregnancy can alter the pharmacokinetics of antiepileptic drugs (AEDs), often resulting in lower serum drug levels due to increased volume of distribution and faster drug metabolism.
  • Therefore, the appropriate next step is to monitor serum levels of antiepileptic drugs and adjust the dosage accordingly.
  •  This approach allows for tailored management that maintains therapeutic drug levels and seizure control, reducing the risk of both maternal seizures and fetal harm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Double the current dose of antiepileptic drugs: Automatically doubling the dose without first checking serum levels could lead to unnecessarily high drug levels, which might increase the risk of toxicity or adverse effects for both the mother and the fetus. Dosage adjustments should be based on monitoring and clinical response, not a predetermined increase.

 

Option B. Discontinue antiepileptic drugs: Discontinuing AEDs in a pregnant woman with epilepsy is not appropriate, as it could lead to uncontrolled seizures, which pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus. Seizure control is paramount during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Switch to a different class of antiepileptic drugs: Switching AEDs during pregnancy is generally not recommended unless the current drug is clearly ineffective or has intolerable side effects. Changing the medication can destabilize seizure control, and many AEDs have specific risks associated with pregnancy, making careful consideration essential.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In pregnant women with epilepsy experiencing increased seizure frequency, the most appropriate step is to monitor serum levels of antiepileptic drugs and adjust the dosage accordingly.
  • This ensures that therapeutic levels are maintained, minimizing the risk of seizures and potential harm to both the mother and the fetus.

questions.text:
A public health consultant is reviewing historical data on the decline of tuberculosis in the early 20th century for a health policy development session. The focus is on understanding the primary drivers behind the reduction in disease prevalence to inform current health strategies.

 

Based on McKeown’s Theory, which of the following is most likely the primary contributor to the significant reduction in tuberculosis prevalence observed during the early 20th century?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Social and environmental factors

 

  • McKeown’s Theory suggests that the reduction in the prevalence of diseases like tuberculosis is primarily due to improvements in social and environmental conditions, such as better nutrition, improved living standards, and sanitation, rather than direct medical interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enhanced knowledge and awareness: While increased knowledge and awareness are important, McKeown’s Theory emphasizes social and environmental changes as the key drivers of disease reduction.

 

Option B. Medical advancements: McKeown argued that medical interventions, while important, were not the primary cause of the reduction in tuberculosis prevalence historically.

 

Option C. Behavioral modification: Changes in behavior are significant, but McKeown’s Theory highlights broader social determinants.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • McKeown’s Theory posits that the reduction in the prevalence of diseases like tuberculosis is largely due to improvements in social and environmental conditions, rather than medical advancements alone.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient with tuberculosis is found to have rifampicin-resistant Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Which of the following gene mutations is responsible for rifampicin resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) RpoB

 

  • Rifampicin resistance in Mycobacterium tuberculosis is primarily due to mutations in the RpoB gene, which encodes the β subunit of RNA polymerase.
  • These mutations alter the binding site of rifampicin, reducing the drug's efficacy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EpoA: This is not associated with rifampicin resistance.

 

Option B. EpoRf: This is not associated with rifampicin resistance.

 

Option C. RpoA: The RpoA gene encodes the α subunit of RNA polymerase, but mutations here are not responsible for rifampicin resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rifampicin resistance in tuberculosis is primarily caused by mutations in the RpoB gene, which encodes the β subunit of RNA polymerase, leading to altered drug binding and reduced efficacy.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the clinic with diarrhea and blood in his stool. A stool sample microscopy shows below. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Entamoeba histolytica

 

  • Entamoeba histolytica is known for its ability to ingest red blood cells (RBCs), a key diagnostic feature that distinguishes it from other similar amoebae.
  • This ability is associated with its pathogenicity, causing amoebic dysentery and liver abscesses.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Entamoeba dispar:  This amoeba is morphologically similar to E. histolytica but does not ingest RBCs and is generally non-pathogenic.

 

Option C. Balantidium coli:  Although a ciliate and not an amoeba, it can cause dysentery similar to amoebiasis. It may ingest cells and debris but is less commonly associated with RBC ingestion than E. histolytica.

 

Option D. Entamoeba moshkovskii:  Similar to E. dispar, it is often indistinguishable from E. histolytica under a microscope but is typically non-pathogenic and does not ingest RBCs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of amoebae ingesting RBCs in a stool sample is indicative of infection with Entamoeba histolytica, a significant cause of amoebic dysentery and systemic amoebiasis, warranting prompt diagnosis and treatment.

choices.text: Transurethral resection of the prostate

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is evaluated for urinary frequency and urgency despite taking tamsulosin for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). He has no other medical problems. On examination, the prostate is modestly enlarged, smooth, and nontender. Urinalysis and PSA levels are normal. Urodynamic studies and postvoid bladder volume determined by ultrasonography exclude bladder outlet obstruction. What is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Tolterodine

 

  • This patient likely has overactive bladder (OAB), which can cause urinary frequency and urgency even when BPH is treated.
  • Tolterodine is an anticholinergic medication that can be added to an α-blocker like tamsulosin to help manage OAB symptoms by reducing involuntary detrusor contractions.
  • The absence of significant postvoid residual urine makes it safe to use an anticholinergic agent in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tadalafil: This medication can be useful for both BPH and erectile dysfunction but is not the preferred add-on therapy in the absence of erectile dysfunction. Additionally, caution is needed when combining it with α-blockers due to the risk of hypotension.

 

Option B. Testosterone gel: This treatment can worsen BPH and is not indicated for urinary symptoms.

 

Option D. Transurethral resection of the prostate: Indicated for obstructive symptoms or complications of BPH, not for irritative symptoms like those this patient is experiencing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with persistent urinary symptoms despite treatment for BPH, particularly when bladder outlet obstruction is excluded, adding an anticholinergic agent like tolterodine is appropriate to manage overactive bladder symptoms.

choices.text: Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock
Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with severe brain injury exhibits decerebrate posturing. According to the Herrington classification of decerebrate rigidity, which of the following is NOT a characteristic of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body

 

  • According to the Herrington classification of decerebrate rigidity, decerebrate rigidity is primarily characterized by a specific posture resulting from severe brain injury, typically involving the brainstem.
  • It involves extensor rigidity of the limbs due to the loss of inhibitory control from the higher brain centers.
  • However, rigidity does not occur in all the muscles of the body; it mainly affects the extensor muscles of the limbs.
  • The characteristic posture includes extension and internal rotation of the arms, extension of the legs, and plantar flexion of the feet.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock: This is true. Unlike spinal cord injury that can cause spinal shock, decerebrate rigidity does not produce an analogous phenomenon. Decerebrate rigidity involves hyperactivity in motor pathways due to the loss of descending inhibitory control.

 

Option C. Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool: This is correct. The increased excitability of the motor neuron pool is a characteristic feature of decerebrate rigidity, where motor neurons become hyperactive due to the loss of upper motor neuron inhibition.

 

Option D. Increase in the rate of discharge of the γ efferent neuron: This is correct. There is an increased rate of discharge in γ efferent neurons, which contributes to the heightened muscle tone observed in decerebrate rigidity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Decerebrate rigidity, according to the Herrington classification, is characterized by increased muscle tone primarily in the extensor muscles of the limbs, not all muscles of the body.
  • This condition results from the loss of descending inhibitory signals from the brain to the spinal cord, leading to hyperactivity in motor pathways and increased discharge of γ efferent neurons.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with difficulty swallowing and hoarseness. On examination, the physician notes that his uvula deviates to the left when he says "ahhh," as shown in the image below. Which of the following nerve injuries is most likely responsible for this uvular deviation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right vagus nerve

 

  • The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is responsible for innervating the muscles of the soft palate, including the levator veli palatini, which elevates the soft palate during phonation.
  • If the vagus nerve on one side is damaged, the muscles on that side become weak or paralyzed, causing the uvula to deviate toward the unaffected side.
  • In this case, the uvula deviates to the left, indicating that the right vagus nerve is injured.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left vagus nerve: If the left vagus nerve were injured, the uvula would deviate to the right, not to the left as shown in the image.

 

Option B. Right glossopharyngeal nerve: The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is primarily involved in sensory innervation of the oropharynx and the posterior third of the tongue. It does not cause uvular deviation when injured.

 

Option D. Left glossopharyngeal nerve: Similar to the right glossopharyngeal nerve, injury to the left glossopharyngeal nerve does not cause uvular deviation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Uvula deviation occurs toward the side opposite a vagus nerve lesion.
  • In this case, deviation to the left indicates a lesion of the right vagus nerve.

choices.text: No further testing or treatment

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine wellness visit. She has never been tested for HIV infection, is asymptomatic, and reports no known risk factors for HIV. Physical examination findings, including vital signs, are normal. HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay is reactive. Subsequent HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay is negative, as is the result of HIV-1 nucleic acid amplification testing. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) No further testing or treatment

 

  • Under the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) guidelines, HIV testing begins with a screening test, typically an HIV antigen/antibody combination assay.
  • If this test is reactive, it is followed by confirmatory testing, such as an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation test and HIV nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) if needed.
  • In this case, the initial reactive result was followed by negative confirmatory tests, indicating a false positive in the initial screening. Given the low likelihood of HIV infection, especially in an asymptomatic individual with no known risk factors, no further testing or treatment is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiation of HIV therapy: Unnecessary because the confirmatory tests were negative, indicating no HIV infection.

 

Option B. T-cell subset testing: Not used for diagnosing HIV infection; it is used in managing confirmed cases to assess immune status.

 

Option C. Viral load testing: Not appropriate when there is no evidence of HIV infection based on confirmatory testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • According to NACO guidelines, when HIV confirmatory tests are negative following an initial reactive screening test, no further testing or treatment is required. The initial reactive result is likely a false positive, and the patient should be reassured.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic liver disease presents with dark urine and fatigue. Urinalysis shows the presence of specific types of casts. Which of the following types of casts is most likely to be associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bile

 

  • Cholemic nephrosis, also known as bile nephrosis, is a renal condition that occurs in patients with severe jaundice or liver dysfunction, often due to chronic liver disease.
  • The excessive buildup of bilirubin in the blood, secondary to hepatic dysfunction, can result in its deposition in the kidneys. This leads to the formation of bile casts in the renal tubules, which can be detected on urinalysis.
  • In this case, the patient has a known history of chronic liver disease, and the presentation of dark urine suggests significant hyperbilirubinemia. The image provided is consistent with the presence of bile casts in the urine. Bile casts appear as yellowish or brownish granular casts, which can be confirmed under a microscope, as seen in the image.
  • Bile casts are specific to cholemic nephrosis and their presence supports the diagnosis of a renal complication due to severe liver disease, making "Bile" the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyaline: Hyaline casts are the most commonly found casts in urine and are often nonspecific. They can be seen in a variety of conditions, including dehydration, vigorous exercise, or diuretic use, but are not specifically associated with cholemic nephrosis.

 

Option B. Lipids: Lipid casts are typically seen in conditions like nephrotic syndrome, where there is significant proteinuria and hyperlipidemia. They are not related to the accumulation of bile in the kidneys.

 

Option C. Cholesterol: Cholesterol casts are generally found in cases of lipiduria and are more common in nephrotic syndrome or in conditions with glomerular disease. They do not correlate with cholemic nephrosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cholemic nephrosis is associated with the presence of bile casts in the urine, which occurs due to the accumulation of bile in the renal tubules in the setting of severe jaundice or liver failure.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female presents with hypertension and diminished pulses in her lower extremities. Physical examination reveals a significant difference in blood pressure between her upper and lower extremities. An echocardiogram confirms post-ductal coarctation of the aorta. Which of the following arteries is not involved in collateral circulation in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral Artery

 

  • In post-ductal coarctation of the aorta, collateral circulation develops to bypass the narrowed segment.
  • The main arteries involved in this collateral circulation include the subclavian, axillary, and intercostal arteries, as well as the scapular branches such as the suprascapular artery.
  • The vertebral artery, however, is not typically involved in this collateral network.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suprascapular Artery: This artery is involved in collateral circulation as it contributes to the network of arteries supplying blood to bypass the coarctation.

 

Option B. Axillary Artery: This artery is a major participant in the collateral circulation around a coarctation of the aorta, providing alternative pathways for blood flow.

 

Option D. Posterior Intercostal Artery: These arteries are significantly involved in collateral circulation in cases of aortic coarctation, helping to bypass the obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vertebral artery is not typically involved in the collateral circulation that develops in response to post-ductal coarctation of the aorta.
  • Collateral circulation primarily involves the subclavian, axillary, intercostal, and scapular arteries.

choices.text: Contact shot
Close shot at a distance of 1 foot
Shot within range of 2 feet
Shot within range of 3 feet

questions.text: A forensic expert examines a case involving a man found deceased with a gunshot wound to the right temple. The firearm was still in his right hand, the skull had burst open, and there was evidence of charring and a cherry-red coloration along the wound track. What is the most likely range from which the shot was fired?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Contact shot

 

  • The described characteristics of the wound—bursting of the skull, charring, and cherry-red coloration of the track—indicate a contact shot.
  • Contact shots are identified by severe burning and soot deposition, as well as a stellate tearing (bursting) of the skull due to the gases from the gunshot being discharged directly into the tissue and bone.
  • The "cherry red" coloration is typically caused by the carbon monoxide in the gunpowder reacting with hemoglobin in the blood, forming carboxyhemoglobin, which is common in close-range and particularly contact shots.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Close shot at a distance of 1 foot: This would typically show some sooting and stippling (unburned powder particles) around the wound but not the intense charring and stellate tearing seen in contact shots. The absence of stippling and the presence of burst fractures indicate closer proximity than one foot.

 

Option C. Shot within range of 2 feet: At this distance, stippling becomes more pronounced around the wound, and sooting might still be visible, but the charring inside the wound track would be less intense, and the bursting of the skull would be less likely.

 

Option D. Shot within range of 3 feet: Stippling would be evident, and sooting may be minimal or absent. There would be no charring inside the wound track, and the force impacting the skull would not typically cause it to burst open.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In forensic investigations, the characteristics of a gunshot wound can provide critical insights into the distance from which a shot was fired.
  • Contact shots show distinctive signs such as muzzle imprint, soot deposition, and specific color changes in the wound track, which are crucial for reconstructing the events leading to a shooting incident.

questions.text: Identify the device in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) PEG tube

  

  • A PEG tube is used for providing nutrition directly into the stomach in patients who cannot swallow food.
  • The distinguishing features of a PEG tube include a retention bolster that secures the tube to the abdominal wall and an inflatable balloon at the end that helps retain the tube within the stomach.
  • This procedure involves making a small incision in the abdomen, inserting the tube, and securing it.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NJ tube: An NJ tube (Nasojejunal tube) is inserted through the nose and extends into the jejunum. It is typically used for feeding but does not require the surgical kit or bolster shown in the image.

 

 

Option C. NG tube:  An NG tube (Nasogastric tube) is a simple tube inserted through the nose into the stomach or intestine. Unlike the PEG tube, it does not involve a retention bolster or a complex insertion procedure, making it less likely to require the tools seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Chest drain tube:  A chest drain tube is used to remove air, fluid, or pus from the pleural space in the chest. It typically does not include the bolster and balloon characteristic of a PEG tube, and the tools in the image do not match those used for chest drainage procedures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The PEG tube is a specialized device used for long-term feeding directly into the stomach, identified by its retention bolster and the presence of specific tools in the insertion kit.
  • Understanding the key components of the PEG tube kit helps differentiate it from other types of medical tubes.

choices.text: IV sodium bicarbonate

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with end-stage kidney disease presents with worsening muscle weakness. She has not been dialyzed for 3 days. Her serum potassium level is 8.0 mEq/L, and ECG shows tall, peaked T waves. After administering IV calcium gluconate, what is the most appropriate additional treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) IV glucose and insulin

 

  • IV glucose and insulin are the most effective immediate treatments for rapidly lowering serum potassium by shifting it intracellularly, which is crucial in managing severe hyperkalemia in patients with end-stage kidney disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IV high-dose furosemide: Ineffective in patients with end-stage kidney disease due to limited renal function.

 

Option C. IV sodium bicarbonate: Unpredictable and less effective in lowering serum potassium in this scenario.

 

Option D. Oral patiromer: Used for chronic management of hyperkalemia, not appropriate for acute, severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In severe hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with end-stage kidney disease, IV glucose and insulin are essential to rapidly decrease serum potassium levels.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a three-month history of abdominal distension and intermittent fever. He denies night sweats or significant weight loss. Physical examination reveals generalized lymphadenopathy, but peripheral blood smear findings are normal. A lymph node biopsy is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and histopathology, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Castleman disease

 

  • Castleman disease is a rare lymphoproliferative disorder characterized by enlarged lymph nodes, systemic inflammation, and the overproduction of certain cytokines, such as interleukin-6 (IL-6).
  • Histologically, the lymph nodes show follicles with abnormal germinal centers and a characteristic "onion-skin" appearance of the mantle zone, which can be seen in the provided image.
  • The clinical presentation of abdominal distension, intermittent fever, and normal peripheral smear findings, along with the histological features, is consistent with Castleman disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  IgG4-related disease: This condition is associated with fibrosis and the infiltration of IgG4-positive plasma cells, which typically involves organs like the pancreas and salivary glands rather than lymph nodes. The histopathology does not match IgG4-related disease.

 

Option B. Hodgkin's lymphoma: Hodgkin's lymphoma typically presents with Reed-Sternberg cells on histology, which are not seen in the provided image. Although it can present with fever and lymphadenopathy, the histological findings do not support this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Angiolymphoma: This is not a commonly recognized clinical entity and does not correspond to the described histological or clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Castleman disease is a lymphoproliferative disorder that presents with systemic symptoms and characteristic histological features, including abnormal germinal centers and an "onion-skin" appearance of the mantle zone.
  •  It is important to recognize the clinical and histopathological features to differentiate it from other lymphoproliferative disorders.

questions.text: A researcher is analyzing the relationship between economic status and infant mortality rate (IMR) to guide public health strategies. Which coefficient of correlation (r) most likely represents the relationship between economic status and IMR?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) r = –0.8

 

  • The relationship between Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) and economic status is generally negative, meaning as economic status improves, IMR tends to decrease.
  • A correlation coefficient (r) of –0.8 suggests a strong negative correlation, which is consistent with what would be expected between IMR and economic status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. r = +1: This would indicate a perfect positive correlation, which is unlikely in this scenario because higher economic status would typically correspond to lower IMR, not higher.

 

Option B. r = –1: This would indicate a perfect negative correlation, which is very rare in real-world data.

 

Option C. r = +0.22: This suggests a weak positive correlation, which is inconsistent with the expected inverse relationship between economic status and IMR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A strong negative correlation, such as r = –0.8, is expected between Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) and economic status, indicating that as economic status improves, IMR typically decreases.
  • Correlation coefficients help quantify the strength and direction of the relationship between two variables.

questions.text: A 15-year-old female with type 1 diabetes mellitus presents in a comatose state with a blood glucose level of 658 mg/dL and urine positive for glucose and ketones. Which insulin type shown in the figure is most appropriate for treating her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) regular insulin

 

Explanation:

 

This 15-year-old presents with classic signs of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA): extremely elevated blood glucose (658 mg/dL), positive urine glucose and ketones, and coma. DKA is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment with regular (soluble) insulin. Regular insulin is the only insulin formulation that can be administered intravenously, providing the rapid action needed to reverse ketoacidosis and hyperglycemia. In the figure, curve A represents regular insulin with its characteristic rapid onset (30 minutes) and peak action at 2-3 hours, making it ideal for acute management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Intermediate acting insulin: Has delayed onset (2-4 hours) and peaks at 4-10 hours, making it too slow for emergency DKA management
