Option C. Long acting insulin: Provides basal coverage with no pronounced peak; cannot be given IV and inappropriate for acute hyperglycemic crisis

 

Option D. Insulin degludec: Ultra-long-acting basal insulin with flat profile (curve D); designed for once-daily basal coverage, not for acute management

 

Educational Objectives:

 

Regular insulin administered intravenously is the cornerstone of DKA treatment due to its rapid onset and ability to be titrated based on hourly glucose monitoring.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought to the clinic due to a history of recurrent infections, easy bruising, and persistent lymphadenopathy. The child's parents report that the lymph nodes have been enlarged for several months and are not painful. Laboratory tests reveal anemia, thrombocytopenia and elevated levels of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, and CD8-) in the peripheral blood. The child has a history of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. A gene mutation analysis confirms a defect in the Fas receptor gene. Which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS)

 

  • ALPS is a rare genetic disorder characterized by chronic lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias (such as anemia and thrombocytopenia), and an elevated level of double-negative T cells (CD3+, CD4-, CD8-).
  • A key feature of ALPS is the mutation in the Fas receptor gene, which is crucial for regulating apoptosis (programmed cell death).
  • The history of recurrent infections, easy bruising, persistent lymphadenopathy and the specific laboratory findings in this case, including the Fas receptor gene mutation, strongly support a diagnosis of ALPS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID): SCID is a severe immunodeficiency disorder characterized by a lack of functional T and B cells, leading to recurrent severe infections early in life. While SCID presents with recurrent infections, it typically does not feature persistent lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias, or elevated double-negative T cells as seen in ALPS.

 

Option B. Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome: Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome is an immunodeficiency characterized by eczema, thrombocytopenia, and recurrent infections. While thrombocytopenia and recurrent infections are common features, Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome does not present with the specific findings of elevated double-negative T cells or Fas receptor gene mutations seen in ALPS.

 

Option D. Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD): CGD is an immunodeficiency disorder that results in recurrent bacterial and fungal infections due to a defect in phagocyte function. While it causes recurrent infections, CGD does not present with lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias, or the specific T cell abnormalities found in ALPS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome (ALPS) is characterized by chronic lymphadenopathy, autoimmune cytopenias and elevated levels of double-negative T cells.
  •  A mutation in the Fas receptor gene, which is involved in regulating apoptosis, is a hallmark of this disorder.
  •  Recognizing the combination of these clinical and laboratory features is essential for diagnosing ALPS and distinguishing it from other immunodeficiency disorders.

questions.text: During a clinical case review, a 45-year-old woman presents with unresolved joint swelling and pain. Her extensive travel history includes trips to tropical regions. She has a past medical history of multiple parasitic infections. Which parasite is least likely to be contributing to her arthritis-like symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Trichuris trichiura

 

  • Trichuris trichiura, also known as the whipworm, primarily infects the large intestine and causes symptoms such as diarrhea, dysentery and occasionally anemia.
  • It is not typically associated with arthritis, making it the least likely cause among the options listed.
  •  The other parasites can cause joint inflammation either through direct infection or as part of a systemic response to the parasite.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wuchereria bancrofti: Causes lymphatic filariasis and can lead to chronic inflammation, including arthritis-like symptoms in the affected limbs.

 

Option C. Dracunculus: Dracunculus medinensis, or the Guinea worm, can cause severe pain and swelling, particularly when the worm begins to emerge from the skin, which could mimic arthritis.

 

Option D. Echinococcus: The larval stage of Echinococcus species can cause cystic lesions in liver and lungs, and occasionally the bones, which may present with pain similar to arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • While many parasites can cause symptoms resembling arthritis, Trichuris trichiura is primarily an intestinal parasite and does not typically cause joint inflammation or arthritis.

questions.text: A physician prescribes salmeterol to a 28-year-old patient as part of a long-term management plan for asthma. During a follow-up appointment, the physician discusses potential side effects of salmeterol to ensure the patient is well-informed and monitors for any adverse effects. Which of the following is NOT an adverse effect of salmeterol?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypoglycemia

 

  • Salmeterol is a long-acting beta-agonist commonly used in the management of asthma. It can cause several cardiovascular and systemic effects due to its action on beta-adrenergic receptors.
  • Common side effects include tachycardia, resulting from beta-1 stimulation, and hypokalemia, which can occur due to beta-2 mediated uptake of potassium into cells.
  • Tolerance to the bronchodilatory effects can also develop over time. However, hypoglycemia is not a known adverse effect of salmeterol; it is more commonly associated with insulin or other antidiabetic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tachycardia: Beta-2 agonists like salmeterol can cause an increase in heart rate, which is a known side effect.

 

Option B. Tolerance: With long-term use, some patients may develop tolerance to the bronchodilatory effects of salmeterol.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: Beta-2 stimulation leads to potassium moving from the extracellular space into cells, potentially lowering serum potassium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When prescribing salmeterol for asthma management, it is vital for healthcare providers to educate patients about common adverse effects like tachycardia and hypokalemia, while clarifying misconceptions, such as the unlikely occurrence of hypoglycemia.
  • Effective patient education can enhance medication adherence and safety.

choices.text: Epidemic typhus
Q fever
Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF)
Rickettsial pox

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with high fever, severe headache and a generalized rash that notably spares the palms and soles. His medical history is unremarkable, and he denies any recent animal contacts or outdoor activities. Which rickettsial infection is most likely responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epidemic typhus

 

  • Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and transmitted by body lice, presenting with symptoms such as high fever, headache and a rash that starts on the trunk and spreads, but characteristically spares the palms and soles.
  • This pattern aligns with the patient's symptoms, making it the most likely diagnosis given the lack of exposure risks associated with other rickettsial diseases.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Q fever: More commonly linked to exposure to farm animals and does not typically present with a rash, making it less likely in this case.

 

Option C. Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF): Characterized by a rash that often involves the palms and soles, which does not match this patient’s rash distribution.

 

Option D. Rickettsial pox: Typically begins with a mite-bite eschar followed by a vesicular rash that can affect the palms and soles, which is also inconsistent with this presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognizing the clinical presentation of epidemic typhus, especially the characteristic rash distribution and systemic symptoms, is essential for prompt diagnosis and effective management, particularly in populations at risk for louse infestation.

questions.text: A clinician uses the device shown in the image to assess a patient's visual function. This instrument is primarily utilized for determining which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Color vision assessment


 

Nagel anomaloscope

 

  • A device that is used to determine degree of red or green color vision deficit.
  • A dial on the anomaloscope is adjusted until the viewer (patient) believes that the green-red balance is appropriate compared with a standard yellow light whose intensity can also be varied.
  • When a person with normal color vision views the match made by a patient with abnormal color vision, a deficit in either red or green color vision is readily apparent.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ocular Pressure measurement: It is done by Tonometry- NCT- non contact tonometer, Schiotz Tonometry- Indentation tonometer, Goldmann Applanation Tonometer- which is the gold standard of tonometry

 

Option B. Peripheral vision assessment: It is done by Perimetry, there are 2 kinds of perimeter- Static Perimetry and Kinetic Perimetry

 

Option D. Depth Perception Analysis: It is done by using polaroid glasses with an image of Fly- this test is called as Titmus Fly Test

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A color vision test is used for measuring color vision against a standard.
  • These tests are most often used to diagnose color vision deficiencies (color blindness), though several of the standards are designed to categorize normal color vision into sub-levels.

questions.text: A 3-month-old boy presents with elevated serum levels of phenylalanine, para-hydroxyphenylpyruvate, and phenylpyruvate. His skin is notably pale, raising suspicion for phenylketonuria (PKU). However, phenylalanine hydroxylase activity is found to be within the normal range. Which of the following should be checked next to support the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dihydropteridine reductase

 

  • When a patient presents with clinical and biochemical features suggestive of phenylketonuria (PKU) but has normal phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) activity, it is important to consider a defect in dihydropteridine reductase (DHPR).
  • DHPR is an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4), a cofactor required by phenylalanine hydroxylase to convert phenylalanine to tyrosine.
  • A deficiency in DHPR results in a condition known as "malignant PKU" or "atypical PKU," where phenylalanine cannot be properly metabolized despite normal PAH activity.
  • The lack of BH4 leads to elevated levels of phenylalanine and its metabolites, similar to classical PKU.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tyrosinase: Tyrosinase is an enzyme involved in melanin synthesis, not in the metabolism of phenylalanine. While its deficiency leads to albinism, it does not cause elevated levels of phenylalanine or its derivatives.

 

Option B. Homogentisic acid oxidase: This enzyme is involved in the breakdown of tyrosine in the pathway that leads to fumarate and acetoacetate. Deficiency leads to alkaptonuria, not PKU or elevated phenylalanine.

 

Option C. Tyrosine: α-ketoglutarate transaminase: This enzyme is involved in the metabolism of tyrosine and α-ketoglutarate, not directly in the metabolism of phenylalanine. Its deficiency is not related to PKU.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cases of suspected PKU with normal phenylalanine hydroxylase activity, the next step should be to evaluate for a deficiency in dihydropteridine reductase (DHPR), as it can lead to a similar biochemical presentation by impairing the regeneration of the cofactor tetrahydrobiopterin, which is essential for phenylalanine metabolism.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents to the OPD with a recently changing, asymmetrical pigmented lesion on her arm. The lesion has irregular borders and variegated coloration. She reports that the lesion has become itchy over the past few weeks. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and the histopathological examination is shown below. Which of the following stains was most likely used to visualize the tissue sample?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Masson Fontana stain

 

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological findings are suggestive of melanocytic nevus.
  • Masson Fontana stain is used to identify melanin and is particularly useful in the diagnosis of pigmented lesions, such as melanomas or pigmented nevi as shown in the above image.
  • The presence of melanin in the tissue is indicated by the black or dark brown coloration, which is characteristic of this stain.
  • Given the clinical presentation of a changing, asymmetrical pigmented lesion with irregular borders and variegated color, the use of Masson Fontana stain is appropriate to assess the presence of melanin and differentiate between benign and malignant melanocytic lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucicarmine stain: This stain is primarily used to detect mucin, which is not relevant in the context of pigmented skin lesions.

 

Option B. Masson trichrome stain: This stain is used to differentiate between collagen and muscle fibers, often in the context of fibrosis or muscle pathology. It is not used to identify melanin.

 

Option D. Van Gieson stain: This is used to differentiate collagen and other connective tissue fibers, which is not relevant for diagnosing pigmented skin lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Masson Fontana stain is specifically used to detect melanin in tissue samples, making it the appropriate choice for evaluating pigmented skin lesions, particularly in the context of suspected melanoma or atypical nevi.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a history of a spontaneous abortion followed by amenorrhea. Her current FSH level is 6 mIU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Uterine synechiae

 

  • In this scenario, the most likely cause of amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion with a normal FSH level (6 mIU/mL) is uterine synechiae (Asherman's syndrome).
  •  Uterine synechiae refer to intrauterine adhesions that can form after procedures such as dilation and curettage (D&C) following a miscarriage.
  • These adhesions can lead to secondary amenorrhea because the endometrial lining is disrupted, preventing normal menstrual shedding.
  • The normal FSH level suggests that the ovarian function is intact, making a uterine cause more likely.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pituitary dysfunction: Pituitary dysfunction typically affects the secretion of hormones such as FSH, LH, and prolactin. In cases of pituitary dysfunction, FSH levels are usually abnormally high or low, not normal, as seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Ovarian dysfunction: Ovarian dysfunction, such as premature ovarian failure or polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), would generally present with abnormal FSH levels. Elevated FSH is indicative of ovarian failure, while PCOS might show normal or slightly elevated FSH with other hormonal imbalances.

 

Option D. First pregnancy: If the patient were pregnant, one would expect to see elevated levels of hCG, not just a normal FSH level. Moreover, pregnancy is generally confirmed with a positive pregnancy test and not by FSH measurement alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion, especially in the presence of a normal FSH level, suggests a possible uterine cause, such as uterine synechiae (Asherman's syndrome). This condition results from intrauterine adhesions that can prevent normal menstruation by obstructing the endometrial cavity.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of secondary amenorrhea. She also reports having milky discharge from her breasts. On examination, galactorrhea is confirmed, and her prolactin levels are elevated. A urine pregnancy test is negative. What is the most appropriate treatment for her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cabergoline

  

  • The most appropriate treatment for this patient, who presents with secondary amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and elevated prolactin levels, is Cabergoline.
  • Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that effectively lowers prolactin levels by inhibiting prolactin secretion from the pituitary gland.
  • Elevated prolactin (hyperprolactinemia) can cause secondary amenorrhea and galactorrhea, and treating the underlying cause of hyperprolactinemia is crucial to resolving these symptoms.
  • Cabergoline is preferred over other treatments due to its efficacy and lower side effect profile compared to other dopamine agonists like bromocriptine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is a hormone that stimulates uterine contractions and milk ejection during lactation. It is not used for treating hyperprolactinemia or galactorrhea and would not address the underlying issue in this case.

 

Option B. OCP (Oral Contraceptive Pills): While oral contraceptive pills can be used to regulate menstrual cycles, they do not treat the underlying cause of hyperprolactinemia and would not address the galactorrhea or elevated prolactin levels.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid that can be used in conditions requiring anti-inflammatory or immunosuppressive therapy. It does not play a role in the treatment of hyperprolactinemia and would not be appropriate for this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment of choice for a woman with secondary amenorrhea, galactorrhea, and elevated prolactin levels is Cabergoline, a dopamine agonist that lowers prolactin levels and addresses the underlying hyperprolactinemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient undergoing cyclosporine therapy for immunosuppression is being monitored for potential side effects. Which of the following is NOT a known complication of cyclosporine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pulmonary fibrosis

 

  • Pulmonary fibrosis is not a recognized complication of cyclosporine therapy.
  • While cyclosporine has many potential side effects, pulmonary fibrosis is not typically associated with this medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypertension: Hypertension is a common side effect of cyclosporine, often due to its effects on renal vasculature and increased production of vasoconstrictors.

 

Option C. Hirsutism: Hirsutism, or excessive hair growth, is a well-known side effect of cyclosporine.

 

Option D. Nephrotoxicity: Nephrotoxicity is one of the most serious and common side effects of cyclosporine, requiring regular monitoring of renal function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cyclosporine therapy is associated with several side effects, including hypertension, hirsutism, and nephrotoxicity, but not typically with pulmonary fibrosis.
  • Regular monitoring is essential to manage these complications.

choices.text: Standard error of the mean
Standard error of difference between two means
Standard error of difference between two proportions

questions.text: A hospital epidemiologist is setting up a system to monitor infection rates across different departments to evaluate a new intervention's effectiveness. What statistical measure should be used to determine how well the departmental infection rate means represent the overall hospital rate?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Standard error of the mean

 

  • The standard error of the mean (SEM) measures the variability of the sample mean from the population mean.
  • It provides an estimate of how much the sample mean is expected to vary from the true population mean due to sampling error.
  • The SEM is calculated as the standard deviation of the sample divided by the square root of the sample size.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Standard error of proportion: This measures the variability of a sample proportion from the population proportion, not the mean.

 

Option C. Standard error of difference between two means: This measures the variability between the means of two different samples, not the variability of one sample mean from the population mean.

 

Option D. Standard error of difference between two proportions: This measures the variability between the proportions of two different samples, not the mean.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard error of the mean (SEM) is the appropriate measure for understanding the variation of the sample mean from the population mean.
  • It is crucial in estimating the precision of the sample mean as a representation of the population mean.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia has responded well to olanzapine, but she has experienced significant weight gain. You are considering switching her antipsychotic medication. Which of the following is the most appropriate antipsychotic to switch to in order to address her weight gain while maintaining her symptom control?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aripiprazole

 

  • Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic with a lower risk of weight gain compared to other antipsychotics, including olanzapine.
  • It has a partial agonist effect on dopamine D2 receptors, which may also contribute to a more favourable metabolic profile.
  • Therefore, switching to aripiprazole is a reasonable choice for managing weight gain while continuing effective treatment for schizophrenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Risperidone: While risperidone is effective in treating schizophrenia, it is associated with moderate weight gain and other metabolic side effects. Switching to risperidone may not significantly mitigate the weight gain experienced with olanzapine.

 

Option C. Quetiapine: Quetiapine, another atypical antipsychotic, is also associated with weight gain and metabolic syndrome, similar to olanzapine. Therefore, it is not the best option for a patient who is experiencing significant weight gain.

 

Option D. Clozapine: Clozapine is typically reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia due to its efficacy but has a high risk of weight gain and metabolic complications. Additionally, it requires regular monitoring for agranulocytosis. Given these concerns, clozapine is not an appropriate choice for a patient who is responding well to treatment but experiencing weight gain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For patients with schizophrenia who respond well to an antipsychotic but experience significant weight gain, switching to aripiprazole, an antipsychotic with a more favourable metabolic profile, can help manage weight while maintaining symptom control.

choices.text: The nominated representative must be appointed in writing by the patient.
The nominated representative has the right to make decisions on behalf of the patient even when the patient is competent.
The nominated representative can be a relative, caregiver, or any other person of the patient’s choice.
The appointment of the nominated representative can be revoked or changed by the patient at any time.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female patient with a history of bipolar disorder wishes to appoint a nominated representative under the Mental Healthcare Act (MHCA) 2017. Which of the following statements regarding the nominated representative is not true?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The nominated representative has the right to make decisions on behalf of the patient even when the patient is competent.

 

  • Under the MHCA 2017, the nominated representative is empowered to make decisions on behalf of the patient only when the patient is not competent to make decisions themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The nominated representative must be appointed in writing by the patient: This is correct, as the Act requires the nomination to be in written form.

 

Option C. The nominated representative can be a relative, caregiver, or any other person of the patient’s choice: This is correct, providing flexibility in the choice of representative.

 

Option D. The appointment of the nominated representative can be revoked or changed by the patient at any time: This is correct, allowing the patient to modify their decision as needed.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks of gestation is undergoing continuous fetal monitoring during labor. The fetal heart rate monitor shows frequent accelerations, which are interpreted as a sign of fetal well-being. Which of the following factors primarily contributes to these increases in fetal heart rate during labor and delivery?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carotid body chemoreceptors

 

  • Carotid body chemoreceptors are sensitive to changes in the levels of oxygen, carbon dioxide, and pH in the blood.
  • During labor, transient reductions in oxygen levels (hypoxia) or changes in carbon dioxide levels can occur, which are detected by these chemoreceptors.
  • In response, the carotid body chemoreceptors trigger reflexes that modulate the fetal heart rate, leading to accelerations as part of the fetal compensatory mechanisms to ensure adequate oxygen delivery and maintain homeostasis.
  • This reflex response indicates an intact and responsive autonomic system, which is crucial for fetal well-being.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aortic baroreceptors: These are primarily involved in detecting changes in blood pressure but do not play a central role in the modulation of fetal heart rate accelerations during labor.

 

Option B. ANP (Atrial Natriuretic Peptide): ANP is involved in the regulation of blood volume and pressure but does not have a direct effect on the modulation of fetal heart rate accelerations.

 

Option C. Autonomic brain stem regulation: While the autonomic brainstem plays a role in overall heart rate regulation, the specific trigger for fetal heart rate accelerations during labor is more directly tied to chemoreceptor activity in response to blood gas levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Carotid body chemoreceptors are primarily responsible for detecting changes in blood oxygen and carbon dioxide levels during labor, leading to fetal heart rate accelerations that indicate good fetal health and adaptive capacity.

choices.text: Both statements are true, and B explains A.
Both statements are true, but B does not explain A.
A is true, B is false.
A is false, B is true.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about an immature cataract examination:

 

  • Assertion (A): When light is thrown from the temporal side in an immature cataract, it casts a shadow over the nasal iris.
  • Reason (B): There is clear lens substance between the pupillary margin and the lens opacity.

 

Choose the correct option:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A is false, B is true.

 

  • Assertion (A): The assertion is incorrect. In cases of immature cataract, the shadow is not cast over the nasal iris but over the lens itself because there is clear lens substance allowing light to pass through and highlight the opacity.
  • Reason (B): The reason is correct. In an immature cataract, there typically remains some clear lens substance between the pupillary margin and the areas of opacity, which is important for visual acuity and examination findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When examining an immature cataract, observe how light interacts with the lens.
  • The presence of clear sections in the lens helps to differentiate the extent and severity of opacities, which is essential for accurate assessment and management of cataract progression.

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman with recently diagnosed multiple myeloma is asymptomatic but has an elevated serum calcium level of 11.2 mg/dL and a total protein of 9.2 g/dL. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ionized calcium

 

  • In this patient with multiple myeloma and an elevated total calcium level, the next appropriate step is to measure the ionized calcium level.
  • The ionized calcium level reflects the physiologically active form of calcium in the blood.
  • In conditions such as multiple myeloma, where there is an increased protein binding of calcium due to elevated serum proteins, the total serum calcium may appear elevated (pseudohypercalcemia) without a true increase in ionized calcium.
  • Therefore, measuring ionized calcium will help determine if the hypercalcemia is real or simply an artifact of protein binding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24-Hour urine calcium: This is used to diagnose familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia (FHH), not relevant in this case.

 

Option B. 25-Hydroxyvitamin D: This measures vitamin D stores and is not directly useful for evaluating hypercalcemia in this context.

 

Option D. Parathyroid hormone: Measuring PTH is important in differentiating PTH-mediated from non–PTH-mediated hypercalcemia, but only after confirming true hypercalcemia through ionized calcium measurement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients with elevated total calcium levels and conditions like multiple myeloma that increase serum protein binding, it is crucial to measure ionized calcium to confirm true hypercalcemia and avoid unnecessary further testing or treatment based on a falsely elevated total calcium level.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the orthopedic clinic with shoulder pain and weakness, particularly when attempting to rotate his arm internally. On physical examination, the patient has significant weakness with internal rotation against resistance, and a positive lift-off test is noted. An X-ray reveals an isolated avulsion fracture at the lesser tuberosity of the humerus. Which of the following muscles is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Subscapularis

  • The subscapularis muscle is responsible for internal rotation of the arm at the shoulder and inserts on the lesser tuberosity of the humerus.
  • An isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tuberosity is highly suggestive of an injury to the subscapularis muscle, as this is where the tendon of the subscapularis attaches.
  • The positive lift-off test, where the patient is unable to lift their hand off their back, further supports the diagnosis of a subscapularis injury.
  • This type of fracture often occurs due to a forceful internal rotation or direct trauma to the shoulder.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infraspinatus: The infraspinatus inserts on the greater tuberosity of the humerus and is responsible for external rotation of the shoulder. It would not cause an avulsion fracture of the lesser tuberosity.

 

Option B. Supraspinatus: The supraspinatus also inserts on the greater tuberosity and is involved in abduction of the shoulder. It is not associated with the lesser tuberosity or internal rotation.

 

Option D. Teres Minor: The teres minor, like the infraspinatus, is involved in external rotation and also inserts on the greater tuberosity, making it unlikely to be associated with an avulsion fracture of the lesser tuberosity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • An isolated avulsion fracture of the lesser tuberosity of the humerus is indicative of a subscapularis muscle injury.
  • The subscapularis is the primary muscle responsible for internal rotation of the shoulder, and its attachment on the lesser tuberosity makes this fracture pattern characteristic of a subscapularis tear or avulsion

questions.text: A 65-year-old man undergoes a low anterior resection for rectal cancer. On the fifth day of his hospital stay, he develops a fever of 39°C (102°F), a blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, a pulse of 110 beats per minute, and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute. Tenderness is present in the lower abdomen. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen reveals an abscess in the pelvis. Which of the following most accurately describes his present condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sepsis

 

  • Sepsis is defined as the presence of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) criteria in the context of a confirmed infection.
  • This patient meets the SIRS criteria with a fever, tachycardia, and tachypnea.
  • The CT scan revealing a pelvic abscess confirms the presence of an infection. Thus, the appropriate diagnosis is sepsis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS): SIRS is characterized by the presence of at least two of the following: temperature >38°C (100.4°F) or <36°C (96.8°F), heart rate >90 beats per minute, respiratory rate >20 breaths per minute or PaCO2 <32 mm Hg, and abnormal white blood cell count (>12,000/mm³ or <4,000/mm³, or >10% immature neutrophils). While this patient meets the SIRS criteria, the diagnosis of SIRS alone does not include the presence of an infection, which this patient has.

 

Option C. Dehydration: Though this is likely to additionally occur, the presence of elevated BP and abdominal findings goes against dehydration alone.

 

Option D. Paralytic ileus: Intra-abdominal sepsis may lead to paralytic ileus, but its findings such as dilated bowel loops with absent bowel sounds are not mentioned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sepsis is diagnosed when a patient meets the criteria for systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS) in the presence of a confirmed infection.
  • It is critical to distinguish between sepsis, severe sepsis, and septic shock to ensure appropriate and timely management.
  • This patient meets the criteria for sepsis based on the clinical and imaging findings indicating an infection, but without evidence of organ dysfunction or hypotension.

questions.text: A competitive swimmer presents to the clinic complaining of persistent itching and redness in the groin area. Given the common causes of dermatological issues in athletes, which of the following is least likely to be responsible for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

  • Aspergillus, primarily a mold associated with respiratory infections, is not typically involved in skin infections of the groin. The environment of this region does not favor the growth of Aspergillus, making it an unlikely cause of the symptoms.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Trichophyton: This dermatophyte is a frequent cause of tinea cruris (jock itch), which commonly presents with itching and redness in the groin.

 

Option B. Microsporum: Typically associated with scalp and body ringworm but can rarely cause groin infections.

 

Option C. Epidermophyton:  Known to cause tinea cruris, presenting with similar symptoms of itching and redness in the groin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of groin itching and redness, especially in athletes, consider common dermatophytes such as Trichophyton, Microsporum and Epidermophyton as probable causes, rather than molds like Aspergillus, which are unusual for such infections.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a painless genital ulcer that has been slowly enlarging for several weeks. Examination reveals a beefy-red granulomatous ulcer with friable granulation tissue that bleeds on contact. There is no tender inguinal lymphadenopathy, but a soft subcutaneous swelling resembling a pseudo-bubo is present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Donovanosis

 

Donovanosis, also called granuloma inguinale, is caused by Calymmatobacterium granulomatis (now Klebsiella granulomatis). It presents with a painless, beefy-red granulomatous ulcer that bleeds easily due to fragile granulation tissue with superficial capillaries. The lesions expand slowly and often lack significant lymphadenopathy, though a pseudo-bubo (a subcutaneous swelling not due to lymph node inflammation) may be seen. Histologically, Donovan bodies are seen in macrophages using Wrights or Giemsa stain. These characteristics make donovanosis distinct from other causes of genital ulcers.
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A) Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV):
LGV, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (L1L3), typically presents initially with a small, painless papule or ulcer that may go unnoticed. The hallmark is tender inguinal or femoral lymphadenopathy that can suppurate, often showing a groove sign, not a pseudo-bubo. Unlike donovanosis, LGV is associated with more robust lymph node involvement.

 

Option C. Chancroid: Caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, chancroid typically presents as multiple painful ulcers with purulent discharge, undermined edges, and painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (true buboes). The ulcer is not beefy-red and bleeds less commonly. The presence of pain and purulent discharge helps differentiate it from donovanosis.

 

Option D. Syphilis: Primary syphilis presents with a painless indurated ulcer (chancre), typically solitary, with clean base and raised, firm borders. There is regional lymphadenopathy, but unlike donovanosis, the ulcer is indurated and not beefy-red, and it doesnt bleed easily. Histologically, no Donovan bodies are found.
 

Educational Objective:

 

Donovanosis presents with a painless, beefy-red ulcer that bleeds easily due to vascular granulation tissue and typically lacks true lymphadenopathy, though pseudo-buboes may occur.

questions.text: A 41-year-old woman presents with intermittent suprapubic pain, urinary urgency and discomfort during urination for the past 3 months. She has not responded to multiple courses of antibiotics. Cystoscopy reveals the presence of Hunner ulcers in the bladder. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Interstitial cystitis

 

  • The patient presents with chronic urinary symptoms including suprapubic pain, increased frequency and dysuria, which are key features of interstitial cystitis (IC).
  • Interstitial cystitis, also known as bladder pain syndrome, is a chronic condition characterized by bladder pain and irritative urinary symptoms without evidence of infection.
  • The presence of Hunner ulcers on cystoscopy is a classic finding associated with interstitial cystitis.
  • These ulcers are areas of inflammation and ulceration in the bladder wall, which are pathognomonic for the condition.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Malakoplakia: Malakoplakia is a rare chronic inflammatory condition usually affecting the genitourinary tract, characterized by the presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies within macrophages. It typically presents with recurrent urinary tract infections and is not associated with Hunner ulcers. Therefore, it is not the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

Option B. Follicular cystitis: Follicular cystitis is a type of chronic cystitis characterized by the presence of lymphoid follicles in the bladder wall. It is typically seen in response to chronic infection or irritation, but it is not specifically associated with Hunner ulcers and would not be the most likely diagnosis given the clinical presentation and cystoscopy findings.

 

Option D. Urothelial carcinoma: Urothelial carcinoma (previously known as transitional cell carcinoma) is the most common type of bladder cancer. It often presents with painless hematuria. Although it can cause urinary symptoms, it is not typically associated with Hunner ulcers. The absence of hematuria and the chronic nature of the symptoms make urothelial carcinoma less likely in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hunner ulcers observed on cystoscopy are a pathognomonic finding for interstitial cystitis, a chronic condition characterized by bladder pain and urinary symptoms such as frequency and dysuria.

choices.text: Observation and NSAIDs for symptom control
Surgical excision of the lesion
Long-term antibiotics and physical therapy

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents with localized pain in the femur that worsens at night and is relieved by NSAIDs. Radiographs show a small, well-defined lytic lesion. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Percutaneous radiofrequency ablation

 

Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA):

 

  •  This is a minimally invasive procedure where a radiofrequency probe is inserted into the tumour through a small incision.
  • The probe generates heat, which destroys the tumour tissue.

 

Advantages:

 

  • Minimally Invasive: RFA is less invasive compared to open surgery and usually requires only a small incision.
  • Effectiveness: It is highly effective for treating osteoid osteomas, with a high success rate in alleviating symptoms and completely eradicating the tumour.
  • Recovery: Patients often experience a quicker recovery time and less postoperative pain compared to surgical excision.

 

Indication: 

 

  • Given that osteoid osteomas are typically small and localized, RFA is a preferred method due to its minimally invasive nature and high efficacy in treating this type of tumour.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation and NSAIDs for Symptom Control:

 

  • Observation: While observation might be an initial approach for some benign conditions, it is not typically sufficient for osteoid osteoma. The pain associated with osteoid osteoma is usually quite severe and does not fully resolve with observation alone.
  • NSAIDs: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) are effective for pain relief in osteoid osteoma. They are often used as a temporary measure to manage symptoms, but they do not address the underlying cause of the pain.
  • Limitations: Relying solely on NSAIDs and observation does not eliminate the tumour and may lead to prolonged suffering and potential complications. Therefore, while NSAIDs are useful for symptom control, they do not constitute definitive treatment.

 

Option B. Surgical Excision of the Lesion:

 

  • Surgical Excision: This approach involves removing the tumour through surgery. While effective in treating osteoid osteoma, it is more invasive compared to less invasive techniques like percutaneous radiofrequency ablation.
  • Risks: Surgical excision carries risks such as infection, wound healing problems, and damage to surrounding structures. It is typically reserved for cases where less invasive treatments are not feasible or have failed.
  • Current Trends: Given advances in minimally invasive techniques, surgical excision is often considered less favourable for osteoid osteoma unless radiofrequency ablation is not possible, or the tumour is inaccessible.

 

Option D. Long-Term Antibiotics and Physical Therapy:

 

  • Antibiotics: Long-term antibiotics are not appropriate for treating osteoid osteoma as it is not an infectious condition. Antibiotics are used for bacterial infections, not benign bone tumors.
  • Physical Therapy: While physical therapy can be beneficial for rehabilitation and improving function, it does not address the underlying cause of the pain associated with an osteoid osteoma. It is not a primary treatment modality for the tumour itself.
  • Inappropriate: This approach does not target the osteoid osteoma directly and is not effective in managing or curing the tumour.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Percutaneous Radiofrequency Ablation (RFA) is the most appropriate management strategy is minimally invasive, effective and provides rapid relief of symptoms with a high success rate.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct in respect of scabies?

 

  1. Male mite Sarcoptes scabiei are commonly transferred from an infected person to a non-infected person.
  2. Norwegian scabies occur in immunodeficient patients.
  3. Permethrin cream (5%) is used for treatment.
  4. Pruritus intensifies at night and after hot shower.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2, 3 and 4

 

Explanation

 

2. Norwegian scabies occur in immunodeficient patients.

 

  • Norwegian scabies, also known as crusted scabies, occurs in immunocompromised individuals and is characterized by thick crusts of skin containing large numbers of mites and eggs.

 

 

3. Permethrin cream (5%) is used for treatment.

 

  • Permethrin cream (5%) is the treatment of choice for scabies.

 

 

  • It is applied to the entire body from the neck down and left for several hours before washing off.

 

4. Pruritus intensifies at night and after hot shower.

 

  • Pruritus (itching) in scabies is typically more intense at night and after a hot shower due to the increased activity of the mites in warmer temperatures and the relaxation of the skin's outer layers, which allows for easier mite movement.

 

Other Option:

 

1. Male mite Sarcoptes scabiei are commonly transferred from an infected person to a non-infected person.

 

  • This statement is incorrect.
  • Female mites are responsible for laying eggs and burrowing into the skin, and they are primarily the ones transferred during close personal contact.

 

 

  • Male mites do not burrow into the skin and are not typically involved in transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Scabies is characterized by intense pruritus, especially at night, and crusted scabies occurs in immunocompromised patients.
  • Permethrin cream (5%) is the preferred treatment.

choices.text: Start sips of water after 6-8 hours
Remove the Foley’s catheter after 24 hours

questions.text: A 22-year-old primigravida undergoes an emergency cesarean section due to obstructed labor. As part of her postoperative care, several interventions are being considered. Which of the following interventions should NOT be implemented in her postoperative management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Remove the Foley’s catheter after 24 hours

 

  • Removing the Foley's catheter after 24 hours might not be appropriate in all cases, particularly after a cesarean section for obstructed labor.
  •  In such scenarios, there might be a higher risk of urinary retention or bladder complications due to prolonged labor, regional anesthesia, or the trauma associated with the obstructed labor.
  • Delaying the removal of the Foley catheter beyond 24 hours could be considered to ensure proper urinary output monitoring and to reduce the risk of bladder dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Start sips of water after 6-8 hours: This is standard practice after cesarean sections, allowing the gastrointestinal system to resume normal function and helping to prevent nausea and vomiting.

 

Option B. Encourage early mobilization: Early mobilization is crucial to prevent complications such as deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and promote faster recovery after surgery.

 

Option D. Broad-spectrum antibiotics: While not always necessary for extended use, broad-spectrum antibiotics may be continued in the immediate postoperative period if there are specific concerns such as prolonged labor, increased risk of infection, or signs of sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the postoperative care of a cesarean section, especially after obstructed labor, the removal of a Foley catheter should be carefully considered and may need to be delayed beyond 24 hours to monitor for urinary complications.

questions.text: A medical officer in a district hospital is investigating a case of suspected poisoning after a sudden, unexplained death. The officer must decide which tissue samples to preserve for toxicological analysis. Which suspected poison necessitates the preservation of spinal cord tissue for definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strychnine

 

  • Strychnine poisoning, known for causing severe muscular convulsions and spasms, directly impacts the central nervous system.
  • Preserving a sample of the spinal cord is critical in cases of suspected strychnine poisoning, as analysis can reveal the impact on neural pathways and assist in confirming the diagnosis through detection of the toxin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oleander: Contains cardiac glycosides affecting the heart; tissue samples typically focus on heart and blood.

 

Option B. Alcohol: Toxicological analysis primarily involves blood and sometimes liver, not typically the spinal cord.

 

Option D. Arsenic: Examination primarily focuses on hair, nails, and internal organs like liver and kidney, not the spinal cord.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Viscera and materials required in certain Poisonings:

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman with gravida 1 is in active labor at 37 weeks of gestation. At 5 cm cervical dilation, an amniotomy is performed, and the amniotic fluid appears golden in color. What is the most likely cause of this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rh isoimmunization

  

  • The presence of golden-colored amniotic fluid is most commonly associated with Rh isoimmunization. In cases of Rh isoimmunization, hemolysis of fetal red blood cells occurs due to the maternal immune response against Rh-positive fetal cells.
  •  The breakdown of red blood cells leads to the release of bilirubin, which can accumulate in the amniotic fluid, giving it a golden or yellowish tint.
  • This finding is an important indicator of fetal hemolysis and warrants immediate attention to prevent further complications such as hydrops fetalis or severe neonatal anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Post maturity: Post maturity is typically associated with meconium-stained amniotic fluid, which appears green or brown due to the presence of meconium in the fluid. Golden-colored fluid is not characteristic of post maturity.

 

Option B. Fetal demise: Fetal demise might lead to amniotic fluid abnormalities, including dark or bloody fluid, but a golden color is not typically associated with this condition.

 

Option D. Fetal distress: Fetal distress is often linked to meconium-stained fluid, which is green or brown, rather than golden. Golden fluid specifically suggests hemolysis rather than hypoxia or acidosis, which are common in distress.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Golden-colored amniotic fluid seen during labor is a potential indicator of Rh isoimmunization, where fetal red blood cell hemolysis leads to elevated bilirubin in the amniotic fluid.

choices.text: Cystic Fibrosis
Chediak-Higashi Syndrome

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the clinic by their parents due to frequent infections, easy bruising and light sensitivity. On examination, the child has pale skin, silvery hair and light-colored eyes. The parents report that the child has a history of recurrent respiratory and skin infections. Laboratory tests reveal giant granules in the white blood cells and platelets. Genetic testing confirms a mutation in the LYST gene. Which of the following genetic conditions is the most likely cause of this child's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chediak-Higashi Syndrome

 

  • Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by partial albinism (manifesting as pale skin, silvery hair and light-colored eyes) and recurrent infections due to defects in the immune system.
  • The presence of giant granules in white blood cells and platelets, along with the mutation in the LYST gene, are key diagnostic features.
  • This syndrome arises from impaired function of lysosomes and granules in various cells, leading to the clinical symptoms observed in the child, including frequent infections, easy bruising and light sensitivity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albinism: Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of pigment in the skin, hair and eyes, leading to light-colored features. However, albinism does not cause recurrent infections, easy bruising or the presence of giant granules in white blood cells and platelets, which are seen in Chediak-Higashi Syndrome. Albinism is also not associated with mutations in the LYST gene.

 

Option B. Cystic Fibrosis: Cystic Fibrosis is a genetic disorder that primarily affects the lungs and digestive system, leading to recurrent respiratory infections, pancreatic insufficiency and malabsorption. It is caused by mutations in the CFTR gene, not the LYST gene, and does not present with albinism, light sensitivity or giant granules in blood cells.

 

Option D. Ataxia-Telangiectasia: Ataxia-Telangiectasia is a rare genetic disorder characterized by progressive cerebellar ataxia, telangiectasias (small dilated blood vessels), immunodeficiency and a predisposition to cancers. It is caused by mutations in the ATM gene and does not present with the specific combination of partial albinism, giant granules in blood cells and recurrent infections that are characteristic of Chediak-Higashi Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chediak-Higashi Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by partial albinism, recurrent infections, and the presence of giant granules in white blood cells and platelets.
  • It is associated with mutations in the LYST gene, which impair the function of lysosomes and granules in cells.
  • Recognizing the clinical and laboratory features of this syndrome is essential for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Internal branch of superior laryngeal nerve
External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A female singer presents with hoarseness of voice, unable to sing higher frequency notes. Bowed and depressed unilateral vocal cord is seen. Which nerve is involved?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) External branch of superior laryngeal nerve

 

  • The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which plays a crucial role in tensing the vocal cords and controlling pitch.
  • Damage to this nerve leads to an inability to produce high-pitched sounds due to a loss of tension in the vocal cords, which is why the patient has difficulty singing higher notes.
  • The bowing and depression of the vocal cord seen in this patient indicates a loss of tension, directly implicating the EBSLN.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle. It also supplies sensory innervation below the level of the vocal cords. If this nerve is damaged, the patient would present with hoarseness of voice, and in severe cases, vocal cord paralysis. However, the cricothyroid muscle, responsible for tensing the vocal cords (especially for high-pitched sounds), would still function normally because it is not innervated by the RLN.

 

Option B. Internal Branch of Superior Laryngeal Nerve: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) provides sensory innervation above the vocal cords, including the epiglottis and laryngeal mucosa. Damage to this nerve does not affect vocal cord tension or movement, hence it would not explain the patient's inability to sing higher frequency notes or the bowing and depression of the vocal cord.

 

Option D. None of the Above: Since the EBSLN is the correct answer, this option is incorrect.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Damage to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) results in loss of function of the cricothyroid muscle, leading to difficulty in producing high-pitched sounds and vocal cord bowing.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents with 3 months of worsening exertional dyspnea, fatigue, and recent exertional chest pain relieved by rest. His physical examination reveals a blood pressure of 155/43 mm Hg, rapid carotid upstrokes and collapse, a diminished S2, a grade 2/6 early diastolic decrescendo murmur at the left sternal border, and a displaced apical impulse. Pulmonary crackles and elevated jugular pressure are also noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Aortic regurgitation

 

  • The most likely diagnosis is chronic aortic regurgitation (AR).
  • The characteristic murmur of AR is a blowing diastolic decrescendo murmur heard best at the left sternal border, often accompanied by signs such as a widened pulse pressure and a Corrigan pulse (a rapid, accentuated upstroke with a quick decline).
  • These findings are consistent with AR, which can lead to symptoms of heart failure and angina due to chronic volume overload and subendocardial ischemia.
  • The other options do not match the physical findings observed in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atrial myxoma: This would present with different symptoms and auscultatory findings, such as a mid-diastolic murmur at the apex or a tumor plop, which are not observed here.

 

Option C. Patent ductus arteriosus: Characterized by a continuous "machinery" murmur heard beneath the left clavicle, which differs from the murmur described in this patient.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation: Typically presents with a systolic murmur and signs like jugular venous distention, large retrograde v waves, and hepatojugular reflux, none of which are present in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aortic regurgitation should be considered in patients presenting with a diastolic murmur, widened pulse pressure, and signs of heart failure, particularly when associated with physical exam findings such as a Corrigan pulse and a displaced apical impulse.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with exertional chest pain that subsides with rest. The physician decides to perform a test to assess myocardial perfusion during stress. The test shows areas of reduced uptake during exercise that improve at rest, suggesting reversible ischemia. Which of the following diagnostic tests was most likely performed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thallium scan

 

  • A thallium scan, also known as myocardial perfusion imaging, is a nuclear medicine test used to evaluate myocardial blood flow during stress and at rest.
  • Thallium-201, a radioactive isotope, is injected into the bloodstream and taken up by viable myocardial cells in proportion to blood flow.
  • Areas of the heart with reduced perfusion during exercise show decreased uptake of thallium, indicating ischemia.
  •  If these areas show improved uptake at rest, this suggests reversible ischemia, typical of conditions like stable angina.
  • This scenario described in the question aligns with the findings of a thallium scan.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MUGA scan: A MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan evaluates the function of the heart's ventricles by assessing the ejection fraction, but it does not assess myocardial perfusion or ischemia.

 

Option B. Tc99m pyrophosphate:  This shows a hot spot by binding to the infarct.

 

Option D. CT coronary angiography: This non-invasive test visualizes coronary arteries to assess for stenosis, but it does not evaluate myocardial perfusion or identify reversible ischemia directly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A thallium scan is specifically used to assess myocardial perfusion during stress and rest.
  • It is the most appropriate test to identify reversible ischemia in patients with exertional chest pain, indicative of conditions like stable angina.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis has been on various disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs) to control her symptoms. Her rheumatologist decides to continue her on a medication that acts by increasing extracellular adenosine, which has anti-inflammatory effects. Which of the following DMARDs acts by this mechanism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Methotrexate

 

  • Methotrexate is the DMARD that acts by increasing extracellular adenosine.
  • Adenosine has potent anti-inflammatory effects, which help in reducing the symptoms and progression of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase and promotes the release of adenosine, thereby exerting its anti-inflammatory effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sulfasalazine: Sulfasalazine is a DMARD that works by modulating the immune system and has anti-inflammatory properties, but it does not primarily act by increasing extracellular adenosine.

 

Option C. Azathioprine: Azathioprine is an immunosuppressive drug that interferes with purine synthesis, thus inhibiting the proliferation of cells, particularly lymphocytes. It does not act through the adenosine pathway.

 

Option D. Leflunomide: Leflunomide inhibits dihydroorotate dehydrogenase, which is involved in pyrimidine synthesis. This drug decreases lymphocyte proliferation, but it does not act by increasing adenosine extracellularly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methotrexate is a key DMARD used in rheumatoid arthritis that works by increasing extracellular adenosine, which has significant anti-inflammatory effects.
  • Other DMARDs such as Sulfasalazine, Azathioprine, and Leflunomide act through different mechanisms and do not involve adenosine pathways.

choices.text: Medial part of Diaphragmatic Pleura

questions.text: Which of the following is not innervated by the marked nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Costal Pleura

 

  • The nerve marked in the image is the phrenic nerve.
  • The phrenic nerve primarily provides motor innervation to the diaphragm and sensory innervation to the central part of the diaphragm, the mediastinal pleura, and the medial part of the diaphragmatic pleura.
  • However, the costal pleura, which lines the inner surface of the ribs, is not innervated by the phrenic nerve.
  • Instead, the costal pleura is supplied by the intercostal nerves, which arise from the thoracic spinal nerves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diaphragm: The phrenic nerve provides motor innervation to the diaphragm, which is essential for respiration.

 

Option B. Mediastinal Pleura: The phrenic nerve supplies sensory innervation to the mediastinal pleura, which covers the mediastinum.

 

Option D. Medial part of Diaphragmatic Pleura: The phrenic nerve also provides sensory innervation to the central part of the diaphragmatic pleura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The phrenic nerve innervates the diaphragm and provides sensory innervation to the mediastinal pleura and the central diaphragmatic pleura.
  • However, the costal pleura is innervated by the intercostal nerves, not the phrenic nerve.

questions.text: A 34-year-old gravida 2 woman, who was induced at 34 weeks’ gestation due to severe preeclampsia, has just delivered. What is the most appropriate uterotonic drug to administer during the third stage of labor to prevent postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inj Oxytocin 10 IU IV

 

  • Oxytocin is the uterotonic drug of choice for the active management of the third stage of labor, especially in women with preeclampsia.
  • It is effective in promoting uterine contractions, thereby reducing the risk of postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Oxytocin is preferred because it has a rapid onset of action, is effective, and is associated with fewer side effects compared to other uterotonics. In
  • preeclamptic patients, oxytocin is particularly favored because it does not raise blood pressure, unlike methylergometrine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol 600 mcg PO: Misoprostol is an alternative uterotonic that can be used when oxytocin is not available. However, it is usually administered rectally or sublingually rather than orally for this purpose. While effective, it is not the first-line drug in this situation.

 

Option B. Inj Methylergometrine 200 mcg IV: Methylergometrine can cause significant vasoconstriction and increase blood pressure, which is particularly risky in a patient with preeclampsia. Therefore, it is contraindicated in such patients.

 

Option D. Inj Carboprost IM: Carboprost is another uterotonic agent that can be used for controlling postpartum hemorrhage, particularly in cases where oxytocin is ineffective. However, it is typically reserved for cases where there is a lack of response to initial treatment due to its side effects, such as bronchospasm and gastrointestinal disturbances. It is not the first-line choice in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Oxytocin is the first-line uterotonic agent for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage during the third stage of labor, especially in women with preeclampsia, as it is effective and does not increase blood pressure.

choices.text: Lateral semicircular canal becomes vertical
Posterior semicircular canal becomes horizontal
Superior semicircular canal becomes inferior

questions.text: In the fizgerald-hallpike test (image given below), patient is made to lie at 30-degree elevation from the supine position. Due to this position:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lateral semicircular canal becomes vertical

 

  • In the supine position with a 30-degree elevation of the head, the lateral (horizontal) semicircular canal, which is normally oriented horizontally when the head is upright, tilts and becomes nearly vertical.
  • This change in orientation is crucial for detecting vertigo induced by BPPV affecting the horizontal canal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior semicircular canal becomes horizontal: The posterior semicircular canal, which lies in a vertical plane when the head is upright, does not become horizontal in this position. It remains mostly in the vertical plane, and this option is incorrect in describing the effect of the position used in the Fitzgerald-Hallpike test.

 

Option C. Superior semicircular canal becomes inferior: The superior (anterior) semicircular canal is oriented vertically, and its anatomical position does not change to become inferior when the patient is placed in the described position. This option is incorrect.

 

Option D. All of the above: Since only the first statement (A) is correct, this option is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the anatomical orientation of the semicircular canals and how different positions of the head during the Fitzgerald-Hallpike test affect their orientation, particularly in relation to the diagnosis of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).

choices.text: Autosomal recessive inheritance with a mutation in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 gene
Autosomal dominant inheritance with a mutation in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 gene
X-linked dominant inheritance with a mutation in the FBN1 gene
Autosomal recessive inheritance with a mutation in the FBN1 gene

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought in with a history of recurrent fractures, blue sclerae as seen in the image, and hearing loss. His mother mentions that she also had frequent fractures in childhood. Which of the following best explains the genetic basis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal dominant inheritance with a mutation in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 gene

 

  • Osteogenesis imperfecta, especially types I and IV, are often due to autosomal dominant mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, leading to defective type I collagen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal recessive inheritance with a mutation in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 gene: Osteogenesis imperfecta (OI) can have autosomal recessive forms, but these are rare. The common forms, especially those with a family history and mild to moderate severity, are autosomal dominant.

 

Option C. X-linked dominant inheritance with a mutation in the FBN1 gene: This describes a different condition, Marfan syndrome, which affects connective tissue but does not typically cause blue sclerae or recurrent fractures.

 

Option D. Autosomal recessive inheritance with a mutation in the FBN1 gene: FBN1 mutations are associated with Marfan syndrome, which has autosomal dominant inheritance. Autosomal recessive forms of OI are caused by mutations in other genes, not FBN1.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is commonly caused by autosomal dominant mutations in the COL1A1 or COL1A2 genes, leading to defective type I collagen.
  • This genetic condition is characterized by recurrent fractures, blue sclerae, and sometimes hearing loss.
  • Recognizing these clinical features and understanding the genetic basis of OI is crucial for accurate diagnosis and appropriate management, particularly given its inherited nature.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine gynecological check-up. She is not currently pregnant and reports regular menstrual cycles. During the ultrasound examination, a classic appearance of the endometrium is seen, given in the image below. This appearance typically correlates with a specific phase of the menstrual cycle. Which phase of the menstrual cycle is most likely depicted in this ultrasound image?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Proliferative

  

  • The ultrasound image provided shows a classic trilaminar appearance of the endometrium, which is characteristic of the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • During this phase, which occurs after menstruation and before ovulation, the endometrium thickens under the influence of estrogen.
  • This phase is marked by a three-layered (trilaminar) appearance on ultrasound: a central echogenic line representing the endometrial cavity, surrounded by a hypoechoic (darker) functional layer, and an outer echogenic basal layer.
  •  This pattern develops as the endometrium prepares for potential implantation following ovulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Periovulatory: While the trilaminar appearance begins in the late proliferative phase, it is most associated with the proliferative phase in general rather than specifically the periovulatory phase, which directly precedes ovulation.

 

Option B. Secretory: In the secretory phase, which follows ovulation, the endometrium becomes uniformly thickened and echogenic due to the influence of progesterone. The trilaminar appearance is no longer present, and the endometrium appears more homogenous and dense.

 

Option C. Menstrual: During the menstrual phase, the endometrium is shed, and the appearance on ultrasound is typically irregular and thin, sometimes with fluid or debris in the endometrial cavity, rather than a trilaminar pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The trilaminar appearance of the endometrium on ultrasound is a hallmark of the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle. This pattern is an important indicator of endometrial preparation for potential implantation, occurring under the influence of estrogen as the cycle progresses toward ovulation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is in active labor. Upon vaginal examination, the healthcare provider notes that the fetal head is descending into the maternal pelvis with the anterior parietal bone leading the way. The provider suspects a positional variation in the engagement of the fetal head. What is this type of engagement called?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nagele’s asynclitism

 

  • When the fetal head engages in the maternal pelvis with the anterior parietal bone descending first, this condition is known as Nagele’s asynclitism (also referred to as anterior asynclitism).
  • In this scenario, the sagittal suture of the fetal head is displaced towards the sacrum, and the anterior parietal bone presents first.
  •  This type of asynclitism occurs due to the fetus's head tilting so that the leading parietal bone is anterior, closer to the pubic symphysis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Asymmetrical synclitism: This term does not refer to a specific recognized condition. Synclitism generally refers to the fetal head being symmetrically aligned, with the sagittal suture equidistant from the sacrum and pubic symphysis. "Asymmetrical synclitism" is not a correct term for the scenario described.

 

Option C. Synclitism: In synclitism, the fetal head is symmetrically aligned in the maternal pelvis, with the sagittal suture positioned midway between the pubic symphysis and the sacrum. Both parietal bones engage equally, unlike the condition described in this question.

 

Option D. Litzmann’s asynclitism: Litzmann’s asynclitism, or posterior asynclitism, occurs when the posterior parietal bone leads, with the sagittal suture closer to the pubic symphysis. This is the opposite of what is described in the scenario where the anterior parietal bone leads.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nagele’s asynclitism, or anterior asynclitism, occurs when the fetal head descends into the maternal pelvis with the anterior parietal bone presenting first, leading to a posterior displacement of the sagittal suture towards the sacrum.
  • Understanding this condition is important for managing labor, as it can influence the progress of the fetal descent.

choices.text: Septic arthritis; start empirical antibiotics and repeat cultures
Reactive arthritis; initiate NSAIDs and follow-up for improvement
Gout: start colchicine and evaluate serum uric acid levels
Osteomyelitis; perform a bone scan and initiate antibiotic

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient with a history of acute gastrointestinal disorder presents with acutely swollen knee joint, fever, and elevated white blood cell count. Joint aspiration yields cloudy fluid with a high white blood cell count but no growth on culture. What is the most likely diagnosis and the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Reactive arthritis; initiate NSAIDs and follow-up for improvement

 

  • Reactive Arthritis: This is an inflammatory arthritis that occurs as a reaction to an infection elsewhere in the body, often following a genitourinary or gastrointestinal infection. It is characterized by joint pain and swelling, but typically, the joint fluid does not show an infectious organism. Reactive arthritis may present with elevated white blood cell counts in the joint fluid, but cultures are usually negative.
  • Management: The primary treatment for reactive arthritis involves nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to control pain and inflammation. This diagnosis can be supported if the patient has a history of recent infection or other predisposing factors and if infectious etiologies have been ruled out.
  • Consideration: Given the patient’s presentation with an acutely swollen knee and elevated white blood cell count in the joint fluid but negative cultures, reactive arthritis is a plausible diagnosis. NSAIDs are effective for symptom relief, and follow-up is essential to monitor improvement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Septic Arthritis; Start Empirical Antibiotics and Repeat Cultures:

 

  • Septic Arthritis: This condition is an infection within the joint space, usually caused by bacteria. It often presents with fever, joint swelling and elevated white blood cell count in the joint fluid. Typically, cultures from joint aspiration should reveal the causative organism. However, in some cases, cultures may be negative due to factors like prior antibiotic use or low bacterial load.
  • Management: Immediate empirical antibiotic therapy is critical in septic arthritis to prevent joint damage and systemic spread. This includes broad-spectrum antibiotics that can cover common pathogens such as Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus species. Repeating cultures may be necessary to identify the causative organism if initial cultures are negative.
  • Consideration: In this patient’s case, the absence of growth on culture might be atypical for septic arthritis but not impossible. Given the clinical presentation, further evaluation and empirical treatment would be warranted. The presence of elevated white blood cells in the joint fluid supports an inflammatory process, which might be infectious or non-infectious.
     

 

Option C. Gout: Start Colchicine and Evaluate Serum Uric Acid Levels:

 

  • Gout: This type of arthritis is caused by the deposition of uric acid crystals in the joints, leading to acute inflammation. It typically presents with sudden onset of severe joint pain, redness and swelling. Joint fluid analysis usually shows needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy.
  • Management: Colchicine is used to manage acute gout attacks, and evaluation of serum uric acid levels helps in diagnosing gout. However, the presence of cloudy fluid with elevated white blood cells but no crystals on microscopy and negative cultures makes gout less likely in this scenario.
  • Consideration: Since gout is characterized by specific findings in the joint fluid and this patient does not have crystals in the joint fluid, gout is less likely the correct diagnosis in this case.

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis; Perform a Bone Scan and Initiate Antibiotics:

 

  • Osteomyelitis: This is an infection of the bone, which can sometimes present with joint symptoms if there is contiguous spread from the bone to the joint. Diagnosis is often confirmed through imaging such as bone scans or MRI and bone biopsy.
  • Management: While initiating antibiotics is crucial for treating osteomyelitis, the presence of elevated white blood cell count and cloudy fluid with negative cultures is not typical for isolated osteomyelitis without additional bone involvement or symptoms. Bone scans and further imaging would be needed if osteomyelitis is suspected.
  • Consideration: This patient’s primary symptoms are localized to the joint, and the lack of positive culture does not strongly suggest osteomyelitis. This diagnosis would require more specific imaging and clinical evidence beyond joint aspiration alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Reactive Arthritis is the most likely diagnosis given the presentation of an acutely swollen knee, fever, and elevated white blood cell count in joint fluid with negative cultures.
  •  NSAIDs are the appropriate first-line treatment for managing reactive arthritis, and follow-up is important to assess response to treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs used in leprosy treatment causes cutaneous Hyperpigmentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clofazimine

 

  • Clofazimine is an antimicrobial agent used in the treatment of leprosy.
  • One of its known side effects is skin pigmentation, where the skin can become darkly discolored

 

 

  • Additionally, clofazimine can cause ichthyosis-like changes, resulting in dry, scaly skin.
  • These dermatologic side effects are due to the drug's deposition in the skin and subcutaneous tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rifampicin: Rifampicin is also used in the treatment of leprosy and is known for causing red-orange discoloration of bodily fluids, such as urine, sweat, and tears, but it does not typically cause hyperpigmentation of the skin.

 

Option B. Ofloxacin: Ofloxacin is an antibiotic used in certain cases of leprosy treatment. However, it is not associated with causing skin hyperpigmentation. It is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal disturbances and tendonitis, especially in older adults.

 

Option D. Dapsone: Dapsone is another key drug used in the treatment of leprosy. While it can cause adverse effects like hemolysis, particularly in patients with G6PD deficiency, and methemoglobinemia, it is not typically associated with causing cutaneous hyperpigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clofazimine, used in the treatment of leprosy, is most likely associated with skin pigmentation and ichthyosis-like side effects.

choices.text: High altitude sickness
Metabolic acidosis

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor indicated?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) High altitude sickness

 

  • Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors, such as acetazolamide, are commonly used to prevent and treat acute mountain sickness (high altitude sickness).
  • They work by inducing a mild metabolic acidosis, which stimulates ventilation and improves oxygenation at high altitudes.

 

Other Options:
